review:
400 hrs and counting. perfect game for anyone who wants to play a combination RTS / turn-based strategy game. this is something that is both merciless and yet easy to grasp and tame. it is merciless because you can play 100 hrs on a campaign and lose. just flat out lose because you let some other faction roll you early on and you did nothing about it and you didn't realize how big of a mistake you made until it was wayyy too late. this is ultimately why i like the game - because it plays more like a simulator.

the easiness of outsmarting the AI in the land battles is offset by the fact that on the campaign map the AI will have massive armies all the time that come seemingly out of nowhere on higher difficulties. the factions will also all eventually turn against you. you versus the world. your 5:1 k/d ratio needs to be consistent or just one battle that ends poorly where your typical AI outsmarting strategies failed will cost you a region and perhaps the campaign.

also if you refuse to save and reload you will have a really, really tough time on higher difficulties. a "legendary" difficulty would solve this problem which is why i like other total war titles more. but this one is still solid

This game is the one of the worst total war game out there, a gigantic waste of my money.

-The AI is retarded.

The AI won't accept the most beneficial diplomatic offer. If it does, it makes the most bizarre and utterly stupid agreements. It also can't play battles for anything. I can place a rock on my chair and it would put up a better fight.

-The battles are stupid. 

Fort battles are a chore, as well as city maps. You have to micro the absolute heck out of everything. The troops are also super inaccurate. I can line up 120 elite men and they will ultimately kill ~10 men at most. This goes for cannons as well. They're useless unless you use them to destroy fort walls, and in that case only regular early-game cannons are worth anything. Rocket Troops and mortars are useless. So basically it's just line infantry spam with the occasional use of basic artillery when there's an annoying fort somewhere. 

My absolute biggest pet peeve of battles (this was the catalyst that made me uninstall the game) is when the AI puts units at the edge of the map and just makes them sit there. Why is this bad, you may ask? Because there is a time limit for battles. Even if you have 3 fresh regiments, if the enemy still has 1 cannon stranded in the middle of nowhere when time runs out, you lose. This made me lose a battle in which I sent >2000 riflemen against their swordsmen. 

-You can only play a select few factions.

There are 42 factions at the start of the game. Sounds cool right? Wrong. Only 11 are playable. The map doesn't even span the whole world, it only spans parts of the Americas, Europe, India, the Middle East, and small parts of Northern Africa. Yay.

Overall, this is a bad total war game. The only thing saving it from being the worst is the fact that this is set during the 1700's and there aren't many other total war games that are similar to this time period. Sure, this game can be fun sometimes, but it's pretty much a waste of money.

A must have for those interested in the era and RTS fans alike. 

From Foot Batteries to Ships-of-the-Line. I can think of few other games that depict 18th century warfare and the age of colonialism and imperialism on such a grand scale as well as this game. 

Presentation is pretty good overall though settlements on the campaign map may be a bit too small to see when fully zoomed out meaning you may not realise you can upgrade building updates (especially if you have turned off the advisor). 


In terms of replayability, there's lots of it. The Road to Independence campaign which basically depicts the rise of the United States from settlers in Virginia during the end of the 17th century, the French and Indian war where you play as the Thirteen Colonies to the full on Revolutionary War. This is intended as a tutorial for the main Grand Campaign mode (and also unlocks the United States as a faction for the main campaign, set at a later date however rather than starting at 1700). 

The Grand Campaign itself is probably the highlight of the single player experience. Here you pick a faction (and believe me there are lots) and start managing your empire. It can take several days to finish a campaign and even once you have met your victory conditions, the game gives you the option to continue the save at any time should you wish to do full map completion. The campaign mechanics are pretty in depth as far as total war games are concerned with the ability to manage taxes, your government ministers, build farms to develop villages into towns, then upgrade those towns and more though if you played something like Civilisation, it may be simpler than what you are used to. 

There's also the ability to play historical/scenario battles (which are basically pre-set armies) and also play custom battles. Finally there's multiplayer for those who prefer a human challenge. 

 
The game does show it's age however and it is a bit clunkier compared to the newer total war games though there's still plenty of fun to have. In some areas it is even better, such as campaign depth/mechanics and imo naval battles were at their best in this game. Battles are pretty fun as well though as is the nature of combat of the time, they can be quite slow and you may fine yourself and the AI trading artillery barrages for several minutes. 

As a final note, I highly recommend you check out the excellent DarthMod for this game. It makes many improvements to the game overall (too many to list here) such as improving the AI, larger unit sizes, more factions/campaigns as well as VFX improvements, particularly smoke from cannon and musket fire.

Empire Total War, was at the time of its conception, creative assembly's most ambitious game. That ambition from 2009 is still impressive over a decade later. First you have two campaigns (Three if you get the warpath dlc or buy the definitive edition). The first campaign is an episodic objective based campaign that is broken up into unlockable sections which unlock more of the map. This is for the main story line which is based around the American War of Independence (1770s). However the more important campaign is the grand campaign where you can pick from several nations in 1700 Europe, the Middle East or India (mods let you play as any nation in the game though) The map for empire is extremely large in scale, it includes All of Europe, North Africa, Middle East, India, the Eastern Part of North America, Central America and even some of Northern South America. There's also trading ports you can dock merchant fleets at across the world. 

Gran Campaign 
Pros
- Large map
- Many nations with diversity of units and cultures makes each battle unique 
- Naval warfare 
- Encompasses a long time frame (1700-1830s)
- There are region specific units as well as ones unique to certain government types and cultures so if you conquer land in North Africa you can recruit North African units, If you conquer land in the Americas you can recruit native Americans and so on. 
- You can buy and sell regions (however for AI to except you will probablly need to offer them one in a trade)
Cons
- Long wait times for certain nations (it is turn based after all)
- The AI is bad at negotiations and often can't be appeased
- Units don't need generals, so you can have as many single unit armies marching around as you want..... as well as the AI.  This can slow down turn times late game when every country has alot of random units just laying around. 
- Crashes are rare but do happen, especially after several hundred turns into a campaign (Save games frequently)
- Only Singleplayer 


Actual Combat 
Empire Total War has two parts, one part real time battles and one part turn based empire manage. (Multiplayer exists but only for the former)

- The AI can use tactics but more common than not the AI will just try to move it's army up to yours so everyone's in firing rang of each other. If they have horse based units they might try a half assed flank. Cannons and artillery exist and sometimes the AI positions them to where they can't hit anything. 

Naval combat 
- can be a little slow..... ships are clunky but its cool to see large three story ships with 50 cannons a side shooting at other large ships... and sinking them. 



This game was ahead of its time and luckily its still pretty cool now, especially if your pc can't run the newer total war games or you really just want your units to use muskets. For $25 its well worth it. 
Overall this game is a solid 9/10

Getting this out of the way first, not my favorite Total War, may even be my least liked one of the series.

As I recall, this was the first game of the series that tried to implement a provincial type system where you have your main city and then minor towns attached to it. It certainly lowers the amount of sheer sieges you have to do in order to gain land, which can cut down on redundancy. However in this game, there's no menu for controlling all the buildings in the province, which means that you have to manually check each minor town to see if it can be upgraded or not. There's a small icon that you may be able to see on the map but you have to actually be looking at it. That system can be a tad annoying to follow, especially when compared to their more recent games like Three Kingdoms which puts everyone on a list at the side of the screen telling you if you can upgrade something.

Battles are easy as hell, and you don't need to put very much thought into pretty well anything when ti comes to army composition, you can win the game by spamming line infantry only. All you gotta do, is get the fire by rank technology, then spam nothing but line infantry and send them in one giant line across the map and you win, you don't need cavalry bayonettes from the line infantry are like spear men, they murder cavalry, you don't need cannons because they are too inaccurate to do real damage to enemies before they reach you, you don't need any melee troops because they get wrecked by line infantry because they even get close, and if they do get close line infantry use bayonettes to be melee troops. Your one size fits all army is Line Infantry...and they are spammable, there's no limit to how many you can have. Militia have too low morale so they end up just running, grenaders are basically just crappy line infantry with a single special skill that does as much as line infantry.

For navel battles, brigs are your line infantry. While not the strongest ship on the sea, they are cheap enough to spam to the point where having a monster ship don't matter.

I really do think the multi-continental map is a pretty neat idea, although this is a little better expanded upon in alter games, such as Warhammer Total War. All good things have to start somewhere, and this is the game that started that one, along with the province setup.

Graphically, its pretty good for its time. Unit control in the battles feels old, there's options that ought to be there that are not which sometimes makes it frustrating to command your armies, especially if you like to group them.

Technology is a little different in this, where you can actually research like 4 things at once so long as you have the schools to do so, which means you could really out tech your enemies fairly easy.

If you like this era of time however, this is pretty good. From my limited knowledge, this does appear to be how they fought, in lines and such, so it would be good to get into.

I recommend this because no total war is bad enough to ever give a thumbs down, and I guess even though its my least favorite Total War, its still not a bad game.

One of my favorite parts of Rome II is that once you've conquered one side of the map and made a great empire, there will be another coming from the other side of the map providing another challenge. Empire doesn't really do that. Happily though, it takes a long time to secure a happy populace, so you can't just sweep across a nation in 5 turns.

Average game at best. I do love battles of this period but this game feels like beta. It was the the first one with Warscape engine/TW Engine 3 (32 bit) and they probably used it as paid test. This is the point where famous TW "sheet" optimization begins. Below i will mention good and bad things.

[h1]Campaign[/h1]

+ You can trade regions.

+ You can trade technology.

- Diplomacy is the worst i saw in TW games so far. It doesn't make sense. One modder mentioned that when Ai faction hates you, it starts with -140 penalty and will increase over time, unlike more reasonable and modern games where it will decrease over time. Expansion penalty is big. I mean in this era there were a lot of "empires". It's not like damn aggressive Roman expansion in antiquity. 
It is very hard to have a peace. AI doesn't want peace even after you won against them few times in a row. They can sign a peace treaty after you gave them tons of money and then attack you shortly after this.
Few times i saw same nations (like Portugal) being destroyed and then revived. 
AI attacked me a lot with small stacks. I can't remember the case when this problem was as big as in Empire.
AI logic in trade is stupid. They want regions all the time in exchange of military access. For real? Why would i give my region, especially when i don't need to walk around your country? Also i don't like guessing how much technology or region cost. Hard to trade.

- Sometimes AI army goes to local building, then away, then again near this building. I saw Venice exchanging units or something like that for too long. Waste of turn time.

- Interface is outdated by now. There is no reminder/notification tab with things like available building upgrade, idle unit etc. Not to mention public order/happiness tab. 
There is no modern building slot style. You have to find and select buildings on map instead of main city. Few buildings per province. With many regions it will become a chore. 3-5 buildings in one region. 10 and more regions. Come on...

- Workers riot too often. I lowered taxes. What else i could do? Had not enough money for buildings they like, but even then they hated me. Every turn i saw messages about "workers strike". A lot of rebellions. I mean like really a lot. 

- Government type change system is bad. You have to wait for revolution. I sided with rebels and they gave me one small army. My whole faction became an enemy before i captured my former capital. Thing is, while my faction was not playable my former enemies took advantage of revolution. Important regions were conquered and i had to declare war on two factions again. The benefits of different government types are not too great to justify this.

- You need to wait until the end of the year marked in campaign victory to receive achievement/ending video. If you have completed your goal too early - Prepare to play "skip turn" simulator.

[h1]Battle[/h1]

- Pathfinding is horrible. Cavalry was near my unit. I order my unit to attack cavalry and it took too long for them to turn around and attack. 
Custom path is also bad. Units with stop running when they change movement direction. 
Some artillery units doesn't move like regular units. I don't know the logic behind this. I tried different things from battle UI panel and nothing happened. When i used RMB, they shot at the ground. 

- Interface. Formation screen mainly. 

- Sieges are horrible. Worst sieges i saw in TW games. Empty small fort. As defender you can try shooting competition with your enemy and as attacker you can use ropes to climb the wall like action movie hero. It is too long and boring. 

- Combat pace/accuracy is bad. Units miss a lot. It makes the combat slower. Not because of morale like in more recent TW games.

[h1]DLC[/h1]

Bad. Five playable factions of Native Americans. All are identical. All are weak.

They can hide grass, forest etc but that will only make the battle longer since AI can be too lazy or stupid to come at you. 
Flanking is a requirement for natives. Of course if your units won't die before you can charge at enemy units. Even in close combat few of my units routed. Spanish cavalry was better. Bowmen are weak. They should have had better accuracy stat and/or range at least.
I took two Spanish settlements and rebellion happened soon. Around 5 units in each army. At the time when i marched to another Spanish settlement and had no local armies... I mean dealing with European rebellions as natives is a lot worse than as Europeans vs Europeans. It's not worth it.

[h1]Final[/h1]

I bought this game twice. The first time, 10 years ago I returned it.

This time, I made the mistake of watching some revolutionary war documentaries. Being the history fan that I am, I figured I'd put myself in the action. I figured after 10 years, this game would have made some progress on the bugs. Considering the reviews, how could I go wrong.

This game is like eating the perfect piece of carrot cake, only to bite into it and realize that the carrots went bad. Want an example? No problem Custer, here it comes.

You spend about 200 hours building an amazing empire, just as you do in all total war games. Eventually, things come to a climax and being the world domineering pioneer that you are - send in the full might of your armies.

First of all, you can't have more than 20 units on the battlefield at once. Is that because it's an old mechanic? Maybe. However, when you put 2 armies next to each other, you would expect the reinforcement area to be somewhere near it. NOPE. Instead as your howitzers wail away, an entire enemy army spawns literally inside you. I don't mind a bug or the occasional crash, which happens.

But for a completely broken game mechanic which was never fixed for 10 years and then call it the "DeFiNiTivE edItiOn". Give me a break. Also, it's really a bad design choice to continue this poor retreat mechanic. Are you telling me that Napoleon wanted to retreat his army at some point and instead of telling his men to march backwards, they did a giant zig zag randomly past their own fortifications right into a nest of enemies?

And don't tell me, "Oh... why don't you use mods?" Because I swear i'll slap you.

Normally I don't hate on Total War games but this is the only option for a american revolutionary version. The others are great minus that ridiculous retreat tactic.

Empire Total War is the biggest single release Total War in history by the huge scope alone. It's the only Total War game to encompass multiple continents on multiple theater. It's vanilla is not that great in mechanical aspects, considering it's poor engine optimization, bugs, and poor AI being some of many weakness this game had. But with enhancement and additional content from mods such as Minor Faction Revenge/Darthmod, this will made the game far better even than a lot of it's more modern counterparts. Using good mods combined with DLC will improve a lot of it's mechanics and unit diversity.

For me this is the best game in the Total War Series. The huge scope made conquering the globe and establishing colonial empire a possibility unrivalled in other Total War games of it's era. Already playing this for years, even when i got bored i will always find another time to return playing this again.

Scroll down past the paragraph for Bullet point problems,

[b]TLDR[/b]: Game is a really good concept and is really fun at some points but is so unbelievably buggy and unfinished in so many areas that it’s actually just not playable in its state.

And to start Sega is an absolute scum company for multiple reasons so please don’t give money to them. They've re-released this 11 year old game with a new price tag and no changes.

I really don't understand Steam reviewers most of the time! I rekon the 88% of people who have reviewed this game positively either have a large chunk of their frontal lobe missing, review the game based on a third party mod that they've downloaded, or enjoy dribbling over the game because they're fulfilling they're fantasies of marching imperial western soldiers into North America or india and murdering axe wielding natives en masse with musket rifles and Puckle guns (Gatling guns)

This is the first time i'v sat and given a list of cons on a steam review and i'm going to keep it short because I don't want to feel like a complete A tier dweeb, I don't feel the need to list Pros here because you can go and look at positive reviews for that.

Let’s start with the blatant fact that this game was released after Sega acquired CA and it was released way before it was ready you can prove this because there is loads of interesting history content, there’s a tonne of unique units and a good variety of nations to play as so you can see while playing they were originally aiming quite high with this game (to a level of the amazing TW predecessors) but it’s completely and unbelievably buggy and unpolished and you can see this very quickly while playing. I’ll list some major problems below, 

The Campaign map is exactly what you expect from a total war except for the amount of regions in the game is a bit odd, for example France and Spain are single regions with Paris and Madrid being the only cities in them, the Campaign AI is completely irrational, alliances mean absolutely nothing except for maybe the ones you are preset with and if you play on normal difficulty it will be a breeze sweeping through and winning, if you go up a notch to hard difficulty every single nation will declare war with you you won’t be able to make any money from trading because you don’t have anyone to trade with and you can’t really repair relations because after they’ve declared war on you, you have around a -100 point diplomatic negative for “At War” which effects your ability to make peace.

You regularly play a game of cat and mouse on the campaign map where a small army will use its incredible move points to sneak past your armies into the back of your country and just walk around plundering towns and sieging cities (this was especially bad when playing as Russia)
You just don’t have the eco early game to combat this and even if you send an army to deal with it if you auto resolve the enemy army will just gain another shed load of movement points and retreat halfway across the map again, continuing the tedious chase.

Army’s can disembark from ships, move a good amount of distance from the shore and siege and win a city in one move, this can take you by surprise and is hard to combat because of the distance that navies can move in one turn as well. ( this is only really a problem when you turn the “see AI moves” off in the options and you will want to do this so the end turn doesn’t take 2 minutes every time you end turn while you watch an AI in another continent move its navy around)

The Battles in this game are mind numbing. The only battles I actually enjoyed were specifically defensive in a field with line infantry if you have anything more complex then that the bugs will just ruin the fun, here are some examples:
[list]
[*]When sieging a fort with a good amount of artillery the game will very regularly have a major lag problem in the two fast forward speeds, actually making them slower than the regular speed.
[*]Also when sieging a fort i’v regularly encountered a problem where i will ask a unit to climb up the walls and they will leave about 10 soldiers stuck at the bottom effectively rendering the unit useless, unusable and broken for the rest of the battle.
[*]Being on the defensive side of a siege battle, fort walls are completely unusable and broken, your men will just glitch all over the place will constantly end up getting stuck, not manning the parapets, the click and drag deployment is completely clunky, and because units have to completely form up to shoot you can deploy men facing the inside of the walls that will probably route the enemy before they can do anything useful on the walls, meaning its more effective to just not use the fort walls at all during a siege defence 
[*]Artillery units are completely broken, you can have a line of cannons that will fire a shotgun type cartridge that will just route 2 or three units of infantry that approach them each
[*]line infantry need every single soldier to completely form up in a line before they fire a single shot, this doesn’t seem too bad until either your unit has two or three men that glitch away from the main unit on top of the fact that your men will move with the urgency of a 80 year old disabled man, meaning that until you unlock the fire and advance tech you cannot win a 1 v 1 against and pre deployed line infantry
[*]Infantry reloading just takes the piss you can’t skirmish with infantry because they just can’t reload in time to fire and move before being charged, if you move them at all it will cancel any reload progress, and again the unit has to be completely formed up to even start reloading. 
[*] Cavalry have very limited use in my opinion they can be very effective when you micromanage repeatedly charging into infantry moving away and rinse and repeating, but again because of bugs sometimes your cavalry will just walk into men rather than charge, they can sometimes charge in single file for some reason, they get tired incredibly quickly, they absolutely can’t stand and fight in a melee, they have to charge to be effective. I charged the heaviest cavalry unit in the game (special horse guards) into a unit of ‘firelock armed infantry’ through a breech in a fort wall. The cavalry charged in a two man file, i left them in a melee and they killed about half the infantry before losing 80% of their men and routing.
[*]I had a fleet of about 13 / 14 ships including HMS Victory, three heavy first rates (the most powerful ships in the game) 5 First rates, and the rest Razee frigates that i auto resolved against a single pirate second rate ship. I lost three razzee’s and every ship became damaged. 
[*]And to finish the reason I uninstalled, I had a battle between my two armies and one enemy army. The battle was predicted as even but because Empire came before CA allowed you to have larger unit battles your second army will reinforce and fill up your first armies unit cap one unit at a time by marching individual units into the map. This time the game decided to spawn my reinforcing units outside the battle and march the men one by one into the map where they were sat getting cut down by the enemy cavalry and then routing before i even had control of them.
[list]

[i]Yeah Coronavirus is happening so i have the time to sit here like a sad fuck and write all of this and keeping it short went out the window.[/i]

Empire: Total War was in development for around 5 years, and it shows in almost every aspect of its design.

To start with, it is an older game as of 2020. Yet despite that, it has a timeless aspect to it, similar to games like Doom or Quake. By that, I mean there's a level of polish that you don't normally see in RTS games.

Practically each and every faction has unique voice acting, Prussian units speak German, American units have Yankee accents, etc. Each faction also has a unique playstyle, doubly so for the Native American units.

I have a good deal of respect for the developers for including Native Americans in the game. They really took their time to balance out a faction that didn't have the same technology level as the European units. Native troops are deadly when compared to the Europeans in the game, but only when they can get in close.

The naval battles are there for those who want them, but I personally didn't enjoy the laggy combat and avoided engagements as a result.

Overall, I have spent most of my time in the Battle Simulator, running different combinations of units against each other. The rock, paper, scissors dynamic of infantry, cavalry, and cannon feels timeless. If I had to guess, the tactical decisions the player makes in this game are very close to those that historical generals had to make.

The campaign mode is fun, but I found that after a while it was very easy to build a death-stack of units and just roll over my AI opponents.

I'm going to level with you: this game is pretty crap. The AI is broken, the number of exploits is unreal and the campaign feels like spanking a legless donkey.

But... I had fun. 96 hours of it which I don't regret (my Mum does but she's always disappointed in me). The gameplay loop is dull and repetitive but somehow really has its moments. The campaign is essentially a steamroll through the moronic AI who couldn't lead an U6s football team let alone an 18th century expeditionary force, but there's quite a bit of satisfaction in doing so. The online and ship battles are probably the saving grace for most, being pretty damn fun when the servers aren't fulfilling their suicidal fantasies.

This game tried to do so much new and gets a bad rap in the Total War community because much like what my last girlfriend would say, it just didn't follow through. But also like my last girlfriend, if you ignore the mess of the overall body, there are some fun bits to play around with.

Would I recommend you pay for this game? NO! Christ no! Go outside or get a job or pay for something worth investing in like a PornHub Premium. 

Is it worth your time? Probably. 

But it's probably also worth a refund WHICH I CAN'T GET BECAUSE I'VE PLAYED 96 HOURS OF THIS GODDAMN GAME.

When you start out in the campaign, the initial impression is amazing due to the large scale of the game, as you can have battles in the Europe, India and the Americas. There are also Playable Naval Battles this time. But as you progress along the campaign, various problems start to appear mostly related to AI, both on campaign and the battle maps. The campaign AI is not suited to for this large scale of the map. Also the Maratha Faction will become overpowered in the mid game and will launch attacks all across the map, sometime even in America. I would suggest installing Darthmod along with BranMacBorn AI, and your experience of this game will be much better.

I have dumped countless hours into most of every Total War game since my cousin showed me Rome when it first came out.  I love this one, despite everyone saying that Napolean is the better one, I am the opposite.  Maybe it's my love for this specific time period or maybe because I ended up playing this one before the other one.  I don't know but I really dig this one!  

One thing that I still find difficult is the sea trading and battles.  I've always found myself not being able to keep up with the rest of the world or running out of money too quickly. But, always room for improvement.  I especially enjoyed playing as Native American tribes and trying to rewrite history but of course in the end, the diplomacy in this game is always forcing you to do something you don't want to do despite having many resources to entice said nation into at least being peaceful with you.

All in all, if you like the Total War series. Get it.

Why this is one of the greatest total war games of all time. 

Like Rome 2 this suffered from a painfully bad launch but, the problems were fixed.  No factions were locked behind a pay wall and only 1 campaign and a few units were and all together you can pick this game up for 30 bucks or less with all dlc. It's really well worth it. It's a faithful and beautiful recreation of 1700s Europe, America, and India. This is the only total war game to date to include multiple map zones. It's a shame they didn't do it again. The mods for this game are great as well. You can roleplay a lot too. All though the minor nations are mostly copy paste, at least their colors are different.

amazing

TL;DR Auto-battle doesn't work, making you fight EVERY battle, can be really tedious.

Honestly, play one of the other Total War games if you want to play a Campaign...the auto-resolve in this one is absolutely positively effed. In my experience it works better in Shogun 2 or the Warhammer ones (unless you play as Skaven). As much as I loved the first Rome: Total War it was pretty borked in that one too.

You will have to fight EVERY SINGLE BATTLE manually if you don't want to inexplicably lose when you outnumber the enemy four to one. It's tedious. 

When you clearly have the advantage it's just a waste of the player's time. I remember having this issue with over ten years ago when I bought it and having tried it again recently I can see that this is still the case. The issue applies to Naval battles, Sieges, Regular Battles you name it.

Egregious example: A single regiment of Line Infantry would NOT win against 3 regiments of Militiamen and a regiment of Minutemen even despite the Line Infantry's stat advantage. I attempted to auto-resolve this battle 3 times using a saved game and the A.I. failed it every time....So I fought the battle myself and it wasn't even a challenge and I lost less than 20 men and absolutely decimated the AI simply by walking forward and leaving my troops in fire-at-will... no special tactics required. Don't even get me started on how the AI will always lose entire ships during a Naval battle with an absolutely inferior force.

The Netherlands

I enjoy this game because I love the time period and I love the immersion. Just imagining how the disciplined soldiers march into the battlefield facing unpredictable death from muskets and canons is really captivating. Warfare has really changed after the practical use of gunpowder, it seemed to have removed the romanticized picture of battle, as an individual line soldier they barely have much control in the fight other than reloading as fast as possible and hope you hit the target and hope he doesn't hit you.

The music in this game is really good, I always find myself enjoying the loading screens because of the soundtracks, IMO it's one of the most beautiful OSTs in the franchise. Empire Total war is a decently priced game that is good, but flawed.
First of all, you do not need DarthMod to have a good time.

Trading is short but sweet, simple to learn, and entertaining to master.

Combat feels epic, strategy creates a skill gap that satisfies you, and makes you feel as if you are one of the greatest generals.

Siege battles are to be avoided, glitchy, boring, overall bad.

Navy combat is confusing and hard to control. This is the first game to fully implement this feature though, there are stepping stones.

Artillery is just right, not being overpowered or underpowered. It can give a strategical defense, but if exposed, can be a waste and a huge loss.

Calvary and skirmishers are cool to use and give you an extra sense of strategy and an edge over your opponent.

Graphics, although not as good as the new games. In my opinion, are excellent. The game does not lag even though there are hundreds or even thousands of bodies everywhere.

However, I feel as if punishment is too severe. One volley should not massacre enemy units. Armies should not leave battle as if they were defeated completely. Wars are fought by attrition and manpower, not by one battle to see who can massacre another army quicker and leave the enemy capital exposed. This does though give an advantage to mobilizing which, again. General, epic.

Hope you enjoyed the review as I have edited this and made sure it was full of my opinion on this game. This should give you insight on whether or not to get the game and whether or not you should play it.

Well, I'll be honest. This is probably the first (and hopefully the last) game I've bought on steam that I felt the need to refund shortly after trying it out. Now, I'm not a complete stranger to the Total War franchise. I've got a relatively old disc-copy of Medieval 2 with the Kingdoms expansion, and recently took advantage of Shogun 2 being given away for free (while also buying a bit of DLC to complete the experience).

Maybe I was a bit biased after experiencing the two aforementioned games, but my first hour of Empire was... bizarre. The UI makes a rather sharp divergence in terms of infantry control--which, by the way, seemed to not want to cooperate with my attempts to form firing lines that AREN'T at weird angles--and the introductory campaign... well... Look, I understand that it's meant to ease you into things, but each battle ended up turning into an overly-long wait time for the troops to line up and fire. They don't even fire in ranks, either--no, apparently you don't get that yet. Thus my foray into having to micro-manage a bunch of different groups of soldiers with (seemingly) wonky control systems across the battlefield began.

I suppose what bugged me the most was how... boring everything felt. Maybe it's the comparative lack of melee units smashing into each-other. Maybe I just had the wrong set of expectations because of previous experiences. Take it with a grain of salt if you will, but I just can't recommend the game after such a lousy first impression.

Hell, if you want some good and fun line-battle action, go get Fall of the Samurai. How an expansion set in a just-then-industrializing country managed to make the gunpowder units more fun than a game about globe-spanning empires is beyond me.

Empire is by far my most favorite Total War game, with only Napoleon a close second. My reason for my love of the game is it's setting, this time period is my most favorite in world history. I think I love this game the most though because of it's trading system, I love to expand trade and fight over the most profitable resources, I love to send ships to South America to get one over on the enemy. The factions are fantastic choices, my favorites being the US, United Provinces, France, and Sweden. The graphics were great for it's time, and the combat gameplay is very good. The musket combat is so satisfying watch and hear, I love to send rangers to snipe the enemy general and cause his troops to panic.

The game is not without issues, but they are quite small in my opinion.

The US should just be a faction you can start playing as, not only unlockable at the end of a story mode which honestly isn't that great.

While I am perfectly fine with the size of the map, I do wish it was a little bigger over in Europe. Even North America could have have more regions to take, there is an entire empty area in the midwest that you can't do anything with, not even build a city. And they are missing major cities like New York City, which is weird because it was a major area of fighting during the various wars. It's missing a few other states I would of liked to see, like the Vermont Republic (who was it's own country for a little while) and maybe Trenton, New Jersey, which saw a lot of combat.

I'm not fond of the fort sieges, I don't think most people are. They're kinda boring...

Sometimes the AI's pointer for shooting is behind them even though I told them to attack in front of them. It doesn't always happen but in order to fix it just keep double clicking and it will fix.

So yeah those are my issues, they aren't a big deal to me, and a lot of fixed with mods. In fact this game has fantastic mods I suggest. I personally use Empires of Destiny which is a bunch of mods put together in a pack. Either way, I very much recommend this game, even without mods.

I own Rome 2 TW and Medieval 2 TW.I love the concept of all the Total War games.

Empire Total War

Pros-

#1.Good graphics

#2.My speakers sound like they will explode from the cannons

#3.It is cool to fight as USA.I'm American

#4.It takes real strategy to manage money in the game on the harder difficulty settings

#5.I like that time in history

#6.Native Americans

#7.The naval battles look cool

#8. Mass murder of the enemy who has been pissing you off is a delight

#9.Multiplayer is in this game but I have not tried it yet

Cons-

#1.The enemy AI is really stupid in battles.They will fire cannons at their own men trying to kill you.I was in a battle today and the enemy killed their own general with a cannon and he was 2 or 3 feet in front of the cannon when they fired it.They will also fire cannons at the bottom of a hill and hit the top of the hill over and over and do no damage to you at all

#2.Your soldiers will shoot and kill their own countrymen in fire at will mode.They are bots and do not think.If you have tired soldiers falling back they will get shot by your own men even if they are 3 feet in front of the fire at will soldiers who are shooting at the enemy at the most far point of their range.

#3.When your soldiers enter buildings in battles it is awkward and is really slow

#4.There is a bug when soldiers die sometimes half of their body might disappear into the ground.It just doesn't look realistic

#5.The other countries have no personality.When I am doing trade talks it feels like I'm negotiating with the same bot mind every time

#6.The AI of your opponents knows which of your cities/towns have little to no defense without having a spy or anyone anywhere near it.This is sadly an issue for most total war games.What I mean is they will declare war on you and attack you if you are weak at one city but with no way of knowing that.It would be like I went to rob your house and I knew when you were leaving and I knew where and how to disable the alarm without anyone telling me and without ever seeing your house before.You could call it more of a challenge but I think it sucks.It is really expensive having enough soldiers to defend against a full army who don't fight.Even when you are at war already the enemy knows which of your cities are the weakest magically

#7.The navy AI is stupid.It is not realistic

#8.If your soldiers are attacked at one end of the line in melee the rest at the other end will do nothing even if there is no one near them for melee and enemy soldiers are in range to be shot.They have to wait for the enemy who is in melee combat with the other end of the line to finish before they do anything.In this example they can be in fire at will mode the entire time.I'm talking about the same squad of soldiers together

The Bottom Line -

There was some cool and fun stuff to be found with Empire and I do not regret buying it.It takes games like this to point the video game industry in the right direction.I can't wait to see this same type of game remade in 2029.

I would recommend this game to casual military strategy fans only.

If you are looking for a realistic game than this is not it but it is still fun to play.

This is a very fun game, given it's age. The graphics are dated, but if you like strategy games, you're not that concerned with graphics, you want game play. Computer AI is not the best, also it is frustrating when you defeat an army, it scurries away - you have to keep chasing it and defeating it over and over again. 

Also, if you have say a Four star general, five cannons, six infantry units, four horse units basically a good sized army - but you face some broken rebel army of barely four units. If you auto battle it, you'll lose a large amount of men - it's silly, very silly indeed. So, sometimes it is best to fight the battle, even though you have an enormous force, versus a couple of camels and some peasantry with muskets. 

Diplomacy is not great - I had Austria repeatedly demanding I give them vast territory for nothing more than a trade agreement. 

All in all, given how old it is - yes I would buy it, but expect imperfections. 7/10 and that is in 2020. Maybe it's the 'lock down and self isolation' speaking, but it's worth a purchase.
If you like strategy games and also like tactical warfare then this is another gem in the TOTAL War series of games.

It's morning, the morning of your regiment's first battle.  Last night's fog slowly lifts, revealing a sprawling verdant plain.  In the distance, you catch a glimpse of the sun reflecting off something.  It's a sword blade, held high by an enemy officer.  With a smooth, practiced motion, he slices it downward, and lines of infantry appear, marching over the crest of the hill, their muskets tipped with gleaming bayonets.  You're nervous, so are your comrades.  You can hear the sergeant in the back reassure some of the men.  You take a breath and steady your nerves, for whether this day ends in bloody defeat or glorious victory, you will have done your part for your family, for your people, for your empire.

Like the rest of the Total War franchise, Empire is played from a macro perspective; you control a nation as it enters the early days of the 18th century.  You decide what will be built, how resources are traded, and if need be, how to wage war.

Empire Total War can be played multiple ways.  First, you have the ubiquitous Grand Campaign, which sees you select a nation to play as and lead to victory.  The goals are fairly simple: depending on what mode you picked, you'll be tasked with capturing a set number of regions.  Some of these regions will be determined by who you play as.  For instance, while playing as Russia, you have to have Moscow among your holdings to be victorious.

Capturing a region is fairly straightforward.  Simply capture the region capital, either by a swift decisive action, or a long strategic siege, and the entire region is yours.  You can decide what will be built in the city itself and the various towns that dot the map.

Cities come with a handful of build slots, each related to certain types of buildings.  The administrative building for instance can be upgraded from magistrate to governor’s residence, and later you will have the choice to turn in into a military governor’s barracks which grants stronger units or the more economically advantageous government council.  Most of the time, the choice is whether to spend treasury on upgrading a building or not.

Any empire worth its salt needs a strong army to back it up, and you have a fairly wide selection of what troops to recruit.  The time period the game takes place saw soldiers armed with muskets line up in tight formations, firing at once in the hopes of hitting something.  This line infantry will no doubt make up the bulk of your army, but be sure to support them with every general’s favorite new toy: cannons!  These beasts can bombard enemy forces at range, and with any luck, you might actually hit some of them.  Their true power becomes apparent when directed at fort walls or at close range with cannister shot.

Don’t forget to defend your flanks, either.  An assortment of cavalry will do you some good, as these fast moving units can harass enemies, or break a formation with a well-timed charge.  Various light infantry units available highlight the shift in warfare happening at the time.  Some units can hide in dense woods or employ skirmishing tactics, like the rangers.  While they are fun to use and quite effective at flanking the enemy, they won’t last long under concentrated fire, so be sure to maneuver them to maximize their effectiveness.

Now let’s get on to the reason you had your eye on this game in the first place: the battles.  Despite all the economics, diplomacy and research you can direct your attention to, Empire Total War is – at its heart – an RTS.  Before a battle starts you will have an opportunity to array your units how you want with a certain highlighted area of the map.  During this time, you won’t be able to see how your enemy’s forces are arrayed, so remain flexible.

These encounters can range from a force of 100 vs 100, or one of well over a thousand taking on a similarly sized foe.  Order units is as simple as selecting them and using the right mouse button to direct them somewhere on the battlefield.  By hold down the mouse button and dragging, you can further dictate how many ranks they form in, that is, how many lines of men they will stand in.  The preferred method at the time was three ranks, but as commander, you may find an unorthodox approach may serve better to win the day.  With 20 units taking position, it may be confusing how your formations will look once they get into position.  By holding the space bar, helpful green dots will show where your troops will be once the reach their destination.

Be sure to zoom in on your units, as they are all very well detailed.  It’s entertaining to watch an officer draw his pistol while his men hurriedly reload their weapons.  The sound design deserves special mention her as well.  The crash of a musket volley and the cries of men charging into the fray add to the excitement of the battles.

Empire adds a new front to the struggle for world domination: naval battles.  While naval combat in this game has been praised quite a bit, I find them slow and unintuitive.  Ships have a hard time maneuvering around the enemy and never go quite where you want them to.  Fortunately, the game comes with an auto-resolve button that allows a battle to be carried out, whether on land or sea, without your direct control.  I usually only use it for naval engagements as I can’t stand them.

In addition to the Grand Campaign, Empire Total War offers a story mode, in which you fight your way across our nation’s earliest engagements.  The first missions teach the basics of combat and nation management, so I’d recommend trying this mode first.  You take command of regiments made up of early settlers, and later fight under the crown in the French-Indian War.  Then, you lead America in its struggle for independence and securing its place in the rapidly growing world.

Empire Total War has provided me with hours of enjoyment.  I could tell stories for days about how sixty ranger held off an entire French army, or how British held fort deep in enemy territory fought off wave after wave of assaults.  Massive armies clashing on damp plains, cavalry charging across a bridge in the nick of time, but I won’t subject you to those now.  Instead, I encourage you to give this game a shot and comment with some of your own exploits.  I tried to included everything I would look for in a game, but feel free to add anything I missed or what you thought of Empire Total War.

While I love it, it must be said. This game is absolute trash. It's an unfinished beta of a game that wanted to be too much, in a time when development was harsh and unforgiving, under the direction of a new publisher that most likely moved all of the staff from Australia to Britain, cancelling a great deal of what was being prepared in the meantime, reorganizing personnel hastly and \ or with terrible timing and awful decision making.
While at its core Creative Assembly was still MTW2's old crew, many - including the battle mechanics programmer - went away mid development. This disorganization coupled with absurdly placed goals and SEGA's demands, created the perfect storm. Empire Total War is the result of a small studio being acquired by a greater entity and put on a forced march towards glory; they needed to literally touch the Sun, and just like Icarus, they failed and landed on their head back to Earth.

Up until mid 2011 - release was March 2009 - the game was borderline unplayable. For well over 2 years musketeers wheeling into the foreground with no AI, terrible campaign crashes, endless loading times, and a plethora of bugs and glitches made the experience awful. But the scope and the novelty of such an endeavour still attracted masses of casuals and the most hardcore groups of exploiters went on to form elite squads of competitive ETW gamers. I was in one too at the time, an international competitive group with a strong German presence. For almost 3 years we got together every week to ruin everyone's fun because winning in this game was - and still is - totally based on exploits. Units have godawful balancing, the speed and impact of all cavalry is all over the place; you can place 2 rows of light cavalrymen behind your infantry and have 3 volleys of instant fire that WILL destroy any unit present beside Guards. If you were a newbie, or even an intermediate player, you'd be completely screwed in a competitive setting, and even at a casual level, the amount of exploits was so atrocious you'd be a winner even in a 2 v 1 secnario just because you'd be making  a 10 Guards 10 Artillery army and flood people with mortar fire. Ragequitting was the norm for everyone. Netcode has always been awful to the core. The few people that still play it in MP know every nook and cranny and can destroy anybody with a thought because all of these incredibly frustrating balancing choices are still there.

The SP side isnt any better tho. AI is an absolute mess of convoluted nonsense. Coding and optimization of the campaign map and battle maps is so bad that it hurts even modern PCs. 
MP campaign was in development and testing phase but again, since this mess of a game came out rushing in through the door with at least 1 year of development left in the dumpster, the few lucky ones able to actually play any game got crashes upon crashes and loading a saved game even with perfect syncing would result in freezes as soon as you'd press the end turn button.
There is STILL an unavoidable, random crash in the Ottoman's turn after 11 years. Never patched, never fixed. The last patch they applied in 2011, while stabilizing the game a bit, completely destroyed the first person camera's coding. You cannot view the bullet trajectory anymore, not from muskets nor from cannons. The game just freezes mid-air.
Switzerland was planned and half finished in the code, but you cant enable it back. Pieces of development tools never given to the public were also half finished and thrown in the dumpster, waiting to be released only in late 2012 for Shogun 2.

I spent an ungodly amount of hours playing this game. I enjoyed it, but I wouldnt recommend it to anyone. It was amazing the first time I put my eyes on it back in 2009, and the few years I went nuts with all the exploits and a crew of dedicated companions to fight with. But now.... no, absolutely not. This game has been abandoned and left in a sorry state for a decade, the only thing keeping it somewhat alive are mods, and even those cant pull its butt up from the ground. There's no sendoff, no fanfare, and there never will be. The creators didnt love their baby enough, and put their necks on a yoke in servitude of SEGA's ambitions. There is no pity, nor remorse in here. Naiveté got their hands in the dirt. Few years later, with Rome 2, they'd prove themselves to be in the same situation. But that is a story for another time.

This game has far too many faults:
* naval combat is absolutely miserable slow motion micromanagement to even get your ships point the their guns the right way - and you can't avoid it as naval trade is the only way to have any kind of economy
* diplomacy is idiotic, especially on hard / very hard - everybody will always declare war on you all the time
* land battles are fun most of the time, but they can easily turn into an hour long slog while both armies stand still or very slowly walk around while the artillery shoots. And balance is really out of whack - cavalry is useless,  fancy unit types are useless, canister shot does all the killing, infantry just protects your canister shot artillery. This is especially true on hard / very hard.
* everything is so finicky, like often your artillery won't even shoot because of some microscopic difference in elevation you didn't even notice, so you spend next 10 minutes of your life repositioning before the battle can actually start
* there's a million bugs and exploits, and you're often forced to use them because base game is just too painful otherwise.

Overall it's totally playable, with mods (I mean I sure as hell played it tons), but it was definitely the weak point of Total War series, and it would be wrong to recommend it.
You'll be better off playing some of the better games like Rome 1, Medieval 2, or Napoleon, or Shogun 2, or Warhammer 2.

This game it must be said is one of the timeless classics, it's in my library next to Sins of a Solar Empire, it's a game that I play maybe twice a year, but everytime I play it I go for the grand campaign and I'm at it for a week or more, over the years I've clocked 127 hours playing TW empire.

Total War Empire is one of the masterpiece games that delivers long term playability without sacrificing short term enjoyment, a difficult balance to achieve for most game makers these days. You can be in command of an epic battle every few minutes, keeping the adrenaline up, while taking dozens of hours to beat a campaign (my current campaign has been 63 hours and I still have an hour or two left until victory).

I will admit, there are bugs, to be honest I've never played a game that was perfect UNLESS it was an extremely boring and short game. Besides the bugs are tolerable, you learn to work with the few quirky ways units behave in forts, and the game auto-saves every turn, so a crash only ever sets you back a few minutes, and the crashes are very rare.

One final con for this game: you can't play all factions, to be honest, there are A LOT, and for balancing purposes and also due to the richness of the game (each faction has it's own special units that are historically accurate), I wager playing as something other than one of the 10 ish factions you get to choose from just wasn't financially possible, or else would have take an extra few years of development. Still, I really would like to see an expansion for this game that didn't just allow for minor faction control, but also included some extra historical special units for the other minor factions. (Read: I wanna be a pirate okay?!)

I have spend over 150 hours in this game and it is still fun to play through. The battle gameplay is unique to the Total War franchise, and it is immersive and interesting as you coach your armies through battle. This game gets quite a bit of crap but honestly, especially with mods it's been an absolute joy to play. Are there some issues here and there of course, but not overly so compared to any other title in the franchise or even games in general. Still the only Total War game (that actually takes place on EARTH) which doesn't completely confine you to one or two continents (or in some cases an island... one... solitary... island. -_-) The only reason I say not to bother with vanilla is because either of the two main mods I'd suggest installing with it (Darthmod -or- Minor Factions Revenge) bring the content more "up to its potential" rather than making any unrecognizable changes but I'd say their required before one makes any definitive opinion on the game as most of the people who's given it a low score is largely judging on vanilla by itself. Its a load of fun and if you're new to Total War games a good first go given the more forgiving economy/battle mechanics compared to TW Rome and TW Attila. Highly Recommended.

When Empire: Total War was released, I purchased it immediately and then found out about how it required an internet connection after I got home. So I sat it down on my desk and it gained dust. When I bought it on Steam, I was excited to play and see how it went. I was not a fan. American History, especially Colonial Era, is a passion of mine. I felt that they did it justice in that sense, but when it came to the brutality I came to expect in a Total War title, I was very unhappy. Just a few cannons decimate an army and send them routing. Fort battles are practically impossible, you can't scale the walls without your men routing after fighting on top on them. You either blow open the gate and storm in or blow up the walls and storm in. The days of siege battles had ended in my opinion. In terms of fighting to the last man like you could see in earlier titles, units choose to flee the battlefield instead of hunkering down and staying strong. Morale is a joke, it depletes so quickly it doesn't really exist. Instead of having many options on how to fight an enemy, it feels as though the game wants you to fight in certain ways, or always lose. Does the enemy have cannons? Use cavalry to attack them or lose. Does the enemy have cavalry? Better shoot them with infantry quick. Do they have infantry? Figure it out or lose. The battles become less about military size and more about unit diversity. Which is an okay thing, but don't make it necessary to win. If I want to have an army only comprising infantry, they would overwhelm defenders of a fort, or an artillery brigade after getting close enough. If you loved the older Total War titles, this is different and should be approached with a small amount of skepticism. I suggest buying this on sale and not at full price.

This game is in the same niche as Napoleon: the recruiting system is vastly different than other Total War niches, like the older Total Wars (Rome I, Medieval, etc.) and the newest titles (Rome II, Attila, Three Kingdoms, etc.) The building style is also different. The game was meant to be experimental in many ways, being, I believe, the first to include three distinct theaters of war. I consider this game a classic and one of the best Total War games they've made. Overall, if you want a Total War title like Attila, you won't find it here. If you're looking for a historically accurate and unique experience, you've come to the right place.

This is just a mess, even with Darthmod its absolutely awful. The difficulty is more retarded than everything, if you put it too low it becomes boring and if you put it too high everyone hates you and wars you in 10 turns literally. Pretty historical, im sure. Also they still give you their shitty trades like demanding half my empire for some tiny garbage place.

I played as Prussia, I did nothing but existed. in 2 Turns Poland warred me. Turn 3 Austria did too. Turn 5 Hannover warred me, turn 8 Britain, France, United Provinces, some small countries arround me all warred me within the same turn despite that I had very positive relations with some of them. As you see nothing works, its just fake. I did not had a single offensive war yet the whole world wants to kill you and if you have good relations and spend time and money for that? Yeah that wont matter.

So yeah, the campaign AI and such feels like absolute and non-historical trash so enjoy having no immersion at all.

About the battles...garbage. The issue is that basically with Empire they introduced a new engine. Its also the downfall of Empire and literally any TW that comes after it, Rome 2 was also such a absolutely horrible game because of it. Why? Well because the engine has NO unit collision at all and only killmoves so enjoy seeing 1v1s all the time as your guys are glitching arround the battlefield as soon as they go into meele against someone, so much fun. The only thing the engine does is simulating projectiles well but everything else feels garbage. Even how your army reacts in battle seems totally stupid, it has a rather static and buggy feeling and the meele feels like im watching trucks driving against another and pushing themselves somewhere literally.

As much as I love the improvement on the campaign map about managing your empire and such and the way trade works  I want to recommend it but all the points above + a few downsides (agents autospawning, thanks game for giving me stuff on parts where they are not needed) is just too much. Nothing is fun anymore about it, the campaign AI feels retarded, they cheat, the battles are absolutely dumb and dont feel like a simulation at all even with mod unless you really go full ranged vs full ranged.

My recommendation: 

Avoid this or grab it on a cheap sale and be prepared for seeing some small improvements at the cost of big dissapointments. Grab Medieval 2 Total War instead, it does everything far better and with certain mods like Stainless Steel the AI wont cheat and behaves incredibly well while the battles are also well done and the whole thing does not feel too old or graphically bad either.
BEST TOTAL WAR EVER

Empire is that Total War game you go back to because there are non others set in this exact time period. While Fall of the Samurai expanded and made this concept of line infantry tactics work, it was constricted by the incredibly limited Japan map, to which Empire has the whole European front, the Americas and India to take over.
.
Of course, the way I describe this makes it sound like one of the best Total Wars to grab on steam. Well, in normal cases you'd be right, but CA is not normal. Nor is the corporate goliath behind them, SEGA.
.
This game suffers from a wide arrange of problems. Such as the AI not fighting according to the tactics that the period demands. They initially just like to bayonet charge by default, and enemy artillery tends to get stuck on open terrain, as laughable as that sounds. Not to mention that your own armies have issues of their own, such as not firing when their supposed to. Or taking too long to get in formation. And don't get me started on the seiges, if you think the AI sounds bad enough on land battles, then seiges will be like swimming up shit creek with your bare hands.
.
Grand Campaign is lacking severely, with rebellions easy to quell, broken economy, and only a semi decent technology tree (I'll give it a pass since Empire is the first gave to have a tech tree in the first place)
.
The thing I enjoy about the tech tree is how it upgrades your basic units to perform better on the battlefield. Something that Warhammer adopts to great effect. 
Sound design is severely lacking, with muskets sounding like cap guns, and artillery having a fwomp sound instead of the deadly thunderous noise it tends to have in real life. It sounds less like a war, and more of a reenactment. The music is dull, composed by Richard Beddow instead of Jeff Van Dyck.
.
Beddow's music is great, as he captures the feeling and spirit of the time periods and did fantastic work on the Warhammer games. While not as intense as Jeff Van Dyck's use of drums and vocals, it still captures that Total War feeling. In this game, not so much. I don't feel a whole lot of intensity during battles, they feel like they should be a spectacle instead of an intense game of strategic planning. Needless to say, this is not his best work. After the first time you hear it, it tends to annoy you to the point that you mute the music and find solace in only the sounds of war. Which is just to my liking for games like this.
So why am I recommending this? And why do I have so many hours logged into it?
Because the game can be incredibly fun and immersive if you have the know-how to mod it to your liking. 
.
Darthmod fixes the numerous issues in the campaign map, whilst making fighting against the ai a bit more bearable. However as famous as it is, it's not enough to truly itch my historical sense.
.
That's where I recommend a mod called Imperial Destroyer
This mod retextures units, overhauls the sounds so that muskets and artillery actually sound like a wall of death, and massivly fixes the ai to actually utilize it's intended purpose of standing in a line and using mass volleys against you. Even seiges are more bearable to fight, and the mod has an option to remove fortresses all together. Rebellions are a lot easier to start, and income for your armies are a luxury. 
.
To describe in my best words how much this mod made me feel historically immersed. 
I found the 7 years war much earlier than should historically happen. The war, much like in history, drained my treasury upon my victory and long fought struggle, and I was forced to increase taxation in the colonies (which the mod just gives you control of right from the start) and it caused a rebellion to stir in Boston, which was the United States emergent faction. They pushed me out of the thirteen colonies and I was forced to watch history repeat itself as I brought my colonial troops overseas to help fight the french, who were gearing up to invade london. 
.
This historically accurate scenario was completely unscripted and gave me a feeling of immersion that the base game could never provide.
I'll be linking the mod here
https://www.twcenter.net/forums/forumdisplay.php?1930-Imperial-Destroyer
So now for my final verdict
.
I give Empire Total War a 6/10 for the vanilla experience
It's lacking in so many good features, but just innovative enough to not be the worst
Modded with Darthmod, I give it a 7/10
For fixing most of the issues, but still retaining that vanilla feel
Modded with Imperial Destroyer, I give it a 9/10
For not only fixing a lot of the core issues I had with it to begin with, but providing a completely Total War experience that should have been from the original game devs

I find it hard to believe I once loved this game. I write this in the hope that one day CA will finally right the course of this beloved franchise. It appears they learn the wrong lessons or ascribe their games' failures to the wrong reasons and double down on the problems instead of fixing them. It's insane that the biggest problems with this game are still present in the most recent total war games.

Restricted camera view should be illegal in RTS games period. A user interface is supposed to facilitate interacting with the game, not to make it a struggle. No one wants their nose buried in the dirt when trying to command an army across a mile of terrain. It doesn't make it "immersive" it makes it obnoxious.

The AI's idiocy will surprise no fan of total war - "very hard" should mean the AI making intelligent decisions, not every other faction suicidally declaring war on you for no reason.

Similarly, the really interesting aspects of this game and Napoleon - town wealth, ancillary economic buildings separated from the capital, etc - that held great promise for improving the depth of gameplay were reversed in subsequent games, actually dumbing down the economy in future titles to unbelievable levels.

A game with the worst AI in the history of strategy games.
Have you seen Scary Movie? Do you remember the scene with the "death" and "safety" signs? Well, the battle AI is like that girl and behaves the same way. An infantry rush on an artillery shooting grape rounds? Why not. Cavalry charge on an infantry with muskets? Sure! Or perhaps a cavalry walk(!) into a spiked obstacle slowly wiping out entire regiment? Yeah, that sound like fun! Let's do it!
Basicly all you have to do in a battle is place your forces, wait for AI killing itself and use cavalry to chase it and wipe it out.
Could there be something more dumb? Sadly, yes.
Diplomacy in this game is like a bad joke. Want some proofs?
Imagine yourself being an attacker in a war. Imagine yourself losing all your forces and three out of four provinces you own including your capital. Imagine yourself that the nation which is basicly wiping you out offers you a peace treaty which would give you all the provinces you just lost and all you have to do is just to take them back.
Now imagine that the AI in this game actually declines such peace offer.

The concept of the game is good, the interface is ok, but the AI is horrible.  On the strategic level I don't think any of the designers ever heard of Jomini or Clausiwitz and the result is juvenile play on the part of the AI.  At the tactical level, in the battle simulator, the AI operates its units beyond their capabilitites in order to compensate for the lack of effective tactics, such as faster unit movements, undocumented formations, and enduring casualty rates of 75% before breaking.  Although you can issue orders to your units, the AI constantly interprets them so as to inflict more damage upon yourself than to the enemy, particularly with artillery.  You have no control over when or if your units will fire.  The AI controlled units usually get in the first volley even if you are waiting in a defensive position.  The AI units fire from beyond their effective ranges.  Instead of using the unit flag (center of the line) as an aim point for artillery the right flank is used causing most shots to miss.  The AI use of cavalry is particularly frustrating, frontal charges on artillery supported by infantry where the unit takes 90% casualties and a the routed remainder still manage to make contact and rout your artillery.  On the other hand, if your cavalry charges the AI artillery it stops your unit in its tracks and stands and fights like Spartans, inflicting heavy casualties on your unit and not routing.  The battle simulator itself is not bad, if the designers could improve the way the AI manages its units instead of allowing it do ridiculous things then it would be a good product.  As it is now, I feel like somebody is just trying to piss me off with the lack of actual battlefield tactics programmed into the AI.

Empire Total War is far from a perfect game. Point to almost any element of the game and you can find a slightly better example somewhere else in the series. But no other game has rivaled the grand scale that this game delivers on. As a kid it was one of my formative moments in gaming to realize just how large a game could be - This game had parallel warfare on three continents, dozens of factions, and some of the most engaging battles. No other total war game (or most strategy games in general) has attempted to execute this mammoth a concept, and while Empire Total War is definitely rough around the edges in many spots it remains a cherished classic in my opinion.

I've spent a lot of time playing this game. I would describe it as a flawed masterpiece.

For all the issues it has with stupid battle AI, stupid campaign AI, poor unit variety and various bugs and glitches in both battles and campaign, this game captures the spirit of grand strategy like no other title in the genre. 

The ingenuity of having multiple theatres of war change the DNA of Total War in respect of replayability and strategic breadth. In pretty much every other TW title, it's about exploding outward from your starting location in a never-ending land war. In Empire, you have the option to strike into different continents. Trade and diplomacy are vital, as upkeep costs are well balanced to ensure the game doesn't turn into a complete and utter steamroll after the first 50 turns as with many other TW titles.

For all its flaws, if you spend a great deal of time with this game and invest in your narratives and the period, you'll find yourself playing it as much as I have.

If your looking for a grand strategy game that makes use of most of the globe then look no further. Set in the same setting as the 7 years war (google it). You embark as the leader of an imperial, monarchist, or republic nation of Europe conquering your enemies, maintaining strategic alliances, and facilitating trade. Use schools and colleges to advance your nations technology, allowing you to have the leg up in military engagements, foreign affairs, and domestic. dominate land and sea by use of real "era" battle tactics, whether it be ambush, hidden flank, feign attacks, or the real threat of canister shot.
This is a great strategy game for learning tactics of the era and it is great fun!
I love it. it includes strategy and amazing problem solving. but also exciting battles. an all around amazing game!

Brilliant game. I would call it the pinnacle of the Total War series. So much fun stuff to do: invade towns, defend hills, have glorious artillery battles, lay siege to forts, storm the governor's palace in an Indian territory, -and- have crazy naval battles, a nice touch to round out what is honestly the best RTS title I've ever played.
When you slow the battle to 1/4 speed, and spread your rifles out along a fence, and form a phalanx of cavalry around your field guns, you'll feel the tension of waiting for the enemy to advance and enjoy that moment when you give the order to fire at will.
There will be some amazing moments as you repel charges, rout an advancing unit and cause panic with concentrated fire, start a skirmish at one end of a fort while running your melee units over the wall at the other side, realize with horror that your last unit will be shredded by canister shot as it valiantly advances on the remaining battery, etc etc.

For  a history nerd who likes real time strategy, it is a heaven.  Not like other strategy games which tends to be too time consuming and slightly boring . You can easily finish this game in a breeze and get started with any other game you have in your queue , . . Highly recommended.

Many people familiar with the franchise considers this to be one of the worst Total War games, and they might very well be right... But it is still a very fun game, after all, Total War games are in general very good, and even (some) of the worst of them are still good.

It is true that it is extremely buggy, perhaps because the developers got too ambitious, and perhaps because this game was made in an all new engine, so quicksaving is certainly a necessity, but the game is absolutely still playable (mostly).

I am also very fascinated by this period (much more so than the medieval period) and this game has allowed me to watch and make, what I like to cal, "history fan-fiction", such as how India colonized Britain in the 1750s or the unification of Germany 150 years too early.

The most interesting campaigns have however been the ones, where I by modifying the startpos file allowed me to start as a tiny weak faction, such as Malta or Dargestan and then went on to turn them into great empires.

By far and away my favorite total war. 

Aside from steam, I played an easy 1000 hours on the CD when this first came out, and enjoyed every moment. Great replay value, even for the same factions. I must have played as every faction at least four times, and always had a radically different game. 

The campaign map is a marvelous progression from Medieval II. A huge map covering Europe and North Africa, the Middle East, India, North America, Central America, and the North of South America. There are also Four sea regions that have Trade Nodes. Brazil, Ivory coast. Strait of Madagascar, and the East Indies. Stretching across the globe, this gives you a true sense of world empire. 

The Combat is why I love this game. The ability to move any number of troops without generals in this age of warfare is perfect. You can run lightning raids and use several small detachments to hold strategic areas on the campaign map and harass larger forces.  My personal favorite is to have an all cavalry force supported by light cavalry artillery to scout ahead of the main body of infantry. "Buford at Gettysburg cough cough!" The Battle maps are large enough for maneuvers, and the terrain must be used to your advantage. A well placed regiment of good line infantry can turn an entire battle, or lose it. 

The AI is well, total war AI. Its either very dumb or you suspect it cheats somehow.  All and all for me it doesn't effect the fun of the game whatsoever. 

I highly recommend you grab this even if it goes back to $59.99 (It really shouldn't), but its worth the money especially if you are a fan of total War, The Age of Enlightenment, American Revolution (Great DLC by the way), and having fun sailing around with a frigate like Jack Aubrey. The naval combat, being the first of the total war series, can be wonky, but its the most glorious naval warfare in history, and loads of fun once you get the hang of it.

Obviously, the question of "which Total War game is greatest?" is very subjective.
