If you prefer the simplified campaign styles of later TW games, the micromanagement of Empire may get to you, but if you love Grand Strategy games like Europa Universalis or Victoria, Empire has that PLUS the trademark huge scale real time battles that made Total War a household name.

I found most negatives can be at least partially offset by something, so now that I'm rich it's been quite easy to give a few presents and get back on friendly terms with everyone other than your sworn enemy(s). Overall a great game that offers hours of play time.
Positives:
- The game offers a vast array of things to do. The multiple areas that you can focus on make the game take a while to complete with any nation. 
- trade doesn't have to be just between nations. Sending trading ships to the different areas also allows you to send profit back directly to your nation. 
- It isn't just about getting the biggest ships but instead having a nice mix of different ships for different parts of the battle.

Negatives:
- Artillery feels useless and the maps don't have a lot of hilly areas that allow you to use them from behind the infantry without the risk of hitting your own troops
- Adding on to the artillery, if you go into a battle, the artillery will have minimal kills at best because of overall poor accuracy but when auto-resolving the battles, they make it seem like artillery is key. 
- I got spoiled a bit with Total War: Shogun 2... having naval artillery in a battle would be quite nice in this game

To put it bluntly, this is a fine game even by 2019 standards. It offers almost endless replayability, with or without mods which have to be manually installed :( , and has a unique place among the Total War series with its combination of gunpowder weapons, naval combat, and trans-continental scale. The primary draws of Empire Total War (ETW for short) are the scale (most of the globe) and the period (18th Century). ETW has the distinction, for better and worse, among the Total War titles of being the first to feature playable naval combat and remains the only title where naval combat is heavily affected by prevailing winds. Given the vast expanses of the globe to trade with and/or conquer, naval strength becomes as important to the game as it was in the period - to a degree that no other TW title can match. The vanilla game did have its issues, primarily with campaign and battle AI that are the usual bane of all TW titles- it's difficult to get an AI to respond both logically (to its advantage) and in character (keeping with the historical/fantasy 'role' of the faction). Several post-release fan-created mods attempted to address this, with varying degrees of success. I highly recommend that players take the time to see what this game had to offer almost a decade ago and what it could lead to in the future.

I remember playing this game way back in the day when this was the top shit! :) Anyway, I decided to purchase it after all of those years. And I must say it has aged quite well. Of course, some of the mechanics (embarking/disembarking) might seem a little rusty, but that's just how the game was designed and it was designed like this for a purpose - if you know what the glitches or bugs are, you can work your way around them quite easily. Also the AI might be lacking compared to some newer games, however considering the size of the campaign at that time, it's just insane that the game doesn't crash all the time. I recommend this to anyone who loves to plan their campaign very slowly, just waiting for the perfect moment to strike. :)

Absolutely love the time period the game is set in and the detail that went into the ships and the combat units. The game may be deceptively easy at the beginning but into the mid-game of the grand campaign mode it can get challenging as all your neighbors begin to unite against you. While I found the battles fun (though the naval battles can be really slow) there is a discernible lack of unit variety and the diplomacy can be tiresome after a while. I really wish that this game had more diplomatic options than it currently does. The AI factions will never make peace with each other when they go to war and that really strips the game of a key strategic aspect: the formation and shifting of political alliances. For example: England has always been keen on preserving the balance of power in Europe, right? Well, they were also keen on fighting the French a lot as well. However, the two would be allies when the circumstances dictated it. In the game, England and France go to war really early and fight each other into the ground. Meanwhile you'll have Poland, Prussia, Sweden and sometimes even Austria gobbling up all of Europe while they do nothing about it and keep destroying all of each other's armies. Diplomacy also lacks the "liberate" option that Napoleon and other titles after had. So your ally was just destroyed and you successfully drive the enemy from their territory? Tough, the only thing to do is to leave their capital undefended until a rebellion starts and they get their capital back. Sucks though because then they'll be at war with you after. Those are my only real gripes with the game. The at times horrible diplomacy and the lack of unit variety. Other than that, I've had loads of fun playing the game and would definitely recommend it to others!

This game gets a lot of bad rep, but let me tell you out of the 500+ hours I have played, I don't regret a thing. This game covers an extremely interesting time in history, when the age of the pike ends and musket begins. Colonies are important to empires economically and strategically. This game has the most expansive map compared to any Total War game, with three massive theaters of war. Yes of course, this game has it's problems like some have mentioned, I've only encountered a couple bugs and issues, but overall I think this game is endless fun. Mods can help improve the game and give players more hours of fun, just gotta look for them. I truly think Empire Total War deserves a sequel or remaster, this game is gold.

I very much enjoyed the gameplay and how you can go to other continents extending your reach across the world. One part of the game i was not happy about was how there is a very small map in scale. where as in thrones of Brittania another total war game i would recommend there would be around a few dozen regions in Ireland alone, when we look at empire total war however we see there is only one settlement in Ireland. If we could a game where it covers the same amount of land that empire total war with the same in depth number of cities and regions as Thrones of Brittanaia then i could see a very long lasting and challenging campaign with many factions and different cultures. Having played the Battle of Brandywine which is one of the scenarios in this game I have come to the conclusion that it is simply appalling in so many ways. (a) the disposition of forces favoured the US (you play as the British) yet historically the reverse was true with the US army being smaller. The British have less artillery than the US, historically they had more and the   US has 16 x 24 lb guns where they had a 14 guns maximum of which the largest was a 6 lb. I suspect the moral of the US troops is higher as gunners charged downhill be cavalry in the flank managed to rout the cavalry. Similarly US rifleman who had no bayonets beat off cavalry when charged in the flank and routed them, something they patently couldn't have done.
The US artillery shoots across the map even when it cant see the enemy and chips away at the flank march which historically they weren't even aware of. The riflemen who were historically deployed on the opposite flank to the one the British flanking march took place on are now conveniently guarding the flank it did take place on. You could be forgiven for suspecting that the author of this travesty was an American trying to stack the odds in the Americans favour, but the AI is so stupid that its not that hard to win. There seems to be no way to rally troops who flee very easily. Not much thought went into this game and I regret wasting $9 on it when it was on special.

While this title have good things, it really could be better. Overall it is fun if u can overlook the many mistakes it have. It completes an important objective which is to simulate a war on a believable way, within the limitations of money, resources, etc.
However there are various glitches or things that, in my opinion, could have been better, without the need of changing too much.

Single Player: To be honest I didnt play enough of mainstream campaing to be able to correctly judge, however I played way more of warpath campaing, so my point of view will be directed from that perspective.
The campaing is pretty much another total war, but with different time period. Naval battles are interesting, but I think game main difference with others is the fact battlefield is ruled by guns now. However on campaing map, it is a restricted version of the shinier Medieval TW, or so. Additionally, warpath is kinda shit, regrettably it is a low budget DLC, maybe they had to focus on doing less factions but more complete. You get very limited options, tech tree, and not even boats.

Multiplayer and BattleCamp: This is where I spend most of the time. I usually play native factions. And I see they could be improved very much with small changes. This applies to most factions, but natives even more. There are some regrettables mistakes that hurt realism a lot. Units are very few, skins repeat too much, units are too slow (i believe this could be easily be changed), they also very dumb, like VERY dumb. Additionally 50% of the units rooster is shit on MP. Maps are pretty, but unbalanced.

Overall, it is a game which I enjoyed a lot, mainly because is one of the only 2 total war where u get to play native americans. This game strong point is ofc time period. But if u want a version of this game which is literally better on everything u should look for Shogun 2.
If u really like the time period, you should try it. Otherwise there are way better total war (I only mean shogun 2)

This is the tutorial, for the record.

I sieged a city filled with Frenchmen and natives, with a decently sized army that includes 3 artillery units.

My men march onto the city, knowing their duty. The music becomes more tense as we approach. My general inexplicably rushed the French general, who also happened to be rushing in the front lines. The first deaths of the battle are both generals.

OK, fair enough. I send 2 British units to flank some natives on the western side, sending the bulk of the army to the front of the fort to assault the rest. My artillery spreads out, firing upon the French... doing absolutely nothing despite direct hits. Speaking of doing nothing, the British sit there despite being ordered to attack, simply allowing the French to shoot their muskets. 

Not good. 80% of my army just routed. The French rush two of the artillery units, and the only infantry I have left are the 2 flanking units.

All of a sudden, every French and native man bolt out of that fort like kids leaving school. Quite confused, I say, "What the fuck?"

Those French fools were all chasing the sole artillery unit that happened to be across the map, on the hill. I casually take both British units and occupy 2 buildings in town. The French immediately march back after they rout the artillery... only to enter the city individually. Despite losing 80% of my goddamn army because of AI incompetence, [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/371887428761288725/605602028579717120/empiretotalblunder.mp4]I inexplicably win the battle because of AI incompetence.[/url]

After 10 years and 1,000 hours, I can say it is my favourite and the best of the Total Wars. I bought it about 18 months after release, and at that point it was very stable and quite playable. It has the usual CA quirks regarding historical accuracy, but there are several mods that make the game more "realistic" if that is your thing. The modding community is fairly quiet these days, but Total War Heaven and total War Center are still the places to go for mods and advice.

I'm currently playing vanilla for the first time in years, and the balance is surprisingly good. The campaign stretches across 3 continents and 4 sea areas, and it a diverse mix of fighting on land, sieges, commerce raiding, fighting pirates, capturing islands, naval battles and world domination. 

For me the biggest change from the previous games was the diplomacy. Other nations actually hold to their alliances making if your reputation is good. The agents are useful without being overpowered and the usual civil war mechanic still exists in the game.

I have all the Total Wars up to Warhammer 2 and this game is still the one I play the most.

An astounding strategy game where you will become the master and commander of the land and naval warfare of the 18th century. Empire: Total War is the first Total War game that I have ever played and I was thoroughly impressed.

Set during the 1700s, you choose your army (British, French, American etc...) and try to conquer the world. Aspects of the game such as diplomacy and military movement are done in turn-based strategy style but the game switches to a real-time strategy style for the combat. Both land and naval forms of combat are fun to play and watching the battles unfold is truly spectacular. It is very difficult to learn all the aspects of the game quickly so I recommend starting the Road To Independence campaign as that almost serves as an extended tutorial. The graphics in this game are some of the best I have seen and the sound is fantastic too.

Empire: Total War is a brilliant strategy game that is definitely worth picking up. I selected this Total War game as my first one because I find the era particularly fascinating. I have since played some of Shogun 2 and the gameplay in that is also excellent so ultimately, you will be drawn to whichever game features the era you are most interested in.

NOTE: If you do not have a high-spec machine, you may be locked out of accessing high graphics settings. You have to correct some hidden files on your computer to allow you to select high graphics settings.

Gameplay: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10 (for the time)
Controls: 10/10
Replay Value: 10/10

"Total War: EMPIRE" (2009) is a game in which you will surely spend many hours once you learn the basic mechanics.

As with any other "Total War" game, you're tasked with bringing a nation of your choosing to greatness and to expand said nation's rule and wealth, either through diplomacy, or through war. In this installment, you're playing in the 18th century.

Gameplay wise, the game is [strike]known[/strike] infamous for having dodgy programing and some major bugs/glitches (especially in the late game). Despite this, I believe that once you're skilled enough, you can achieve your campaign objectives before you encounter such issues. Both the campaign and battle HUDs are user-friendly and intuitive. My main issue with the game (other than the dodgy programing/bugs/glitches, of course), as with any other "Total War" game, is the fact that you only have a small selection of nations you can play as. Granted, this can be [strike]fixed[/strike] bodged with mods such as Empire Total Factions (which I have) or Darthmod, but I feel like this should be a part of the base game.

Overall, I give "Total War: EMPIRE" a 7/10. Worth buying if it's on sale.

This game is a good balance of tactical battle play and strategic territory play.

TLDR: A good game, plenty to keep you interested, but even the short campaigns are long (minimum 100 turns)

The game operates around two turns a year, with each power moving once per turn.

Conducting Battles

I particularly like the battle mechanics in this game.  When you opt to fight a battle yourself rather than use an 'auto resolve') you command your troops in units.  Each unit is typically 60 or 120 men and all are equipped with the same weapons and skills.  Given the period in history (from 1700) in the early game rate of fire and accuracy is low but improves slightly with new technology.  Units must be arranged carefully to support each other.  the AI performance varies so in some battles it's significantly more of a challenge to you than in others.  Some units have abilities that others don't and some can be more effective in certain situations.  For example Line Infantry can learn how to 'form square' making them much mire resistant to cavalry but Light Infantry can't.

There can only be 20 units from each side in the battle at a time, but if you there are additional armies nearby they can join the battle (they will march in from one edge).  Even small numbers of units can cope with an enemy with significant reinforcements if they are prepared for them as they enter the battle one unit at a time, typically away from the bulk of their forces.

The more experienced troops are the better their performance, including morale.  Also units can be replenished after a battle (unlike in Medieval Total War) allowing you to build up an army of experienced battle hardened veterans.

Naval Battles are also present in this game, and are quite tricky (at least for me),

Managing Territory

There are the usual empire management mechanics of managing resources, keeping the people happy (both the working classes and the wealthy classes) and researching technologies.  Religion also plays a part with determining how happy your subjects are, you can support your Empire's religion by building religious buildings which in turn produce religious agents (teachers) who can boost their (your) religion in territories they are placed in.

Trade also plays a significant part of the management as you can bring in significant amounts of money through trade.  There are a number of trade zones which you can send ships to to gather trade resources.  Prices of traded commodities change over time and merchant ships can be sunk by other factions and trade roots can be raided.  You can only trade with factions you have made a trade agreement with, and you can blockade ports.

You can also use agents to gather information about an enemy territory and to assassinate other characters.  Assassination is difficult, but possible.

Recommendation: If you have time to play a full campaign and the attention to detail to manage the resources and battles you will get a lot out of this game.  If you just want to play some battles there are some options for that too.  It's not a shooter, it's a thinker.

TOTAL WAR HITS A HOME RUN...
  ...With this iteration of total war, you get to spear head the ever expanding horizon of the new world. The campaign is heavily set in the Americans, with the colonisation of the new world. But will you take up the task of fighting the natives back or will you ally yourself with the new fraction ebbing its way across the country. Are your eyes set on the horizon in the west or the east?

 Set with the era of flint-lock rifles, the game play sets itself apart from its predecessors as new tactics must be deployed. No longer is the wars fought with swords and skill, give your me the line of sight and for goodness sake give them cover with nearby structures. Brutality is king in this explosive new game, blow your opponents up with your explosive cannon balls, tear through your opponents with ball-bearings. While they are distracted flank them with your cavalry and ram them in the rear.
 
 Just because your men do not need to be skilled to be enlisted, does not mean you can relax and breeze your way through it. The challenge of the command has never been greater, if you take your eye away from the enemy, you may find your rear exposed and the battle lost.

 This game is highly enjoyable and addictive so be warned, that once you buy this game you may want to cash in on those sick days you got lined up, grab your provisions and prepare to go out on the front lines for you are commander and chief.

I was able to nab this for a dollar fifty, it's not bad honestly, I like how you don't just build up a single spot, but instead focus on the surrounding area, like farms, harbors, etc.

Despite it's negative reception upon release, the updates and DLC content the game received over time made the game a pretty solid entry in the Total War Series. I find myself always coming back to it, as I am a huge fan of the time period, the mechanics, and the unique and interesting take on the era that the title brings with it. Overall, it's campaign map is one of the best, AI is a bit shoddy but can be fun, it's battles have their bright moments and I've had no fail in replaying it over and over again without boredom. 

The only downsides I see are there are occasional glitches, none completely game breaking or requiring you to start a fresh save. Most only need a quick restart of the app and you're good to go again. And if you ever have any problems with the units/variety/balance, DarthMod has helped immensely.

Font is unreadable.  I end up squinting and hunched forward guessing at what it says.  I only manage an hour or so at a time because it's so physically uncomfortable to play that way.  

I could find no way to fix it with the options/settings available in game.  After a bit of google searching, I found two options[both fan made];  One is a total overhaul that just happens to "fix" the font, and another that makes it larger but then it doesn't fit in the space anymore.  I also discovered that this is apparently a consistent issue throughout the TW series.  I was planning to get a few more of these games, but the back/headache I get from trying to read this mess is just not worth it.  


[Edit]:  I forgot to mention the cause of the font issue:  
It seems certain monitor size and resolution combinations aren't supported.  My 20 inch widescreen, 16:9 monitor is one of those.

Wonderful and simplistic empire development game with plenty of modifications available if you choose for greater customization.

Pros:
- Wonderfully thought out primary campaigns
- Seamless interaction in combat and regions
- Easy to gain the grasp of
- Unique "play it your way" philosophy
- Many historical empires and units from the eras

Cons:
- Game and engine is a tad dated, results in minor bugs over prolonged play periods
- Bugs can be slightly annoying and rarely force you to restart the game from scratch

Would highly recommend due to great value for price

A great game. I'd almost go as far as to say that the replay value is limitless. The tech tree is large and interesting, so are the maps. There's a great variety of nations to choose from and plenty of units for each one. Multiplayer is a fun experience as long as you take care to keep the right people out of your servers (IE: clan players and other spammers.) This is to NTW what the MG42 is to the MG3. It's older, and it has its flaws, but god damn it's good. ETW will also probably last you longer.

Edit: I'd also like to take this moment to call Valve Corp. out on its recent anti-consumer practice of subtly hiding negative reviews. Read here: https://steamcommunity.com/games/593110/announcements/detail/1808664240333155775

I have a good amount of hours on both this game and Total War Rome 2, (Neither Warhammers because that genre/playstyle isn't up my alley) and a little Napoleon, and this one is by far my favorite of them all. For 2 non personal reasons and 1 personal. The personal one is I am just a fan of the musket/line warfare this game allows. The 2 non personal are, 1. The scale of the game. No other total war game takes place in 3 different continents, you are able to not only take over all of Europe, but the Colonial Americas out until about Texas, and as far down south as Venezuela in South America. As well as being able to take over the middle east and all of India. Finally the mods for this game are some of my personal favorite of the Total War Saga. The reason I think the mods are best in this game ties back to the scale of the game. Have you ever wanted to play as the 13 colonies and try to revolt from Britain yourself? You can with a less than 10mb mod! Simple installs also! Have you ever wanted to be an Indian tribe that takes over the Americas and eventually take over Europe? You can! Overall just an amazing game that too me seems to never age.

This game lacks one major component that is critical for the success of any game—fun. This game is not enjoyable. Empire building is simply unlocking upgrades via clicking. Battles are tedious and visually wretched. From a distance, and not even that far of a distance, your units become atari-esque pixel people. The AI is possibly the worst battle and campaign AI I have ever encountered. As France, you can simultaneously conquer England and the Netherlands within 10 turns because of how idiotic and illogical the AI is. 

The naval battles are cool, and actually a huge high point of the game. It is just a shame that the game, all round, makes me feel like I would just rather be playing EU4 or Medieval 2 instead. 

All in all, I would give this a 5.4/10. It is playable, and the game is cool, but at its core it is an experience that will leave you with that strange after taste off-brand toothpaste gives you.

Empire Total War is amazing. Admittedly, it does feel a bit clunky and the bugs can become somewhat of a nuisance when they do occur. The AI in battle can be ridiculously laughable during certain moments. Also, in the campaign map their units will sometimes annoyingly create endless small stacks of armies, (I'm looking at you especially, you pesky Ottomans)  however, I feel that the positive outweighs the negative.

The scale of the campaign map is honestly one of my favorite things. You can create so many different scenarios. Nothing is more satisfying than starting off as a small nation in the brink of collapse by bigger and competing powers and building your way up to become an empire. Love the gunplay too. I would really love an Empire Total War 2 with improved AI/mechanics, more/new features, enhanced diplomacy, additional playable factions (though there are mods for that) and maybe even a larger, more detailed campaign map. I'm sure many others would love to see this happen. There's a lot of potential for it. 

Overall, get this.

I really like the game and its qualities. It has a very difficult to master trading and political mechanic as well as a multitude of other factors such as army costs, building upgrades and the dominating of other nations through war or vassal making.

However, I would like to see some updates and improvements for future players.

-allow all nations to be playable.

  the game allows you to choose just a select few major nations and wont let your play the underdogs, dont get me wrong, I love destroying the world as the french or British. But to play as Mysore, Persia, the colonies or even the pirates would be an outstanding improvement to the overall re-play value of the game and will leave people coming back for more every time they play.


- more trade resources and more resource buildings.

  I know there are a large quantity of resources already, but the addition of historically expensive commodities such as opium, slaves, wampum, and gunpowder would increase the gameplay value for those who enjoy the trade aspect of the game, and since you have an in-game technology called "abolition of slavery" you could use that as a way to end slave trading in the game and thus cause a little havoc in the trade between the nations. 


- the addition of Asia

honestly I am shocked you didn't add Asia in this game to begin with, the silk road was a very crucial part of European trade and commerce and the addition of china and other Asian nations would have added another theatre to the war-map, only adding yet more playability value, although I am quite happy India was included as it to was crucial for the European trading scene. But Asia would have been a major improvement for the game. Although seeing as how your making the "3 kingdoms" game we will finally be able to play in Asia ... well ... China at least.


other than these I have no issues with the game and Enjoy it very much so. I give this game a ;

3/5 for nation choices

4/5 for diplomacy and trading

5/5 for war simulation and strategy

5/5 for graphics

Been playing this game for a long time now, and while I agree that it's one of the "worst" games in the series, it's also one of the best. 

I think us veterans of the game have a love-hate relationship with it, because it's a pain in the butt at times, a huge one. But, it's also one of the most enjoyable games, the game introduced a lot of features never before seen in games like this. I think people who has given this game a chance know about the infamous glitches, for me the worst one is the game saving one where it causes the whole game to crash, however I always keep coming back to this game for more, even if I know that any turn could be my last. 

There is a simple way to lower the risk however, and it works, at least for me. You have an auto save of course but what I do is, not only keep the auto save but on turn one I save, and on turn two I save, making two save files plus the auto. And then, on each turn I overwrite those two save files. For example, on turn 3 I will overwrite 1, on turn 4 I will overwrite file 2, and so on. I will also sometimes make a third save file.

I also recommend playing this with darthmod, it adds a little bit more spice to the game, adding better effects for the muskets, cannons, rockets, etc and adding a little bit more realism, and it also unlocks nations to play such as the United States, which I am in the process of fulfilling manifest destiny and taking over the world.

Overall I recommend it, it's like the ugly duckling of the Total War games but I still love it, and I think other veterans of the game would say the same.

This installment in the Total War series brought in the worst engine the series had to offer. "Warscape" meant that tactics were no longer the primary focus on a battle, and stats were mostly what mattered. For instance, in a Medieval 2 battle you could beat an enemy army which greatly outmatched your own through moral shocks, Hammer & Anvil, whereas in Empire  and later installments this is much less doable. In fact, Cavalry charges -- and charges altogether -- are a complete mess, as Warscape seemingly annihilated any semblance of unit collision. 

Other points:
- A pathetic score
- Horrendous AI, even in your own units (constant re-shuffling of their formation, strange behaviour in sieges) 
- Disappointing Naval Battles (which CA still hasn't made enjoyable)
- The Warscape Engine was a direct attack on the modding community. Since the release of Empire, modders are still unable to edit campaign maps and many other important aspects of the game.

Total War: Empire Definitive Edition is recommended for strategy and rts gamers, especially for those who have a particular interest in the XVIII century warfare. 

I am aware that when this game was launched, many claimed that it was the worst Total War game ever. Its reputation was not redeemed thanks to Creative Assembly employing its warscape engine for Rome 2. This engine, in my humble opinion, was good for musket and line formations rather than melee combat. That doomed Rome 2, for what I understand. 

Naturally, I was hesitant to play Empire with many youtubers and reviewers bashing it. Nevertheless I finally decided to buy it considering the Definitive Edition. I played the short Swedish campaign. Coming from Rome 1, my favorite game, I was expecting a different game, naturally, and I liked it. 

You get to play not only in Europe, but in the New World and India and there are various factions to choose from.

Regions are no longer represented only by a big city and a port, like in Rome 1. There is the region capital, mines, farms, towns and ports which will grow and evolve according to the technology tree the player selects. For instance, there are developments that favor happiness among the nobility and unrest in the lower classes; or buildings that favor a change of government from monarchy to republic. 

You can choose to play a grand campaign choosing among the various factions, paly the American Independence, a short campaign, the Warpath campaign (I have not played it yet), or custom battles. 

The gameplay is divided in classic Total War format: strategy layer in the world map, and battles in the tactical map. In the world map you develop your cities, towns and resources; build and manage armies. What happens in the world map may have important effects in the tactical portion and vice versa. You can choose to fight battles in the world map with auto resolve, or command your armies directly, both on land and sea. 

Two important difference in managing your armies take place. First, unlike Rome 1, generals are no longer members of the family, but rather are promoted among the ranks of the army. Secondly, when an army suffers casualties, you can merge units like before, but also you can replenish them without having to return to a city. Replenishment takes turns to be fully effective, but help you in continuing your war campaign. Furthermore, when you have a general in your army, he can recruit soldiers even if he is far away from any city, having to wait them to be recruited in the various cities, and marching to meet the army where the general is located.

The AI: this is one of the weak aspects of the game, especially when diplomacy comes to play. Sometimes you want to offer a trade agreement and the AI has an outrageous counter offer, for example, demanding one of your regions even if the AI faction is in the other side of the world with now power to take it. 

In battles, the limitations of the warscape engine show when melee attacks take place. Sieges are worse than in Rome 1 and I clearly can understand why so many people were disappointed. However, most of the time I found myself enjoying the two layers of the game: world strategy, tactical battles. So far, I have played only with Sweden, and found out that fighting the Russians was easy, but dealing with the Prussians was much harder. 

All in all, I recommend the game. The setting, the world map, the various factions plus the ones from the DLC included now in the one package Definitive Edition, offers hours of enjoyment. And let’s face it, the AI has never been the strength of CA, and while in Empire is especially less competent than in previous titles, the overall experience is positive. However, if you are die hard gamer who expects realistic AI, perhaps is better to stay away.

One of (if not my top) favourite TW titles. Empire is a gorgeously detailed, complex game which brings to life a fascinating period of history. The battles (land and sea) look fantastic, with long lines of musket smoke drifting up from your troops/ships. Tech trees are filled with detail, if slightly long winded, and the diplomacy system is much improved from Medieval II (allies will no longer randomly turn on you...). 
Most of all, let me recommend the Darthmod for this game. It fixes the couple of issues the vanilla game had, such as a lack of unit diversity for some nations, and turns artillery into the deadly tool it actually was. The basegame AI isn't too bad, but with the Darthmod it will actually attempt complex tactics like flanking and concentrating artillery to create weak spots. 
My only remaining criticism is that siege battles in forts are just *awful*. I've read that this is essentially down to pathfinding issues with the AI creating massive lag in the processing. CA promised to fix it (spoiler alert: they didn't). 

Good thing the pitched battles/battles in cities without forts are far more fun anyway.

I don't have as many hours as some people do, especially the hardcore TW fanbase; but, I play games just to play them and have fun so I might have a different perspective on this. I loved commanding nation's armies from the Napoleonic Era because the awesome navies that are included and large battles that are in that part of history. The game really shows both of those with beautiful graphics and allows you to customize (in skirmish) the size and moving parts in the battles. I think the ship to ship combat is pretty good (it's a bit tricky to make fun) and very beautiful with many different settings (like a twilight map with the sun shimmering off the water) and all the nations have some different variants of ships. When fighting on land the units have lots of individual soldiers and the cap for how many units you can have is high, and moddable to have no capacity either. I really recommend the game, which is definitely worth 25$. The definitive edition comes with some DLC as well within the same pricetag.

My opinion of this game is the same as it was nearly 10 years ago, when this game first game out: Broken and ugly.

Empire Total War remains one of the most disappointing Total War games I have ever played. Despite being the largest (in land mass) game of the Franchise, it remains to be an empty game. Europe is broken up into a handful of regions, with places like France and Spain being 1 region each as oppose to being multiple, with nothing really unique in terms of map design, as you can easily conquer France as Britain within 1-2 turns from a fresh new campaign.

The units are ugly and are all just copy and pastes. The unit roster in this game is very dull and predictable, with Line Infantry making up the backbone of any army (with Guards and other elite units late-game) making the battles very samey after several battles, with the terrible AI making it even worse and not a challenge, even if it is on the highest difficulty. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if it was at least fun to watch. As aforementioned, the units of most of the factions are copy and pastes, with a slightly different colour to their uniforms, but that is really it. If you look at actual Uniforms from this period, you would see they were as diverse as their colour-schemes. The only 'uniqueness' are the DLC added unit packs.

A.I is terrible, like most CA games. Countries will randomly declare war on you for no reason, make outragous demands in order to get trade (including asking for tech, money and a region from you for a trade agreement, regardless if theyre a major power or not). Anyone that plays this game will know that a country like Britain, will ask for a shitty region from you in exchange for Scotland or a Caribbean region, you obviously reject it only for them to later send a fleet with an Army in it in order to take it; declaring war at the last minute.

Overall, this is a disaster of a game. If it wasn't for the fact its one of the few games set in this period, this game would be a distant memory.

Total War: EMPIRE is a game developed by The Creative Assembly and published by SEGA and forms part of the Total War series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

Total War: EMPIRE overall, however, is a fun game to play, yet sometimes flawed, but is a great grand strategy game to play in short bursts!

The most photogenic and ambitious grand strategy game I've ever played. 
There's so much to like I'll just mention the cons:
The ai is very selfish and it shows in the auto resolve battle option. This is good for me because I love to play almost every battle, but I can imagine that not everybody will feel the same.
The ai again, is not very good at operating on the global scale (with the exception of Britain, Spain and sometimes Maratha India)
The learning curve. There's many aspects of this game you will be able to improve upon besides the military option and you'll likely learn something new in every campaign you play.

Although it has it's flaws, Empire: Total War, in my opinion, is the best Total War game ever made. It's historical accuracy in Campaign play is so accurate it can actually teach you a lot of history (especially if you read the in-game descriptions). 

The content of the game is really diverse. The weaknesses and strengths of each individual faction in the game is set realistically & historically accurate. The unique units factions possess are also great & historically accurate (The British having the Blackwatch Elite Infantry, The Maratha with the Elephants, The Ottomans with the 64-iber Artillery and the fearsome Organ Gun). I also really like the fact that you can create your own alternate timeline/history via the use of revolutions and other new features intoduced that did not exist in previous Total War games. 

Although minor, some flaws of this game are that the Campaign AI is sometimes stubborn af (they won't accept deals no matter what you offer them), Cavalry is very weak and have almost no effect in battles, and some minor limiting things, such as not being able to liberate a nation or a region without causing an intentional rebellion in the region, which takes 3 turns to onset. However if you play this game with DarthMod installed, it will basically make the game flawless. 

This game was also the first Total War game to have a fully incorporated Naval Battle System which was a huge advance in the Total War series. If you are a dedicated Total War fan like me and if you like historical accuracy in games, then this game is a must have.
Empire: Total War is still fun to play years after its release and i reccommend buying the collection when it is on sale.

This was the first game that brought me to Steam when I bought the hardcopy back in, whenever it was released (dif. account).

I think that, over the years, the main thing that always bugged me was the unit sprite draw distance; the distance at which units on the map degraded in graphical quality to preserve rendering speed. Apart from that, the game has to be played at maximum difficulty to present any challange, and powerful countries such as England and France sometimes invade you even though historically it wouldn't make sense. 

Then there is the Ottoman Empire which takes huge chunks of time during the turn-switch, because it creates a million single-stack armies which all have to be moved aimlessly and whatnot - best to defeat the ottomans or weaken them early-on to save 3 minutes per turn. 

I have had a hate-love relationship with this game as I love the time period and the potential, but the poor execution of the game itself is a big turn-off.

10/10, The Best Total War game out there. Hopefully they make a sequel with new nation players.

[h1] Total War: EMPIRE [/h1]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

This is a strategy game similar to Civilization. The difference is in the gameplay combat where for land battles (vs sea battles) you deploy your armies and engage the enemy. This is usually rather overwhelming for me because there is a lot of action happening on the screen at the same time and it is hard for me to keep track of all of my units. There are two aspects to gameplay: nation building and combat.

Either nation building or combat can be automated. With nation building you can have the computer automatically manage your tax and construction policy if you would rather focus on combat. And you can automatically resolve any combat option.

[h1] Story / Engagement [/h1]

Not much of a story. Just try to build your empire at the expense of your enemies (and allies) by leveraging resource management, trade, diplomacy, and military might. Diplomacy can be frustrating as, seemingly, fair deals are often rejected by the computer controlled nations. 

[h1] Compatible with Linux [/h1]

Yes, no problems. 

[h1] Time Spent on Game [/h1]

8.6 Hours

I am a staunch Strategy/CIty Builder games fan. Always have been starting from the days of Populous: The Beginning, Caesar III, Age of Empires II and other classics. I love every kind of strategy : RTS, Turn Based and what not. Total War in that regard has been a constant companion over the years. I started playing Total War: Rome when I was in highschool and spent so many hours on it and I learned so much because it increased my already manic levels of love for history. Then came Medieval II, Empire and more. All of them have been amazing. There are tons of mods and wonderful player made content that keeps these games fresh and fun even now.

Though I had one regret - I love beautiful graphics and these games which once seemed amazing looking have started looking dull after seeing better graphics quality. So you can imagine how happy I was when I suddenly got a mail stating that all my Total War games were being updated to modern graphics for free! What a gift! Brilliant move CA! 

All the gripes we had about the DLC's just vanished. Empire is one of the classics even among the stellar Total War series due to it's unique map, time period. mechanics and troops. It's amazingly fun to say the least. Now with updated graphics, it's going to take up all my free time :) 

For those who have never played these TW games, I recommend you to do so. They're worth everything you pay for and more. Especially if you pick them up during the Summer Sale or Publisher sale. You get massively steep discounts for the entire franchise excluding the latest Warhammer installment. Hoping to see more players online! Let's have fun!

Though, I've generally moved on to Empire's newer brethren, namely the wonderful Total Warhammer games, Empire will always hold a special place in my heart.

Few games have approached the scope and breadth of Empire's sometimes shaky reach.  CA had ambitious goals for Empire, and while it's arguable if they completely succeeded - there is not a more accessible Horse and Musket/Age of Colonialism battle-simulator out there and I eagerly await Empire 2.

Multi-continental empires, theaters of operations, trade zones and some of the best, most memorable naval-combat in the entire series.  There's a lot to love in TW: Empire, and now the Definitive Edition brings it all together.

***

Yes, this game is a bit dated now, but if you add the DarthMod some of the battles can get truly epic and I've no doubt that a modern PC should be able to easily handle even the largest unit-settings.  

I've spent many...many hours in this game, and every empire plays quite differently, even though you're basically  just dealing with different flavors of "dudes w/ muskets".  

Strong Recommendation - even today.  Dear CA: *please* consider an Empire 2 at some point.

Game Summary:
Empire: Total War is set in the 18th century, a turbulent era and a period alive with global conflict, revolutionary fervour and technological advances. The game features themes such as the Industrial Revolution, America's struggle for independence, the race to control Eastern trade routes and the globalisation of war on land and sea. Empire: Total War saw the debut of 3D naval combat within the Total War franchise. Players intuitively command vast fleets or single ships upon seascapes rich with extraordinary water and weather effects that play a huge role in your eventual glorious success or ignominious defeat. After pummelling your enemy with cannon fire, close in to grapple their ship and prepare to board taking control your men as they fight hand to hand on the decks. Empire: Total War also saw further enhancements to the Total War series signature 3D battles and turn based campaign map. Real time battles pose new challenges with the addition of cannon and musket, challenging players to master new formations and tactics as a result of the increasing role of gunpowder within warfare. And the Campaign Map – for many the heart of Total War – saw new improved systems for Trade, Diplomacy and Espionage with agents, a refined and streamlined UI, improved Advisors and extended scope taking in the riches of India, the turbulence of Europe and the untapped potential of North America.

This game was a very awkward entry in the series in hindsight as it was shoulder to shoulder with the Napoleon entry also by the same developers. Usually CA try to avoid such direct competition with their own work, rotating themes and eras as they go so the next time they hit the same or similar era some time has passed (see the gap between M:TW 1&2, Shogun 1&2, Rome 1&2, etc.). Sadly this was not one of their better entries and I just can't enjoy it much despite my appreciation for the era and the kind of tactics used and what it allows for in gaming. If you want Napolenic or Colonial era strategy fun focused around musket formations and the shot/cavalry/cannon concept then you should look elsewhere. It is thankfully a well covered era by many developers, especially if you also include the earlier "pike and shot" era of warfare. If you just want any Total War style game then there are many others to choose from too and modding options really should be taken into account and explored.

A great, magnificent, yet flawed game. I have hundreds of hours into this game on another steam account and there is good reason for it. Not since has CA made a game with such scope, such grandiosity. You can literally conquer almost the entire world. The possibilities are endless. 

Want Russia to control the Bahamas and fight pirates in the Caribbean? Check. Want to see endless hordes of Native American soldiers crash against Prussian cannon batteries in Georgia? Check. Want to cause political unrest in your enemies homelands by giving them enlightenment technologies in the late game for no seemingly good reason? Check. Want to watch the utter awesomeness of the "fire by rank" tech while your line infantry mow down helpless Firelock Armed Populace defending Berlin? Check. Want to watch your best and greatest Heavy First Rate ship completely obliterate enemy sloops and then rage when it catches on fire and blows up? Check. There are many, many more examples. 

I am prepared to talk about the not so good aspects of the game. Mainly, it seems that CA basically abandoned this game after not too long. There are a great deal of bugs and ridiculous AI moves that will have you shaking your head. In fact the AI is probably the worst part of the game. Instead of being competent, the AI has extreme buffs on higher difficulties which feels cheap at times. That said, there are many ways to exploit the AI and basically win every single battle. There are also a number of things missing in the game, parts of the game that need modding or tweaking but are lacking.

Also you can basically forget about diplomacy. Allies will constantly betray you for no reason, other factions will almost NEVER accept the most reasonable terms in diplomacy unless it is massively in their favor. Once you declare war on a faction or are declared upon, it is almost always a fight to the death, winner takes all, no place for peace. Diplomacy has a very small place in this game, especially on higher difficulties.

As I said it seems CA basically abandoned this game and moved on to Napoleon TW immediately. For example, you cannot repair city fortifications. Remember that one time Poland attacked Berlin, made a hole in the wall with a cannon that one time? Hope you like that massive opening in your fortifications, because there is no way to repair it. Only way to do so would be to tear it completely down and build an entirely new fort. The list goes on. That said, I have probably played this game more than any other game ever and it is surely one of the best for its vision, historical atmosphere, and just altogether awesome gameplay experiences.

Positives:

1. Empire Total War brings a militarily interesting period of history and brings it to you in a pleasing manner that is at times intense and can keep you on the edge of your seat. This RTS/ Turn Based Grand Strategy offers an interesting experience by pushing many new concepts in the Total War Franchise up to this games release date. 

2. The warfare can be at times quite riveting and draw you into the game and leave you on the edge of your seat at some moments. Though this does happen uncommonly, there is something extremely exciting when your army become engaged with a force of either equal or larger size and if they quality of those troops are just as strong as yours. Those moments really suck you into the game and can leave you with moments of tense excitement as you know a single wrong move in those instances can lead to defeat. Then there is the amazing satisfaction of seeing a risky strategy lead to complete and overwhelming sucess that leaves you extremely satisfied. The scale of the combat is awe inspiring too, this is due to the amount of soldiers that exist on the field at anyone time. Typically most RTS see no more then 250 units (this is still even extremely high and unusual). Total War throws that away with their games and puts over 1000 men on the field. This size and scope is always amazing to see and always leaves me awestruck. Especially in Empire when you see long lines of Line infantry moving into position to slug it out with an opposing regiment. Artillery is amazing to watch in this game as well as you watch sections of regiments get blown away leaving holes in the enemy's regiment. 

3. Naval Combat was introduced as a commandable battle rather then AI in previous Total War titles. I do find this combat event to be at times fun and impressive to watch. 

4. Large campaign map that covers 3 continents with trade and colonies becoming more important then previous titles. If you are playing as the Netherlands, and your main trading port is blockaded, your economy practically disappears. Leads to more strategy with the new emphasis on trade. 

5. Some of the nations start out with extremely fun and interesting scenarios ot play. Example: Prussia being forced to blitz early on to unify it's land and fight multiple enemies from the beginning. Dutch starting with few territories and only one European territory. 

Negatives:

1. The combat is slow. Though I said there were times it deserved praise, the combat for the most part is slow and repetitive. Either you can completely overwhelm an enemy or they completely overwhelm you. Even then, the scope of the tactical maps is too large. To set up an attack properly, it can sometimes take up to 15-20 minutes. Especially in a game where position is key to sucess, this is a tedious and annoying process. Then the AI doesn't always pick quality units. So even if you see that the battle is obviously already a no brainer, that doesn't mean the auto resolve will agree and then you are stuck fighting an annoying fight that seems like a chore. Cavalry is still used in Empire, but it's relevance compared to previous titles has decreased significantly. Infantry is king in this game. This lack of usefullness by calvary makes the battles that much longer. 

2. While Naval Combat is impressive at times to watch, I do belive it is just as slow at times. Then the AI doesn't place as much emphasis on naval battles, so most battles are never using the maximum potential of naval units available. This leaves this awesome feature feeling underwhelming. 

3. The Grand Strategy aspect feels slow and sluggish. The movement ranges can feel slow. I think Mid II handled this well by making the cities closer together. This time the cities are more distant which leaves the player having to spend more time moving units then actually fighting. 

4. There are way too many rebellions. Every time you take a city, you can expect at least 2 or 3 rebellions. This lengthens the game time unecessarily against rebel armies that are often extremely underwhelming and never too big of a threat unless you took a city with a small force. These feel more like a chore then actually productive to the game. 

5. The campaign map is huge, but it would be amazing to expand the map even more. Empire leaves large strethces of land blank of cities or doesn't even count them as territory. France is a huge chunk of territory and could be broken up even more, instead it's one giant region. Spain is the same way and those both could have been split up more. 

6. The battles could have been even more overwhelming. The little puffs of smoke could be more epic and weapons could sound like weapons instead of fireworks. The battles are awesome to watch, but they could have been even more so with a few tweaks.

Overall:

I enjoyed Empire. I put plenty of hours into it. I do believe that this game is underwhelming though in the grand scheme of things. Empire had far more potential then the final product then was given to the player community. I still feel like it is an experience worth having and would recommend it. But that would be a recommendation that would require alot of explanation behind it as well.

Fantastic infantry/cavalry/artillery/naval programming. I enjoyed playing the grand campaign multiple times, and ended up wishing it encompassed more of the world and a longer timeframe than 1700 - 1800. Custom battles are fun on both land and sea, but sadly the battle AI appears quite basic, either you can run rings around them, or they relentlessly attack.

The campaign AI has issues too, as they simply refuse any deal you try to make; before eventually declaring war for no reason. The game itself is plagued by countless glitches and oversights left in. It's heartbreaking because so many look fixable, as if SEGA forced Creative Assembly to make Napoleon: Total War rather than fix Empire.

The worst issue seems to be a memory leak which reduces the frame rate massively, and the dreaded fort lag. Empire is a flawed game, but that doesn't stop it from being playable, and considering that Imperial Glory was the only competition (and had less scope), then Empire owns a big reputation for what it offers.

The campaign and battle HUDs are so similar that their outline eventually got burned into my monitor, and I don't regret playing it at all, I just wish it was given the polish it clearly deserves. The short-lived RedShell debacle did nothing to help the reputation of the game.

People say that this is one of the worst Total War games.  Having played the others (including Shogun 2), I have to disagree.  I have enjoyed this a lot and don't see how this game could be considered "bad".  Simply the mere size of this game makes it so exciting.  Having an empire stretching across Europe, North America, Asia, and North Africa is really satisfying and really pushes your total war managing skills (it is really hard).  The troops and the fighting are fun though I have to admit, Napoleon and Fall of the Samurai probably has better designed gunfights.

Well, I've had this game for a while now and I've had fun times and very annoying times. I would love to give this games a thumbs up, but when I look back at how many times I've been hitting my computer and screaming when the screen goes completely black on my SECOND custom battle. Or when the second after I exit a battle in a campaign the games starts to fuck itself and the flags glitch and the UI honestly just breaks and shoots itself. Okay, so the battles CAN be fun but there are so many freakin' flaws! If you look at a lot of the reviews for this game, they'll say that the AI is as thick as a bucket of shit, but my god is the AI stupid! They do stupid things like charging in their GENERAL, or just walking up to you and getting ripped apart by Light Foot or Skirmishers. And trust me, there's a lot more where that came from. Your units require complete and utter attention, because none of them have any regard for friendly fire and will happily shoot through your own units if placed behind! There's a lot more but I don't have enough space to list that. The soldiers in units have no personality, no individuality at all. All of the animations are completely in sync as if they're freakin' robots. Yet they don't march in sync like they should? What? In the vanilla game all of the Line Infantry units for each country are re-colours of the other. Very well done CA. Then, there's the sea battles. Okay, so the ship skins are rubbish, the 'marine' skins are rubbish, the affect that a broadside actually has is minute, the cannons (and the muskets for that matter) make a small puff of smoke and the AI is still as dumb as ever. Now, the Campaign. The Campaign is one of the largest areas of ETW that show how disgustingly unreliable the game is. I've found that: If you hover over certain parts of the map you'll get a framerate of 0.00000001, the diplomacy is utter bollocks, I've had the Ottoman Empire asking me for Scotland, the 'portraits' of Kings/Queens/Gentlemen etc are hilarious and the game will eventually just shoot itself. So yeah, that's all I could be bothered to mention in this review. Honestly, just get mods and then it'll be a bit more fun. But even thten there are internal problems that no mods can fix. Oh well, just get NTW.

We have no idea what data Redshell really pulls from our machines because it's closed source so trust has completely gone out the window. It's been great CA but it's time to let go of Total War, a series that frankly has gotten less challenging and engaging (I assume because they want their game to be more mainstream, ie more money).

I purchased Empire TW with the hopes of a great game as I enjoy similar strategy games like Europa Universalis and Civilization. I was able to play for a few hours, but around hour 4 the game began to crash. First it would crash mid-game, and has gotten to the point that I can't get past the main menu without the game crashing while loading. I have contacted Feral Interactive and Steam requesting support, but nothing has been resolved. Steam has also denyed my request for a refund.
While not aesthetically pleasing, the game was entertaining while it lasted. Unfortunately, due to its consistant crashing on my Mac I can not recommend this game.

For starters, I'm a HUGE total war fan. Love the games and have really liked the amount of history they've covered over the years. One of the unique things that I've always enjoyed about TW is that they've always got some authentic units and battle mechanics. Now, specifically in regards to "Empire" not TW as a whole. Empire is one of my favorite takes. When I originally started, I was absolutely overwhelmed with all of the in's-and-out's of the mangement portion of the game. Thankfully, they had an option to let that sort itself out. This feature helps me stay focused more on the conquest and less on the economics. Additionally, they have a cool take on Naval warfare. However, there is one thing I'll complain about. It's with the auto-resolve feature. 
When the game indicates that you're opponents army and yours is "close" in strength before entering into a battle, DO NOT AUTORESOLVE IT. Unless there is some type of landslide margin between the two armies, you're almost always going to lose an absolutely unneccessary amount of units. My advice, just hate it, and fight the battle. I've found that even when I'm outmatched, not only do I win, but I lose much fewer units. Idk, it's a small thing really--especially since I jump into TW for it's epic battles anyway! 
That's my only complaint. Like at all. This game is freakin awesome. Buy it--if you like TW, you'll probably like this. If you like CIV, you'll probably like this. If you like Europa Uni. you'll like this. Although, personally, I'd just get it when it's on sale! Thier bundles are usually pretty sweet.

Empire is looked down upon by the older fans due to a bad release but tis is a fun total war game dont get me wrong though as it has its faults. Campaign: It is large, very large, as it has 3 continets to cover which makes it difficult to mange when you arwe begining but certain factions like: Prussia and Austria dont worry about this as they are only european based factions. Larger nations such as the French and British are coverng all three continets, but trouble arises early as you have to mange alot and you are forced to maintain one continet at a time. Road to Idepedentance campaign is fun following the first colony at Jamestown to a new nation the United Sates of America. Battles: These are like Napoleon but are smaller and unit variety between factions is minimal especially when you paly in the early time period battles bt in the late each faction presents their own units but all of them have a few units in common. Anval battles where introduced in this game and they are fun to have large ship battle in line firing one at a time but this was the first game with is so I'll go easy on it. What I Dislike: one on one unit battles where a single character will attack a single man and it will be more "cinimeatic" but this kills immersion. DLC I didslike the unit pack but it isnt as bad as Rome 2 or Attila . Otherwise the game would be a 7-8/10
I love the naval aspects of Empire Total War. The people who put this game together have done really well combining land and sea power into a great "Total War' experience.
The Roblox version is better tbh. Still a good game though

Total War has become so expansive with so many entries that I'm not going to waste time recapping what it is or how it's differnt than other strategy games, rather I'll just compare it to other Total War entries.  If you are Total War veteran, skip to the final conclusion at the end.

  On a scale of good to bad, this game falls pretty solidly in the middle of the Total War franchise.  It's by no means the masterpiece that the first Rome game was, but Empire offers such an expansive and all encompassing world that it manages to stand out from other titles in the series.

 Empire is all about Width over depth.  There isn't anything particularly deep and the boundaries are met rather quickly, but on the whole that feels okay because rather than just focusing on some smaller world map like the Medditerranian or Japan, you have almost the entire world at your finger tips.

 A lot of changes while somewhat shallow, are at least interesting additions such as the way your territories build and max out with hotspots.  

  For someone who is a fan of the series, this is a solid game to check out and worth your time.  If you are new, it's a fine game but there are better Total War games to start with.

6/10

I usually love historical strategy games, especially those covering the 18th Century. Unfortunately, I am unable to love this one; I found it too exasperating to be fun. So may aspects of it are so clunky, badly designed and annoying, that I ended up abandoning it in disgust. It might have helped if they had bothered to give us a  tutorial for the main, turn-based part of the game. But no, you'll have to buy 'Napoleon: Total War' if you want that essential feature, but even there, it is inadequate.

I wasted so many hours baffling over this game, trying to figure things out, like why ship's captains keeps saying, sarcastically: "This is a ship, Sir; it cannot sail on land!", when I was not trying to sail it on land! And how to get armies and/or agents into ships and how to disembark them, without them disappearing. There is no simple drag and drop for this, instead they have a system that's more cryptic than a Rubic's cube. 

Getting your trade ships to do any trading is also as baffling as a jigsaw puzzle with misfitting pieces. Almost every time you try to put your ship on a trading node (if you are lucky enough to find one), another ship instantly appears and blocks you, as soon as you click on the node. This is accompanied by the message: "Another character is blocking your path". (Oh, so I'm a "character", am I?) It's all the crap like this that drove me to cut my losses and bin this time-wasting tangle-fest. When people pay good money for a game, they want to have fun, for heaven's sake; not spend hours vexing over how to perform simple operations.

The game's interface is not particularly attractive, and there is an intolerable wait between turns while we are made to sit through a tedious, unnecessarily long-winded graphic representation of what the rest of the world is doing for its turns, represented by characters strutting around the map, doing God knows what, and ships that sail a few miles and then often mysteriously vanish.
 
The game also crashes too often, and there is no option to load earlier saves. So, if the game's screwed-up mechanics trips you up disastrously when you are well into the campaign, tough luck, buddy, you either keep playing, or start the campaign again from scratch!

Lastly, I don't think the devs had a clue who they were targeting when they designed this game. On the one hand, the educational pop-up windows seem suited to grown-up History students, while on the other hand, the British military officers all talk like cringeworthy charicatures, as though they are trying to amuse six-year-olds. Stuff like that puts short thrift to any hope of game immersion.

Had I paid the full and extortionate price for this game, I would have been truly peeved. As it is, I'll regard it as a learning experience - i.e. to be wary of ever buying another game from this studio.

The designers would have done themselves a big favour if they had looked at and considered the merits of an older game called  'Imperial Glory'. That game was a real pleasure, compared to this cack-handed clunker - and a tiny fraction of the price, too.

Please give my review a 'thumbs up' if you consider it helpful. Many thanks.

First off, let me start by saying that this was the first game i played in the total war series and even though it is definitely not their most popular or their best game, it is still more than worth spending your time playing and is a forgiving game for beginners in the series. while other TW games like medieval 2 and Napoleon tend to be less than forgiving. It's a good place to begin from and the battles are fun and immersive as usual with technological advancements through the ages giving you a greater arsenal and varied strategies to play around with.The naval battles alsoo provide an interesting combat expirience to break any monotony you may endure during a campaign.
While it may not be the pinnacle of TW games it certainly is worth a shot and you might just like it quite a bit. Think of it as a filler between meals, a kind of tasty snack thats filling and enjoyable would be one way to describe the game.
If you have any doubts then i would suggest picking it up in a sale, that way you wont be too dissapointed even if you dont like it.

... No.

I'm truly sorry, for I would love to recommend this game - as far as I know the only one with polish Winged Hussars in it, with the ability to send them to beat the crap out of Americas and India. Nice historical setup, nice history background for almost anything, if you care to read all the tiny texts. Nice battle graphics, dudes in units are slightly different from each other...

But.
There is a saying, "Anything before 'but' doesn't count".

But.

- The AI is a moron. 
    * Pike squares with their back to the wall, on which there is significant musket and arty covering fire? Charge it with cav. 1 unit at time, of course. And maaany more idiotic behaviors I could make a small book of.
    * Yeah, arty on the wall. Try getting your troops to man it. Works +/- nice with units around 60-man size, with bigger? Nope. They will keep staggering going to the cannons and away. Inch towards cannons, inch away, forever. Never getting to man them, or do anything as complex as properly line up at top of the wall to fire off it. Maybe like 10 men out of 120 will fire. But! Mostly only after you specifically tell them to. They will first rotate 1 man in rank, stand idly, then aim->fire. After like 10s from enemy getting in range. This is enough time for the enemy to get past the range, many times.
     * Sieges in general. Tell the units to get out of the fort clicking a bit past one gate you want them to get out through. Think they will use that one? Only if you're lucky. But then, if they try to use the right one, it won't open for them. They will all get clumped in the passage by the gate. After quite a bit of clicking, you will get them unstuck, but.. Almost never all of them. 5-10 chars from a unit can get like perma-stuck in there, just on the corner of a fkin gate.
     * Fire by rank? Doesn't apply to shooting at charging cavalry, or any units passing left-to-right in front of your shooters. Because reasons.

- Bugs.
     * Build a church or whatever it's called, get no religious agent for 77 turns. Build another, get none either. Raze and rebuild, still nothing. M-hm.
     * Units that are supposed to be sneaking while not running often just don't sneak for no apparent reason.
     * I hover my mouse over Danemark's capital. FPS drops to 0.5 (my computer handles Witcher 3 on max details easy). Ofc you can't get there even though there are these magical golden arrows.
     * Game crashes occasionally, because reasons. Even in middle of a hour-long siege exhaustion battle.
     * No turning battle camera left with mouse drag. Turning right is ok... Oh wait, no, it no longer works too. Funny, it just worked a sec ago.
     * Even if you sincerely FK all the above, because you want your winged hussars to conquer America too badly. Even if you don't play sieges, just fatigue the cities. Resign from even looking at Danemark or converting the populace. Even if you settle for everything above, get to almost beat two big empires, start thinking about building up a fleet to claim New World... Just when you get a grasp of it all... Then ALL your saves get corrupt. Campaign fkin over. This was my trigger to write this review. I am quite bloody upset.

- My personal feelings
     * Tech tree is a joke.
     * There are more unit types in AoE 2. Even counting all faction specials as 1.
     * The camera is clunky.
     * Maaany UI elements are missing. Like view all towns which have development available or need repairs, or show points where your trade routes are being raided. Try doing it yourselves when you get bigger, I dare you.
     * Cav is a joke. They lose to everything. No point in making more than 2 cav units per army, just for 'flanked' morale debuff and chasing down stuff in a win-more situation. I sure hoped Winged Hussars will be better than this, but never got to play them...
     * Obstacles on battle map are clunky and unintuitive to get advantage of.
     * Clunky cam + very varying terrain height = trying to make your cannons/shooters fire only to see they hit terrain/don't fire at all. Then zoom in, narrow your eyes, examine, examine, exaaamine... Oh damn, there IS a small uphill here, so my guys don't have a clear shot. Fk.
     * Mighty <> Spectacular <> Terrifying... Which one is bloody higher? Mby add Ludicrous, too.
     * What does prestige stand for? Actual army size or battles won or friggin what does this tell me?
     * I feel spammed by all the notifications already, why the sudden fk do the barbary states have to sue for peace every turn?



Overall... I wish it worked. But even with my enthusiastic attitude towards the very idea of this game... I can't recommend it. It's not worth your time and cash. You will find only frustration here.

Cheers,

B.

Personally I love the idea of three 'theatres of war'. With ships taking months to reach places like the Americas and India it's not 'realistic to have them on one combined map like every other Total War game. This makes for a fantastic battle of the sea's. Sure you can own America or India - or both - but if your enemies decide to raid your trade routes out in Brazil, The Ivory Coast - wherever they may be - then you're drawn into battle - your loss is their gain... Making supply raids a fantastic way to earn income.

Like I said this is something which is has been drastically missing from recent Total War games and I've loved this aspect of it.

On a downside the AI is pretty terrible in battle, and the automatic battle is massively broken - to the point of being almost game-breaking. I've had 18 stack armies lose to 10 stack armies of the EXACT same level of units. If I play those battles out I'll absolutely destroy the computer losing probably 10% of my men in comparison to 50-60% losses if I actually win an auto-battle. As it's expensive to replenish your armies this changes your whole economic strategy, meaning you pretty much have to play each battle out yourself.

All in all it's a solid Total War game and I highly recommend all fans of the series try it out!

Empire Total War is good for one thing - The first game to have naval battles included. It is rather fun, I must admit. But this "fun" does not counter all the bad that I have encountered in the many hours of playing..  
The AI is as much as crap as that of a game from 300 BC, the voice acting is very lazy, Total War really didn't mean on spending much to make this game great. The game has a poor DLC policy, just like any other Total War game encountered so far and even worse is the lag that sometimes appears when for example selecting an Army or Navy in the middle of the ocean sea, or when there's many more armies fielded in the same theatre. The game is a wonderful initiative and the fact that there's so much territory is lovely. The gameplay isn't that bad either, but my opinion about this game is easy and cheaply made, when CA had even lazier developers walking around their office.

Still my most played TW with almost 400 hours. 
I know a lot of people cite other titles for doing this or that better but for me ETW was the perfect balance between grand strategy and RTS. Theres something special about expanding your colonies, managing youre homeland, the naval warfare and trade.
and yes, there are some tradeoffs, fort battles are a pain in the Ass with the AI going complete bonkers and making my CPU almost overheat but outside of that its perfect. 
i love the warhammer setting but the global map there just didnt appeal to me. the battles were, without a doubt better but at the end of the day empire got the balance right.
thats also why i didnt really like napoleon, to me it focused more on the RTS than the grand strategy element, fighting off pirates in the carribean and slowly making my way up south america with the netherlands always brings back fond memories of conquest.

This game is a great Grand Strategy RTS, though it does have its limitations. While fun on the macro level, once you get in to battles you should be careful on what units are involved and how many will be fighting.

For instance, I attacked paris and, facing the multiple armies that were close enough to aid the occupying force, I was facing about 3000 soldiers with around 1500 have my own, meaning ther were about 2000. This, plus siting back and shelling the fort with fire rounds, made the lag so horrible that what should have been a 30 minute battle took 2 and a half hours.

That said, on the whole the game is fun, just expect a good amount of lag when you get near "end game" scales of activity, mostly in battle but on overworld map too at times.
