Runs well under Ubuntu 17.10 (CPU AMD Ryzen 1600, 8GB RAM, GPU AMD RX560 with amdgpu driver). Weird unreadable font at start, solution: open text config file ~/.local/share/feral-interactive/Empire/preferences & change UsePBOSurfaces from 1 to 0

After heavy thinking and a bit of research, along with recommendations from others... it should be noted that I DO recommend the Total War series.

I DO NOT recommend this Total war game though.

This just so happens to be my first Total War game. I enjoyed the style of the campaign and how big the battles can be...but I was heavily let down by the unit design/how they respond in battle/useless ship battles/a number of other things listed below.

+ The game does take strategy to a high degree, being able to win against a force of 1000 troops with only a force of 200 troops of your own, used in the right ways. Or rather, one right way...

+ Tons and tons of economy management with many options to choose from.

+ Agents, being both notoriously OP in specific circumstances to bottomline useless in others. I had fun with them though.


- There are a solid amount of differing units, but more than half of them are basically the same unit with a lesser number and some minor stat changes. So all in all, there are 4 units in total. Ranged attackers, Cavalry, Cannons, and Grenediers.

- Attrociously stupid AI. That 1000 vs 200 troop battle I mentioned above? All due to flanking. This isn't is a bad thing...but let me explain: The AI loves to send in either 1 small garrison of troops or turtles until you get close, in which case, they rinse and repeat that sending in of 1 set of troops at a time. This makes it very easy to flank them constantly. 

- All battles are won by flanking. The few times I saw good AI, was when they had reinforcements come in that I was unaware of, which flanked my squad and ultimately caused my squad to panic and run away.

- Routing I feel like is a dumb mechanic that needs to be squashed away. It's far to easy to rout by flanking. Sometimes a simple flank will kill 1 or 2 troops of 120 troop squad and the whole squad will bolt out of there. 

- Cannons were absolutely useless. I did heavy googling and was told Canister Shot was the only useful part of cannons, and they were right. But still not nearly as useful as a load of cavalry that you can flank enemies with.

- Unit management in battle is FRUSTRATING. They require lining themselves up constantly in an attempt to imitate the 1700-1800s style of strategic troop placement, wasting precious time, before ever firing a single bullet. Units get bugged on fortress walls, not sure whether to go up or down the stairs when attacking enemies. Units will not shoot enemies at all sometimes, just staring at them blankly while the enemy shoots at you. 

- They threw in the American Revolution as a story point but they didn't add any story into the campaign. A pointless contribution.


Overall, I'm let down. I beat the Road to Independence campaign on Normal and that's as far as I'm going. For anyone who reads this and is thoroughly experienced in Total War games, give me a recommendation of an actually good Total War game, and I will check it out.

If you're looking for a good and easy to learn strategy game, then i can't reccommend this game enough! This is perhaps one of my favourite Total War titles and funnily enough Empire was the one that got me into the Total War franchise. Now i played vanilla for a couple of hours and had a good long campagine with Britian, Sweden and Prussia. (Including the Road To Independence campagine). 

I then used mods because you quickly find out that you can only play the major nations of that time period, such as Britain, France, Spain, Russia etc. The big bois. I downloaded the minor factions mod and holy shit it makes the game a hundread times better! The mod lets you play every single nation (hence the name) that you can't play in vanilla, which is strange really because it would've probs received better reception. I'm still using Minor Factions Revenge to this day and haven't returned to vanilla since, it not only gives u the ability to play every nation available, but it also has custom sounds, FX, units, soundtrack, models, historical figures, tech, UI etc. There are also plenty of other mods out there such as Darthmod and ACW (American civil war), again some key elements that was missing from vanilla, the mods are an all around improvement of the game and supposedly what ETW was meant to be but we didn't get.  

So do i reccommend this game? Hell yes, but if you are going to purcahse i would personally wait for a sale and then mod the shit out of it! The mods are easy to install and the Total War community is great with plenty guides to help you get started.

Around 70 hours and I haven't even finished the general campaign, and I'm playing the vanilla version, still have to try the mods. That's why I can only talk about the unmodded version: it's great. I read that at launch this game was quite buggy, well, that's one of the reasons I take my time to get the games I want, waiting for the best possible version. Empire: Total War is big, really big, you have almost every continent to play with, and I imagine that with mods the experience must be awesome! The only real flaw I found is that after every turn, specially when you have invested tons of hours already, the "loading" part when every faction does their stuff before you yourself can do your thing can get very loooooong. Sometimes you have to wait for like 10 minutes!
it is a goood game but if you play it for 3 hours i will get very board

I will preface this review by saying: if you are a fan of Napoleon Total War, then this game is a fun side-on (even though technically it came out first). I quite enjoy this game and can (to an extent) understand the praise heaped upon it by reviewers on release. However...

This game has gained a notorious reputation due to its AI and path-finding, and these two factors turn the game almost into one of luck. On the one hand even on Hard difficulty, the AI enemies have two strategies, one for defence (turtling) and one for offense (sending their units at you in a big line that can easily be outflanked). Therefore, even if you are outnumbered five to one, you can still easily win, thus presenting no real challenge. On the other hand, the way in which the units control (at least is my opinion) is atrocious. I cannot count how many times I have given clear instructions to a unit to line up on one side of a wall to defend it, only to come back a minute later to find them facing the opposite direction and being shot in the back. Even if you are a military genius, you can potentially lose battles due to your units simply disobeying orders, or the UI and controls being so bad that they bug out and do whatever the hell they want.

In campaign mode, the Diplomacy is also a joke (a running theme in some of the Total War games) with the AI being either hyper aggressive (never surrendering or making peace even if you are crushing them) or being flat out stupid (declaring war on long time allies just because).

If you like Total War (like I do) then you will probably enjoy this game. However, if you have to choose between this and Napoleon for the Lined Infantry style of warfare, choose Napoleon: it is far better in graphical quality, UI quality and is much more refined.

[h1]Empire: Total War was a Total Failure[/h1]

This game sucks!

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Huge map. One of the biggest in Total War history.
[*] Loads of factions.
[*] Possibly the only modern game based in this time period.
[/list]
[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Bugs everywhere! Your game could come to an end at any moment thanks to unfixable game breaking bugs. There are so many minor and major bugs that I can't even list them all!
[*] AI is abysmal on the campaign map and in battles! The AI will charge back and forth in front of your lines and won't attack. Your own troops will sometimes decide not to fire at all. Your own troops won't fire unless every single man is in formation so if one man is stuck the whole unit will stand and do nothing! Melee combat is awful as your troops will sometimes stand staring at each other instead of fighting. AI will make the dumbest diplomatic decisions. AI will recruit armies that make no strategic sense! The AI will never flank you, if you flank the AI you will win everytime. Whole units might commit suicide during seige battles by climbing down off the wall and dying for no reason. Units are really slow at doing anything to tell them to do. Cannons are completely useless. Sometimes the AI won't attack when they're supposed to and if you turned off battle timer you're screwed! THE LIST GOES ON...
[*] Routing mechanic is broken, I've seen whole units of 120 men break and run because 1 or 2 men got shot.
[*] The mods do not fix this game! Some idiots say there are mods that fix the game but trust me they don't. The core gameplay is broken and no mod can fix it.
[/list]

WHATEVER YOU DO DON'T BUY THIS. The positive reviews are written through nostalgia goggles, you would have to be half brain dead to enjoy this. The reason for why Napoleon: Total War exists is because Creative Assembly was aware how awful Empire: Total War was.

Just don't buy this and don't listen to anyone who tells you otherwise. This is as broken as Rome 2 was.

Ive played hundreds of hours of the Total War series and this is by far the most disappointing and upsetting. And I dont just mean in comparison to the newer titles in the series. Even Medieval was better. The bad mechanics let down what is a really interesting setting for a Total War game. Switching between melee and ranged mode for units has yet to work without bugging. Its too unreliable to even consider using anymore, it literally just makes units stop moving, cease firing, and await death. In the world map, a single unit can raid multiple resources in a turn and hamstring your entire civilisation unless you garrison every single farm/mine/school/port, (of which there are several per region) simply so a stray bandit wont begin a famine that unravells your entire society. If you're at war with a faction and they wish for peace, they will pester you every single turn until they get it. So enjoy 45 seconds of denying peace every turn as every faction has a crack at it every single turn. AI has no prompting to attack when theyre attempting to break a seige, so you enter a battle the enemy instigated, and then they just wait for you to storm the walls, completely nullifying the point of seiging in the first place.
There are better Total War Games. This is the worst.

So I have never written a review for a game; ever. I've been an active steam member for 12 years, have owned multiple products, played some for almost 1,000 hours, and i've never written a review. Until now.

Empire: Total War is a blissful take on what a [strike]good[/strike] great strategy game is. While being a little (it's not even noticeable, really) buggy in regards to A.I controlled opponents, overall it's not even an issue. The campaign mode is detailed; enormously detailed. I first loaded up a 'World Domination' campaign as France and almost lost my mind. Initially, I thought to myself "This is too complex, I just want to control some soldiers and punch on with England". 3 days later, i'm still playing the same campaign, currently negotiating with Spain over the new American world, losing my trade routes to Swedish raiders, desperately rallying soldiers for a fresh Prussian invasion to the east, and putting down rebellions constantly in England while they refuse my rule.

Annoyed by politics in the real world? Load up Empire: Total War and just fire ministers for the hell of it. Problems with England expanding into resource-rich America? Just take London by force, and cut them off early. It's a game where you control how your empire unfolds, who your friends are, or if you want to just take everyone down with you.

What attracted me to the Total War franchise are the battles themselves though. It's always a moment of absolute awe the first time you enter the deployment screen and see the tens and thousands of your units ready and willing to engage the enemy, and the tactics you need to utilise. Every unit serves a function, from cheap meat shields, to fully armoured heavy cavalry, right down to hit and run skirmishers. Morale is everything. Your soldiers will only fight as well as the rest of your army; the more weak points you have, the more likely it is you will be scattered. Your soldiers gain experience and ranks which are so valuable it isn't even funny. Facing a 10,000+ Austrian invasion force? Your highly experienced 2000+ linesman will shock you with how well they perform. Seriously. I've faced utter annihilation holed up in a fort with barely 400 soldiers, and still managed to hold the line against almost 5,000 Ottoman soldiers, all thanks to how mobile they were around the siege, and how battle hardened they already were.

So far, I can't stop playing. I'm at work right now writing this, hoping to pass the time until I can get home in... 6 hours, 28 minutes, load up my campaign, and get right back to sending those loyalist redcoats right back to the hell they came from.

Empire is the first of the Steam Total War games I played.  It has been a great experience, and it has spoiled me for strategy/tactical-in-one games. I have also played Napoleon, Shogun2, Attila and most recently Rome2. I would like to see an Empire2 which includes a multi-player campaign/tactical offering which would expand the use of naval units as done in Shogun2-Fall of the Samurai. 

Other themes for future Total War games might be Unifying Ancient China, WW1 and of course WW2.

Another theme might be the American Civil War, though I realize it is essentially a 2 sided game.  A multi-player game could incorporate players on each side down to Brigade or Division level leadership, or at the very least Corp commanders. Diplomacy might even involve Native Americans, Mexico, Britain and France.  Just a thought.

This game, is superb, I don't think I'll be able to play another game like it, but enough, let me tell you the tale of how poland became stronk!

So, when I started, I had only those beginning regions, and some protectorates, soon, Sweden declared war on Russia, I responded with my army, and, much like star wars, they were raw recruits, then they became my 501st, they went all throughout Sweden, eventually, and finally, conquering it, I think it took 20 years, at the same time I spent some time, reforming the infrastructure, and then went to war with Prussia when they swindled me into a deal, I quickly overran them, went to war with Westphalia, lost the Great General Miloslaw, who died in Bavaria, he was replaced with General Miloslaw, Westphalia, however, was a total loss, I had no idea what we were up against, and signed peace, went to war with Hannover, Berlin rebels, and three battles are fought to take it back, one when my troops were defending, the second when I was laying siege, and they attacked me, and the third when the only survivors of the second tried attacking, effectively ending them, at this same time, took over Hannover, but cut them a deal, they were now my protectorate, time passes, spend on troops, and infrastructure, realize nearing campaign deadline, invade Austria, win!

Good game with a unique trading system. Campaign map gameplay feels smooth and easy, with enough micro- and macromanagement to keep you entertained for a while. Combat however, is often awkward with non-responsive or slow responding troops, and sieges are a downright pain at times. Darthmod is a must-have, since it fixes a lot of battles. Naval battles are fun and rewarding, although they tend to get too messy and clustered when fighting with a large fleet against an equally large fleet. All in all, the game has many new and unique options never seen in gaming before, and I'd recommend trying it out if you like strategy games.

Fort assault can be terrible though, to the point of auto-resolving it instead of playing it out.

The main selling point for me in this game was the very well executed naval battle mechanic. It takes a little practice to understand keeping  your ships in line or double line formation while both navies hammer away at each other with shot and grape. I haven't used any mods in this game, so that may be an option to explore. 

Not sure if there are any major dislikes other than needing a variety in additional ship types like the Spanish and Russian navies who sported very unique ship designs. The landscape also can be a little bit infuriating because it's a bit of a departure from the more contoured landscapes of Medieval II. There are also some minor bugs, but its more inconvenience rather than anything that dimishes play. 

Although there are some minor issues, these are overshadowed at least for me by the primary items listed since I've seen few other games that focus on that aspect of naval combat and done in a way that gives it justice. If you are a fan of the Age of Sail then check this one out.

Empire: Total War is a stunning game. It is a more advance version of the total war series. The Maps is seperated into 3; The North Americas, Europe and India. The design and organisation of the game is meticulous and it is enjoyable whether you play it in campaign or if you follow the story line. The awesome part about Empire compared to the other Total War Series (with the exception of Napolean: Total War) is the naval battles where you can literally manouver ships in naval battles. Enjoy!

It's a really nice game, but the AI is horrible. And by horrible, I mean horrible. Cavarly charging for some mortars with infantry behind them? They'll never engage just turn around until they rout. Artillery bombarding enemy artillery? They'll refuse to ever fire. Enemy AI having a 10:1 advantage and assaulting you? No they'll just sit and get destroyed by artillery. My 453 hours on Napoleon Total War pretty much sum up how I hate hate the battle AI, the rest of the game is good.

A tale of Greatness.

Britain battled its way into France, the war lasting a few long bloody years, until Britain managed to vanquish the French to hell. It was time for peace across the Empire, money from trade gave the people and cities of the Empire a whole host of new technologies not to mention wealth, war was no longer on the agenda for Britain. Peace with all their immediate neighbours was now the key. 

The American front was abandoned, too costly for the Empire to pursue. The money gained over many years of peace now began to become too great to ignore, something had to be done. A show of grandeur? A voyage to the new world perhaps? No. A voyage to another continent entirely, this was Britain's goal. A war with India ensued for decades but finally the war came to and end and the good times followed. Wealth unimaginable to a commoner of the period. Other Empires grew ever more jealous and dared challenge the might of the Empire now spanning over a great reach of the globe. Small skirmishes for Britain were great wars for other countries. Europe and parts of Russia were lost. Once a peaceful Empire, now consumed by a ravenous apatite for all known land.

America, a newly formed country was at the time the last bastion of the civilised world not yet controlled by Britain. Vast fleets were contracted over a 60 year span, the day came when Operation Tea Party was launched.  Somewhat of a Colonial Blitzkrieg ensued. America fell in a matter of years.

-Great Campaign spanning 3 continents with tons of factions, resource management tools, excellent mechanics.
-Patched combat is very good; it's not Napoleon quality, but still endlessly fun. 
-Naval combat is decent. It can be very fun, but it's usually better to play the actual battles rather than autoresolve.
-Unit detail and historical accuracy with uniforms is not Napoleon level, but the units and the environments are very pretty compared to preious TW generation.
-Autoresolve function will see your armies whittle away fast, and playing every single battle can make for a very time-consuming campaign, especially if you start with one of the larger factions.
-Useable buildings and fortifications can still be buggy.
-Overall an excellent and extremely entertaining 18th century warfare strategy game.

Empire Total War in my opinion is one of the greatest Total War titles, before Warhammer was released. It became the bar I checked all future titles against, and still miss the naval combat in current titles. I have played the crap out of this game. 

What particularly made this game fun was the actual battles and SHIP to SHIP combat. Back in 2009 when it was released, unfortunately this suffered from quite a few bugs that I think hurt it's release, which largely have been resolved.

This was a bold new direction for the Total War series when it was released, and it stands up well.  There are some issues with the siege mechanics, and it would've been nice to see South American, African and Asian theatres, but otherwise good fun.

Empire is proabably the worst game of the total war series.

1.  UI is pretty bad, with undistinctive uniforms in a battle.
2.  Troops move slowly and react poorly to commands.
3.  Artillery is utterly garbage in this game.  Even direct hits barely do anything.  Totally inaccurate, even at short range.
4.  cavlary is garbage,  light cav cant beat heavy cav even with 3 to 1 numbers.  Totally useless against line infantry.  Unit size is also too small
5.  Bad balance.  This game is totally about line infantry spam.  Just play UK and spam line infantry,some guards and light cavlary.  They can take on anything in the game.  Most other factions are quite weak that dont have good line infantry,  Indians, natives, russia, 
6.  Skirimishers are optional,  generally it turns into a melee where cav catches skirmishes and then all line infantry, especially UK go into melee.  Uk line infantry can shred most other line infantries even when outnumbered.

There are only a handfull of strategy games that let me play as India. Fewer still let me actually conquer the world while playing as India. This one allowed me to do both. Living in a country that has to deal with the legacy of being exploited for centuries by a colonial power, it was very satifying destroying all of them, one by one, if only in a game. I saved England for last.

In addition to that it was every bit as fun as I've come to expect from the Total War series. I'd give it 10/10 if not for that annoying message asking me to buy the DLC every time I started the game. So 9/10 then.

Empire: Total War is a bit different from other Total War entries, for starters,
its the most advanced time period a game is based of ever.
the combat is a bit different as well as ranged battles became almost the 
absolute of the warfare (suits the time period well wich is nice).
about the period I gotta say it was all made really great, everything
from the industrialization wich is present to the american revolution,
everything is quite accurate. 
ill switch now to a more short, summorized review.

POSITIVES:
-Graphics are great considering it was made in 09.
-UI is well placed and designed, really in the spirit of the period.
-Sound is okay, outstanding in battle.
-Music is great and well placed.
-Combat is great but...

NEGETIVES:
-...Sieging is the worst ever in a Total War game.
-Sometimes will crash, corrupt save files and glitch out.
-Tutorial is somewhat of a drag and uninspiring. 

My overall score: 7.2/10

I never liked this period of history until I started playing Empire Total War. The way battles are unfolding, with deep tactical approach to each battle, changed my mind about the 18th century forever.

As far as the game itself is concerned, one of the best features are naval battles; unpredictable and powerful, you will be on the edge of your chair whenever you deploy your precious fleet to fight the enemy. Do you have enough gunpower? Enough manpower? Are your ships slow? Are their flanks exposed to multiple ships at once? Are winds favoring your approach?

Questions are many, but answer is one: You must use your wits and skill to emerge a victor from this carnage.

As an avid fan of strategy games, Empire: Total War really takes the cake. Campaign wise, you get to lead your glorious nation through the 18th century across three theaters and conquer the globe. The technology tree compliments the game very well, immersing you in the feeling of truly being in the Age of Enlightenment. In the battle view, you get to watch 1000s of men clash with muskets, cannons, sabers, and bayonets... what's not to like? The only thing stopping you is your ambition...

Mediterranean Chicken and Pasta
Makes: 4 servingsPrep: 5 mins Cook: 15 mins Carb Grams Per Serving: 38
Ingredients
1 6 - ounce jar marinated artichoke hearts
1 tablespoon olive oil
12 ounces skinless, boneless chicken breast, cut into bite-size pieces
3 garlic cloves, thinly sliced
1/4 cup chicken broth
1/4 dry white wine
1 teaspoon dried oregano, crushed
1 7 - ounce jar roasted red peppers, drained and cut into strips
1/4 cup pitted kalamata olives
3 cups hot cooked campanelle or penne pasta
1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese (optional)
Directions
Drain artichoke hearts, reserving marinade, and chop them.
In a large skillet, heat oil over medium-high heat; add chicken and garlic. Cook and stir until chicken is brown. 
Add the reserved artichoke marinade, broth, wine and dried oregano.
Bring to a boil; reduce heat. Simmer, covered, 10 minutes.
Stir in chopped artichokes, roasted peppers and olives.
To serve, spoon chicken mixture over pasta. If desired, sprinkle with feta cheese.
Nutrition Information
Servings Per Recipe: 4

This is a true story, one of Austria's finest generals, and how he fought to bring Austria victory. 

> Starts game as Austria
> Is a Absolute Monarchy, so we have a King and a Prince.
> The Kings son, Prince Eugan, is already great at fighting
> Decides to send him to Poland-Lithuania, to help the war effort
> Prince Eugan conquers all of Poland-Lithuania
> 10/10 Job Prince Eugan
> Decides its a good time to go attack the Ottomans
> Sends Prince Eugan to go help the war effort
> Prince Eugan conquers all of the Ottomans lands that Venice hadn't already conquered
> 20/10 job Prince Eugan
> Revolution happens, Government loses and a new Republic is established
> Nobody really cares about it so they keep calling him Prince, but don't be confused, the President is in charge now.
> Prussia's military is becoming a little too big
> Also Realizes they hold land I need
> dammit prussia why are you the bane of my existance
> Sends Prince Eugan to go deal with it
> Prince Eugan already has 5 stars under his belt, and is brilliant
> Prince Eugan wins battle after battle, with forces outnumbering his 2:1
> Prince Eugan has now conquered Prussia
> 30/10 job Prince Eugan
> Prince Eugan mops up the rest of the Small Nations that fought against Austria
> Prince Eugan is now the most accomplished man in the empire
> Middle Class gets pissed and has a Civil War
> They win, and a Constitutional Monarchy is born
> Prince Eugan is now a Prince again
> Realizes I need to go get Istanbul and Venice from Venice, as the year is 1740
> Prince Eugan goes and takes Istanbul, where another General takes his place
> Prince Eugan is on his way to Venice when he realizes that Austria was taken by the Italian States
> Prince Eugan takes back Austria
> He marches to Venice, and than to Rome to destroy the Italian States
> He succeeds
> Prince Eugan has single handedly toppled Poland-Lithuania, Prussia, the Italian States, Venice, and the Ottomans in Europe
> 40/10 job Prince Eugan
> Austria's stellar military holds Istanbul from the Ottomans, and we win the game
> Prince Eugan is now 90 years old and Is still alive, as he watches the fireworks

God Bless your soul Prince Eugan, you have done your country proud.

I want to recommend this game, I want to play this game, I love TW... but the bugs/annoyances that persist in this game are unbearable:
1. Cannot multitask - if I close the window I need to close the game and reset - wtf? That alone is brutal. 
2. Troops ignore commands at key moments, for example firing in lines is fairly straight forward - hold the line, fire reload, don't start turning around to face the other way and then get charged by cavalry (tried with or with guard mode - no wavering, losses or problems). 
3. (this one is personal preference) hate that fact it's spread over various continents but some may enjoy that. Pick one, and stick to it. 
4. Compared to Shogun 2 and Medieval 2, this is far from my favourite (but still better than most other TWs).  Why? The AI is just ridiculous perhaps it is totally essentially to use Darthmod.  

Areas it does well are:
1. It's a key period of history that was a power struggle for the mega powers and the lead up to 'Western Civilisation' along with capitalism.
2. If and when it works it is beautiful with high graphics, the musket smoke to cannon fire - a beautiful game. 
3. Naval battles look great, still clunky but look amazing.  

The bugs have literally held me up from being able to get some enjoyment going but I have to assume they aren't common.

Short review: Good game.

Long review: This game is packed with stuff to do. And you are having fun doing those things. The thing I have noticed in this game though, when compared to Napoleon: Total War, this game has some glitches that N:TW doesn't have, but N:TW has some glitches that work perfectly in this game. For example shooting artillery with your infantry. In N:TW those things seem to absorb all the shots, while in E:TW you can shoot artillery with your muskets. 

There are some other things in E:TW such as:
1) Lags sometimes during battles, even though your PC specs are way over recommended.
2) Sometimes infantry will not shoot even within range WITH fire at will enabled and they have ammo

Look. If you like TW games, you need to have this one. BUT make sure this isn't the first Total War game you play, because it might be confusing at some times. 
This Total War is one of my personal favorites despite some of these glitches.

Before I start off this review, I just want to say that I've always been a fan of anything RTS, and I have been interested in this video game genre for as long as I can remember. Another thing, Empire: Total War was my first Total War game I ever played. Initially, after playing the game for a few hours, I was somewhat confused because I usually played real-time strategy games such as Stronghold, Age of Empires, and similar titles. Although confused at first, since Empire: Total War was turn-based and focused more in-depth on economic & government management, I was not disappointed whatsoever. In fact, I honestly enjoyed playing this game very much and I still do. I recall purchasing this game when it was on sale along with the full DLC bundle. I honestly can say that the various DLC that is available for this game is definitely worth your money. Before I continue, I am going list the pros and cons of this game.

Pros:
-Fairly large campaign map. The campaign map (excluding the American Revolution campaign), includes the regions of Europe, North Africa, India, North America, Northern South America & the Caribbean. However, there are minor trade areas such as the Ivory Coast, far eastern Asia, Madagascar, etc...
-There are many playable factions that are featured in this game. These factions include Great Britain, France, Austria. Spain, the Ottoman Empire, and much more. There are also many 'emergent' factions that are basically nations that are created whenever certain provinces revolt, such as Hungary or Ireland. 
-Implements historical references through the use of short articles  (This might be more of a personal preference of mine, but as somebody who looves history, I've always found the historical implemented articles interesting.) Another thing, these historical articles pop up throughout the vanilla campaign as in-game years advance. 
-There are many unique and fun mods that you can download. These mods include Darthmod (my personal favorite), the civil war mod, and much more. I definitely recommend you to check out these mods. 
-The in-game real-time battles can be very engaging. These battles can either be naval or land, however, they are very interesting to see and participate in, especially when you play multiplayer matches. 
-The soundtrack accurately fits the game. I've always found the soundtrack during the campaign soothing and calm, and warlike during battles respectively. 
-The multiplayer aspect of this game is good at best. Although not very crowded with players, whenever you do join a multiplayer match, you and your opponent generally feel competitive and focused.
-Although the governmental and economic managing may be confusing at first, especially if you aren't familiar with this type of RTS, you will eventually get the hang of it. The managing aspect isn't a very difficult concept to understand.

Cons:
-During battles and sometimes during campaigns, you might run into a few bugs here and there. 
-The AI during battles might be an annoyance from time to time. These annoyances include not reacting to your orders, not responding to enemy fire, and basically being bullet sponges. These annoyances are often an occurrence during large fortress battles.
-The campaign AI, such as other factions, may do random actions, such as invading an isolated province far away from their own nation without any real reason. This is especially evident with the Maratha Confederacy, as they tend to become pretty powerful during the vanilla campaign if they are isolated long enough, and this faction tends to invade provinces far away. Although I do not expect this game to be totally historically accurate throughout the campaign, I've always found it funny and somewhat annoying whenever the Maratha Confederacy, an Indian faction, invade Rupert's Land in North America. 

So there it is, my pros and cons of this game. Please take note that many of these pros and cons apply to the vanilla game (without mods). I highly recommend buying this game if you are into turn-based strategy and real time battles. This game is definitely worth the current price it is being sold for.

This game is the base that made Modern Total war games as great as they are today. This game has the raw intensity of the original series of games ( Rome, Shogun) with some of the newer (and highly fragile) aspects. Unfortunately this game comes with old bugs that plagued the originals, including the "Turn 50 Oversized Nation" lag spikes, specifically for the Ottomans. It becomes less of a problem if you increase the game's ram availability manually, but the game itself struggles to process the turns of bigger nations late game.

This is minor though, as most games you can squash the big nations before they become a laggy mess. Oh, and dont forget, there are mods everywhere for this, as it incorporates the modern and post modern TW elements, allowing it to include a huge variety.

This game is horribly broken, atleast in my few hours of experience.

I'm not referring to gameplay mechanic or anything like that, that's all well in hand. The thing that kills it for me is the astoundingly horrible AI and crashes/freezing. So I'll go over the good and the bad (Atleast in my opinion).

THE BAD

The AI: It's bad, it's just bad. Keep in mind I've clocked 200+ hours in M2TW and the AI there is bad. The AI immediatly wages war against everything around it, which isn't bad, the problem is everyone is your ally and youre always inclined to help them.  The problem, the ally AI ALWAYS loses, as Britain, both the United Provinces and Portugese were destroyed in a matter of turns when I went to war with them. And keep in mind you remain at war even if you're far away from the enemy faction. Arranging peace I'll get too. But the AI is just outrageously horrible, letting you go nearly anywhere and getting BS forces from nowhere.


Diplomacy: It's worse than M2 standards. Want peace? Too bad, even if theyre down to one province and under siege, they'll want all your colonies. Example; At war with Maratha, offer peace in exchange for some tech and money (No territory owned by me in India keep in mind), what do they do even though it is a useless war? Want Parts of Canada and the Carribean. CANADA AND THE CARRIBEAN, AND THEY'RE BASED IN INDIA!!! Like wtf AI. This makes it impossible tomake peace in these useless wars as you can never bribe them. They either flat out refguse or give you terrible demands, this goes for any other diplomacy.


Freezing/Crashing: Maybe this is just a problem with muy toaster, but every few turns the game will crash or freeze, forcing me to shut down my computer and log back on. Not much else to say.


The Music: Coming from M2TW, I guess I expected grand battle themes, but nope, just some quiet none fun ones.

----------------

THE GOOD

Politics: Love itm, civilian anger to taxes, revolutions, changing governments, it's wonderful as a mechanism to remind you of internal threats. Elections are random, so you may get good, bad, or meh mebers of government, but whatever.

Gameplay Mechanics: Battles are done fairly well and can be engaging in situations such as sieges or big engagements, but small engagements aren't as fun.

Other Bits: The little trinkets of history, economy and other things are also very fun bits to learn about and play around with.

Tech Tree: A bit annoying but great feature to decide what to focus on (Military, farming, philosophy).

----------

Summary: Overall Empire is a meh game for me, the upsides are negated by the problems with it to me, and I find it only enjoyable in small doses. I would recommend it to anyone interested in the time period (18th Century).

I suppose I'll continue playing it irregularly but not as often as I'd like.

(Also you get some stuff for TF2 so there's that).

Beneath all the features and complex game mechanics, Empire remains a mix of turn-based empire building and real-time strategy, these two elements kept separate but affecting each other throughout the game. In the one half, you're developing your cities, raising and moving armies and sending out agents to spy, sabotage or steal technology on your behalf. You also have to maintain diplomatic relations with allies and rivals, steer scientific progress to develop new military, social and technological assets, and ensure that your economy remains headed in the right direction. When conflict rears its ugly head - and inevitably it will - it's time for the other half of the game to take over. This is the 3D real-time strategy that you'll remember from previous Total War games or the BBC programme Time Commanders; a fast-paced, realistic simulation of warfare featuring dozens of units and thousands of men on the field at any one time.


It's a mix designed to satisfy would-be Bismarcks and would-be Napoleons, and the game cleverly allows you to play the way you like best. Handling both portions gives you the full, rich Total War experience, but if you want to let the AI handle the management of the economy and the society, you can. If you want to let battles resolve themselves and concentrate on the political drama, then that's fine too. If you want, you don't even have to spend a second in the central 'Grand Campaign'; you can just set up your own battles or play the pre-defined scenarios, and just enjoy the sounds of booming cannon, musket-fire and clashing steel.

Empire is definitely one of my favourite titles in the Total War series but for a lot of TW gamers I talk to they don't often understand why. Empire ranks fairly low in terms of reception alongside other contemporary titles despite being the only TW game set in the Georgian era. I'm going to avoid doing a huge broad review of the game, and instead focus on two points I'd like to raise for the new player:

1) The battle engine

This gets a lot of hate right off the bat. Essentially, before Empire if you charged two units of infantry together in any preceding game they would smush into a realistic mass and start going to town on one another. If four of your guys surrounded one of the enemy, they would all attack together and punch his lights out. Since the Warscape engine was introduced with Empire, the combat is reduced to kill moves only. This means that only one soldier can kill any one other soldier at any one time, and it is based on pre-scripted and often quite lengthy kill moves. Combine this with a very badly-designed unit collision system? If you look at a melee battle, it's like watching Cheerios with ADHD fight for control of the milk.

Empire does reduce this impact somewhat. With the basis being on firelock warfare above everything else, the vast majority of your battles on this game are going to be conducted at range with the major exception of cavalry charges. The engine is nowhere near as prominent in this scenario, and I actually think the musket volleys look great when they pick out six or seven blokes from across the enemy's front line. I cannot excuse the melee though, it just looks awful.

2) Campaign Diplomacy

The campaign itself was a lot of fun for me. I found the politics system a little dry and underused, but aside from the occasional spot of lag the campaign map was by and large really enjoyable. I have played a Swedish and Prussian game recently and really enjoyed both aside from one thing: the diplomacy.

The diplomacy makes no sense. The AI factions ask for backwater regions all the time, they refuse alliances and trade agreements for no good reason, the factors influencing international reputation are incredibly difficult to manipulate and almost impossible to move back to positive/negative after they have gone too far in either direction and above all it just lacks any kind of logic and breaks the immersion. 



There are tons more pros and cons to the game, but I felt I'd keep my review nice and concise and focus on the two biggest deal breakers for me. Even with those in full effect, I still love this game and have great fun both on single and multiplayer. I'd recommend it for sure!

Fun game. One really has to be forward thinking to be able to balance managing your empire while being in constant states of war.  The naval aspect is difficult; land warfare is challenging and fun. The appointment of competent ministers is a constant battle as they can change ovver time to bacome less efficient and effective. Negotiations seem impossible until you become very powerful, but are still fun to attempt. Allowing one to rewrite history to some extent is such a thrill.

This is widely criticized as one of the buggiest titles in the series and often called one of the worst overall. I wholeheartedly disagree with the latter.

While this title is certainly buggy at times, it performs very well and provides some of the most entertaining total war battles to date. The naval battles are second only to Napoleon (and to be honest I didn't really put much time into Napoleon so I really should not count that title). The land battles are capable of being incredibly large and exceptionally exciting. The AI isn't the best in the series but I find it good enough to provide a challenge.

Overall, the game looks and sounds great. The game may crash on rare occasions as many games will eventually do but this one has a greater tendency to run for hours without trouble on all of the systems I have ever played it on. The game's DLC isn't all that great but what really matters is the base campaign which is awesome fun.

Compared to other games in the series, this one has the largest playable campaign map with regions stretching as far west as the American mid-west and as far east as India. The naval battles are so good you will actually WANT to play them...most of the time...they will admittedly get a big tedious later on when you have 20 or more ships under your command.

Overall I feel this game is largely over-criticized because it was the first in the series built on the newer game engine which frustrated a lot of the old school fans. While I still prefer Medieval 2 to this title, I still enjoy this title today and can't wait for an Empire 2.

[h1]Rule the world[/h1]
Empire: Total War is a turn based strategy game with realtime battles. When you start, you take control of a few main countries of that era, during the years around 1700 AD. You can play on North America, Europe, North Africa and India. 

Empire is one of the most ambitious TW titles with its huge map(s) and features from Rome and Medieval 2. I enjoyed american campaign and indian warpath or european contries as well. On the other hand, the ambition is its own downfall as it the big map feel kinda empty and sometimes a bit wrapped things around some core ideas are better than this goulash of all things that were good in previous titles. 
Also I highly suggest using some mods especially focusing on AI tweaking such as Darthmod etc., AI in this game is actually worse than in Medieval and its probably biggest minus of this title.

++ Musket era
+ Graphics. For such old title it still looks more than decent.
+ Gameplay and historic events.
+ Massive map.
+ Nice and long research tree. Fire by rank looks great btw.
+ Colonies. Being able to conquer most of the world.
+ Interesting campaigns.
+ Multiplayer. Community over this game is still alive.
+- Similar UI like in Medieval II "classic", might feel outdated for some people.
-- AI
- Reinforcing lost men in units for money. I see why this feature was changed in later installments.
- Dificulty. Game is rushing you to progress faster (time is the issue) but both campaing and battle AI is horrid without mods. Very hard's not making much sense since its just alienation of all your neighbours and AI cheats more with money.
- No option for making protectorats (Napoleon TW feature)
- Graphical glitches

This game is for everyone who is fond of the history of the 18th century, of the time when the European powers were fighting relentlessly with each other in order to conquer more lands and impose its supremacy. The game is a real advance in the Total War series. The quality of grafics both on a strategic map and on a battlefield is impressive. The 18th cenury is a period of the rapid development of technological progress, so you'd better pay attention to this important issue during the game, otherwise your enemies would become more technologically advanced and sooner or later you would get into a big trouble. The times of brave knights in full armour, undisputable advantages of heavy cavalry on the battlefields have gone. Now new tactics rule the show, and there is a new belle in this bloody ball and its name is line infantry. And do not forget to protect your ports and trade rutes and for this you would have to maintain a powerfull fleet. Epic war battles, which are the most important innovation in the Total War series, are waiting for you! Don't know how to steer war vessels and order them to attack your enemy and maneuver under the fire? So, you'd better begin learning! Anyway, if you are keen on the atmosphere of the 18th century and would like to imagine yourself a ruler, general and admiral of the century of the Enlightenment, this game will absorb you completely and give you real pleasure! Good luck in your conquests and great deeds!

Oh, Empire! How I hate loving you. I have ploughed many hours in to this game, and honestly I'm not sure why. Actually I am sure why: long, very long, turn times. Even on decent hardware it takes an age for AI factions to complete their turns, which often kills any enjoyment early in a campaign, and as with most campaigns you will want to play through to the year 1800 for victory, that means 200 long waits. If you're in for the long hall, bring some work with you, or just have a kettle nearby as you'll have plenty of time to get on with other things or make a nice cup of tea while you wait. 

That being said, I have enjoyed this game. I love the time period, and it is certainly ambitious as the campaign allows you to battle over multiple continents and grow a truly global empire for your faction. Being British, I also loved the addition of naval combat and the chance to role out First Rate Ships-of-the-Line and wreak merry mayhem across the seas. There is a lot to like about deploying your troops to America and slashing through hordes of Native Indian tribesmen, or establishing a trading post in India and then having to repulse waves of marauding Mughals as you try to set up your tea plantations and secure your trade routes. However, there is also a lot not to like about useless AI that really can't handle large infantry formations, weirdly missing features (such as a family tree, or commanders with personality), uninteresting siege battles, and odd bits that should never have made it passed the Beta testing, like the fact that you can't repair damaged city defenses. 

All of these can be fixed with Mods (DarthMod being the go-to), and there is enough here to warrant a recommendation, but it is a close call. The Creative Assembly team dropped many balls with this one, and showed the kind of complacency that reared its ugly head again in Rome II. I do hope they re-visit this time period, and ultimately this game with a Napoleon Total War facelift would be fantastic. If you want to enjoy truly global empire building then dive in, but at a low price as the game is likely to frustrate. However, if you need more polish in the same historical setting, then I recommend heading for the far more reliable Napoleon Total War.

As a huge total war fan, I was very disappointed with E:TW. I couldn't even force myself to put more than a few sessions into the game because of one thing - How awful the battle AI and unit pathing is.

I've put thousands of hours into rome 1 and Shogun 2. Most of them were played on the lowest settings on an old mac before I built my PC, so I'm VERY familiar with the general weirdness of total war AI. Empire takes every weird bug and turns it up to 11. Units won't fire when they're obviously in range. (Yes I know how line of sight works) Movement orders over bridges will often send your units halfway across the map to cross in the shallows. Attack orders can end in a unit casually strolling towards the enemy only to reform at the wrong angle. 

Seige battles especially are almost unplayable. Units will not fire off the walls correctly, cannons will not target walls correctly. Good luck trying to order your units through the right holes in the wall, they will just run off to a different side of the fort taking fire.

There's so much potential for an amzing game here but the clunkiness brings it down to the worst Total War game I've ever played. There's no single glaring flaw but the exceptionlly stupid AI makes you micromanage your units constantly. If you don't they will end up taking a route you didn't want them to, getting stuck on terrain or taking casualties you didn't deserve. Nothing is worse than having units get destroyed just because they didn't do what you wanted them to.

I used to think the matchlock units in shogun 2 were bad but now they control buttery smooth compared to Empire. Do yourself a favor and get Napolean (I haven't played but hear it's a lot smoother) or  Fall of the Samurai if you want guns in your total war. 

To top it all off, in my 10 hours of play I experienced FOUR crashes to desktop.  NOPE!

If you're thinking on getting a Total War game I'd recomend getting Empire, playing as France, England, or Spain will be some of the best gameplay you'll get, The Road to Independence Campaign is extremly addicting and the battles aren't as good as Napoleon: Total War but they're still okay. Well then, I hope you find the money and time to buy this amazing game.

As someone who has been traditionally partial to medieval armour, weapons, and aesthetic, I originally didn't think style of warfare in the early modern period or the "Black Powder" style of warfare prominent in the 17th and 18th centuries was particularly fascinating and appealing. This was largely due to the inaccurate portrayal of the grim realities of warfare in contemporary period works at the time. however, as a history major who became acquainted with enthusiasts, connoiseurs, and aficionados of this style of warfare. it was their presence which inspired me to take the time to learn about the politics, warfare, society, and culture of the 17th and 18th centuries. it was through my studies that I came to understand how intense the aesthetic and experience of warfare was during the early modern period of european history. most artistic interpretations by the period of warfare's contemporaries as well as much of our modern interpretations of this style of warfare in both games and films make little effort in the way of expressing the visual, physical, and emotional brutality and intenseness that many young men and seasoned veterans had to face in the early modern period. 

advancements in military technology such as those made in firearms and artillery transformed the face of warfare forever as opposed to the melee and armourcentric style of warfare that happened in the middle ages and the renaissance. Thus, with these new technological advancements came new, and might i argue, scarier and more visceral kinds of human cruelties and brutalities that made fighting and killing far in excess of the limits of the raw powers of the human body. The human element of warfare was also highly elevated in response to these new evolutions in the nature of warfare. with the advent of military drill and training, the physical and mental fitness and discipline of the soldiers of this period were arguably superior to the serjents, men at arms, archers, and crossbowmen who peopled the infantry of the medieval era. with the exception of the aristocratic knights who were trained from birth to be expert killers and equipped with the finest weapons, armour, and mounts. medieval infantry to the best of scholarly observation and research were fairely weaker and undiscplined in contrast to the line infantry and footmen of the early modern period, who were typically organized into a line of battle and were expected to depend on discipline and sheer individual courage to hold the line of battle in the face of opposing firepower. 

However, the novelty that I came to appreciate most about the warfare and military aesthetic of this time period was the surprising amount of melee and close combat that was used in this battle, with the development of the lighter, more efficient flintlock muskets and the extinction of renaissance "Pike and Shot" formations in favour of the plug bayonets and their later innovations. regiments of line infantry would often resort to close combat or melee, which would remain strategically and tactically sound both as a means to save ammunition and fight on terrain where "The lne of fire" would be a strategically unfeasable means to fight an opponent, such as the narrow corridors of an urban settlement, strategic bottlenecks like the crossing of a bridge or the breach of a fortress, or even certain narrow and uneven terrain where froming a line of attack would be impossible due to the strategic limitations of the terrain. The other occasion where close combat and melee would also remain in a position of strategic and tactical importance in this age of warfare would be through the use of cavalry. while black powder warfare would influence the strategic and tactical use of cavalry with smaller firearms such as carbines and pistols, close combat cavalry charges with "cold steel" such as sabres and lances would continue to be the weapons and tactics of choice for many, if not most generals in the 17th and 18th centuries. 

This understanding of the strategic and tactical importance of close combat and melee in early modern warfare would be enough to spark my enthusiasm for both the warfare and history of this time period. however, in coming to understand the aesthetic innacuracies of modern portrayals of medieval soldiers and warriors. i have come to realize that the rise of standard issue military uniforms is a novelty of early modern european warfare in this time period. and thus, military attire of this period was both aesthetically superior to all its predecessors from the medieval and classical periods, and would remain the alltime epitome and gold standard of military attire that would serve as the foundation and inspiration of later forms of military uniform.

Lastly, Through my personal understanding of the military expoits of the French Emperor and General Napoleon Bonaparte and his experiences leading french armies during the revolutionary and napoleonic wars. I have come to believe, taking into consideration napoleon's love for classical greek and roman military history as well as his mathematical expertise in understanding the nature of probability and calculated, strategic planning. That the individual tactics and overall military strategy of the black powder warfare of the 17th and 18th centuries centuries are largely inspired by scholarly research and understanding of military warfare as practiced by the ancient greeks and romans. The rennaissance, or the beginning of the early modern period in the 15th century was marked by an intense fascination and study of classical texts from ancient greece and rome. while originally preserved and interpreted by the literati of the roman catholic church, a growing secular interest and interpreation of these ancient texts was beginning to take prominence amongst the scholarly community of the renaissance onwards which would affect and improve all manner of life and society, and warfare and combat were no exceptions from this advancements made in the study of these antiquated texts. the organization, structure, tactics, and strategic docrines of the black powder warfare the 17th and 18th century were arguably inspired by scholarly research and interpration of greek and roman military treatises and manuscripts as well as the personal military exploits by classical greek and roman generals like Julius Caesar, Alexander the Great, and Leonidas. Both the Impact and influence such texts would have on the developments of early modern warfare would be epitomized in Napoleon's battles such as rigoli, austerlitz, and liepzig, and toulon where application of the principles behind Spartan, Macedonian, and Roman military tactics would would result in triumph for napoleon and the french empire that would result in france being the first european country to dominate europe since ancient rome. Due to the multitude and the genius of napoleon's many military victories, his battles and military exploits would continue to be studied in the presitigious setting of military academies to this very day, and the accounts of napoleons military triumphs and those of generals like him, as well as the treastises and manuscripts by military theorists of the time such as carl von clausewitz would serve as the foundational material for which all aspiring military officers to this very day continue to study as a means of developing a knowledge base for military thinking.

In conclusion to all my points. My studies of the politics, warfare, and military theory of the early modern period have opened me to chossing this game as my alltime favourite total war game. even moreso than medieval II total war, my traditional favourite of which I have spent 2000 or so hours on. For all of you who enjoy swords, armour, and melee, and hack and slash style rpg and action games, I wouldn't recommend this game to you unless you have the openness and curiousity to learn about and appreciate the political and military history of this time period.

I played the game for 31 hours, patched in full to 1.6, and played with/without DarthMod. Sorry to say: it is a buggy mess. I played all previous games except the first Shogun (played Shogun 2), all are stable after patches. The killer for Empire is the dreaded 'Ottoman bug' which ruins an otherwise fun and entertaining game (look up the bug yourself). I loved the action, the graphics, the encyclopedia of historical events, basically everything about the game - except the longgggg turn times. Some claim mods fixed the bug but I couldn't get it to work with mods and I've got technical knowledge and c++ background (tried vanilla and with DarthMod 8, 8.1). Turn times start out taking a few seconds, and within 30-40 turns it devolved into literally 8-10 minutes staring at the screen. I spend time between every turn playing guitar and staring at the screen...waiting. The bug is due to the Ottomans spamming multiple single unit armies near a certain land bridge, clogging up the AI because, for some reason, CA decided that even when AI units are not visible (and I check the box that said do not show AI movement) the AI still moves EVERY one of them, in a queue of first-in, first-out order. The bug exists in vanilla and patched. There are ways of changing the unit costs so that the Ottomans disband the units when they run out of cash, but as an adult my limited free time is to be spent actually playing games, not modding them to work as advertised. After 31 hours of play - the majority of it staring, waiting, and my frustration turned to irritation - I sadly have to call it quits. I recommend any previous CA title but this. (running on Win 7 64-bit w/GTH 970)

What's not to love about Empire: Total War.

I really like this entry in the franchise, but it has a few weak spots.

The setting: The move to a primarily firearm based era makes this Total War different from the others. While at first it is a refreshing change, it gets a little old after a while. This style of warfare relies a lot more on standing around and blasting each other with artillery and a lot less on charging into melee. Most battles play out in a similar fashion.

Naval combat: While the first addition of naval combat is exciting, it is rather slow placed. It can be tough to get the hang of, but is still fun to watch!

Campaign: This is where the game excels. The grand campaign in this iteration offers lots of new options, like rebellions, protectorates that actually do something, and a more intricate trade system. No real downsides here!

Overall, a good game. Still crashes to the desktop occasionally, so get used to hitting quicksave.

One last pet peeve. The implementation of forts is completely broken, making them a liability more than a bonus.
Empire: TotalWar is definitely far from a perfect game. But overall its a fun little game to speand your time on while not really doing much at all.

[h1]"The most broken Total War game in history"[/h1]
While the introduction of naval battles were great ideas and gun powder battles in general are great fun, I have never had a worse experience than this with any Total War game. Not even Rome II at it's release was as buggy as Empire still is today. After playing Empire for 42h I can easily say Empire Total War has the worst AI in any game of the series. 

So far I've seen the AI defending a fort by assembling all it's troops in the center the fort, allowing my men to climb the walls and kill all of them without taking a single hit.

Even deadlier for the AI's troops and yours as well is walking stairs. I can't describe how often I've seen soldiers getting off a fort wall via a staircase simply fall over and die by the hundreds. Once they reach the bottom of the staircase they just fall over, without taking any hits. Hundreds of dead bodies on a single spot. This bug wasn't even fixed in Empire's sequel/standalone addon Napoleon Total War. In fact this even happened to me more frequently there. 

This is gamebreaking and it's unbelievable how these bugs still haven't been fixed.


[i]tl;dr Many gamebreaking bugs, even years after release[/i]

Empire Total War is a strategy game set during the 1700s, which has you controlling the various armies of the time and controlling units like dragoons, cavalry, cannons and line infantry, as well as participating in fun naval combat.  You can play all the major countries of the time, such as Britain, Prussia, France and Spain, and fight in Europe, North America and India in a variety of different landscapes.  It's an absolute blast and there is a lot of replayability.  The game is enhanced greatly by mods, the best of which in my opinion is Darthmod Empire.

For fans of the Total War series, you won't be disappointed with this addition. Gameplay is exactly what you have come to expect. The only real changes that I'm aware of are the technology tree and the naval warfare aspect. Some of the mechanics with troop movement and friendly fire are a bit frustrating at times, but this might also be due to my own ineptitude. 

All in all, a very solid game. Like most of the Total War titles, games are extremely long. I frequently find myself forgetting where I left off after being AFK for a week or two, and this more or less forces me to restart to recoup my stategy. These games are extremely fun from the get go and then get a little stale as replayability loses appeal. 7/10

Easily one of the best Total War games to date. It has replayablility, in depth turn-based grand strategy, and tactical real time battles that have the sight, feel, and sound of the Age of Colonialism. 
Although it came out awhile ago, its graphics are not terrible by any means, and as you can see from my own play time:  It's a favorite.
 I also nominated this game for the "Game within aa Game" award, because it really does feel like two different games. One momment your in the cannon smoke filled fields being a Genearl and master tactician of troops, and in another you are a King:  Whose will is absolute and you have a wide range of abilities that factor your economy, your peoples opinion of you, espionage, research, infastructure, and of course building and maintaining an army (Their expensive by the way)

Only downside is that Sea warfare is kinda tricky, but the graphics and simiulations of boarding another's ship and claiming her for your own is very satisfying. ;)


Defs buy this game if on sale and if its not buy it anyways, especially if you appreciate the Total War franchise.

Empire is my all-time Total War favorite after the CA fixed the early bugs. The game is mostly well-balanced, the firearms bring an extra dimension (tactical combat phase isn't just mindless melee) and the three theatres (Europe, India, Americas) provide varied approaches to the Grand Strategy. Exchanging broadsides in naval combat is also very well done.

18th century is well represented and the different units (line and light infantry, light and heavy cavalry, dragoons, cannons, howitzers etc.) are interesting. You can play as a historical European superpower like France, Prussia, Austria, Sweden or Poland-Lithuania or choose the Ottoman Empire or the India-based Marathas. The United States has her own campaign, as well as the Native Americans. Regarding the learning curve for new players, this isn't a walk in the park but not a minute-detail micromanagement hell either.

Only serious downsides are that the AI and unit pathfinding are at times bit lacking but otherwise this is a very engaging and entertaining game. Highly recommended.

I nominated this game for the "Office Chair General Award" in 2016 Steam Awards as it is in my opinion the most satisfying world conquest game ever for us basement napoleons/caesars.

If, like me, you are partial to history, especially the history of the Age of Limited Warfare, then Empire: Total War is the perfect game for you.  There is immense amusement to be made, re-writing the history of Europe, and the game world has a wonderful periphery, in which all manner of delightful and unexpected things happen, like the Pope conquering the Ottoman Empire.  It manages to be an excellent strategy game, with levels of increasing complexity for those who would delve into them, but also a simple interface, and wonderfully easy, shallower format that allows someone to ease into the game.  I would highly recommend this to any fan of the 18th Century, or any fan of the Total War games.

A little bit of an update

The huge expansive area to conquer is amazing! While if you are a European power Europe may seem scaled down a lot in comparison to other Total War game, your focal point would be the other continents and claiming those territories, this makes for a stretched out but enjoyable game. with events and technological research to keep things fresh and not as boring, as well as trying out the different and underdeveloped countries allowing for multiple playthroughs, thats excluding the mods :D and lets not forget about the new naval battles which work fine and more involvement with ships and trade, their are so many things to talk about with this game i hope a bigger and more ambitious Empire 2 is in the making.

However one flaw i do find the game to have is the limited town growth, as no matter how big a small one you'd find will get, you will never unlock other building types which can be a bit frustrating, plus the AI being stupid which is to expect but luckily not as bad as Medieval II's gun powder units.
Nominated for the "Just 5 more minutes" award. There's so much information on every bulding and unit of the world

still holds up great graphically and gameplay wise. now is actually the best time to play it with a modern i7 and decent sized SSD. it struggled lots on older hardware and crash, especially as your empire grew. now you can take over the whole world and it's fine.

I've spent countless hours conquering the world with this game, I recommend it to anybody who loves strategy games or the time period it is set in (18th Century)
I also recommend using the mod DarthMod Ultimate Commander, which improves many aspects of the game.

After playing this game for a few hours I rate it as one the the greatest real time strategy games of all time. Equally fun if you take a hands off approach to your battles and rely on the auto resolve funstion or take control against insermountable odds and use keen strategic placement of your troups along will real time battle manuevers to outflank and crush your foes. 

Varying nations have different bonuses and starting situations. A multitude of possible alliances and backstabs are possible and achieveable by various means. Placate your population with religion, sorted diversions or military presence or victories. Utilize the same to dominate a conquered populace and/or turn them in time to your loyal followers. Infiltrate opposing countries with spies, assasinate or sabatoge as you go. Send out religious emisaries to turn populations to the one true religion. Train researchers to bolster your war technology or steal/trade it from another country.  

The Grand Campaign is amongst the best offered in any strategy game and was probably the best at the time the game was released. So many factions to conquer. So many alternative routes to take to world domination. Replayability is off the charts.

Now... the review:

Before Steam, I played the vanilla version for well over 300 hours, 99% singleplayer. For whatever reasons Total War MP doesn't do it for me like say.. Age of Empires 2 MP does.

This is my favourite game out of the Total War series, often taking the spot as my favourite strategy game in general. I love the scale of it all. One can really get satisfied by upgrading and fighting for your distant colonies! This game is HUGE! Playing the "Grand Campain" on "World Domination" mode may take 10+ hours to fully complete. The sea battles are hard, but very fun! Managing an armada is quite a task, hopefully you've done the proper research! The race against other faction's scientific clocks is on, as Empire lets one build schools and send schollarly gentlemen to research new technology!

If you're a fan of previous Total Wars, you might be overwhelmed with all the new features and mechanics, but TRUST ME it will grow on you!

If this is your first Total War game, you're in for one heck of an experience as well!

Once you see the whole mini-map one solid color, and that color is your factions color, you will share the same satisfaction I have gotten many a time from Empire!

The best addition to this game that was not present in previous Total War games is the technology tree. It perfectly showcases how advances in civil sciences were similar to a double edged sword

The next best addition is the amount of the Earth is playable.
-naval battles will be fought all along the coasts of europe and the Mediterranean, the Ivory Coast, the East Indies, and in North America.
-land is conquerable across 5 continents: Europe, Africa, Asia, North America, and South America.

So let's start with the first problem you will notice in the game, the setting
    -The 18th century is the dawn of the industrial period and falls to the enlightenment age, but playing through all 100 years and the world stays almost the same.

The next worst part of the game is the AI. Have you ever watched a movie or played a game that was so bad you enjoyed it because of how much a joke it is, well the AI is exactly like that, except the joke is as bad as your father's
-cannot embark units
-has cavalry run straight at line infantry instead of artillery
-builds militia units
-fights with trading ships
-has no clue that there are 4 more continents other than the one it is on
    
next is the combat
-every match is won based on the amount of line infantry you have
-grenadiers are useless
-cavalry becomes obsolete late game
-pray to RNGesus 

4th are the units
-all line infantry are the same except for their colors
-Great Britain, France, Spain, Prussia, Austria, Poland and Lithuania, Russia, and Sweden use almost all the same units.
-no unit variety among european factions unless you buy DLC
-auxillary units are useless
-artillery has little variety besides the ball weight and the mobility

Lastly I'll talk about the naval aspect of the game
-creative assembly has never been boating before, and it shows
-naval battles are like watching turtles have sex
-same formula for winning in land battles; the more rate ships = the winner

I have been playing Total War games since Shogun Total War, and I have to say this is probably one of my favourites!

The vanilla verison of the game had its issues, which have mostly been patched, however when combined with mods like Darth Mod the game really comes into its own. 

If you like the age of muskets, colonisation,  revolution and enjoy large scale battles with 1000's of troops on screen this might be for you.

You can be as tactical as you like, fielding small but experienced professional armies, using terrain and defensive formations to your advantage. 

Alternatively you can send out massed armies of militia and native troops to over whelm your enemy with sheer numbers and fire power. It's up to you.

Don't neglect the home front or you might find yourself putting down rebellious peasants whilst trying to fight a major power.

Empire Total War is a great choice if you have an itch for Age of Sail/Gunpowder Era game play. For those of you whom may never have played a Total War title this next part is for you.

 Total War games are a mixture of 2 common Strategy Game mechanics. You have a campaign board and you have a RTS Battle Mode. For the camapign board think Sid Meyer's Civilization, you control the empires finances, build queues and unit movements in this mode. When you go to fight an enemy force you then go into a RTS mode where the armies involved fight on a map that represents your location on the campaign board. Example, if your forces engage the enemy in a forest then expect the battle mode map to be a forest. If you attack an enemy that is blocking bridge access to the other side on the campaign board you will have to fight accross that bridge in the battle mode map if you want to win. The opposite is true if you are defending. 

You can choose to automate nearly everything in this game, wether it be taxes, building queues or even land and sea battles. This makes it somewhat easier to learn the ropes of the game as it can be a bit overwhelming at first but I would suggest going straight for the deep end and learn how to do it all yourself.

Graphically the game looks great with maxed settings.

Audio seems legit most of time but every now and again i notice that some sounds vanish only to return later just as quickly as they left.

Quick note on pacing in the game, if you are new or just havent played in a while it can seem slow to start and in some ways it truly is. Trust that patience is a virtue in the early game because when the shiiyat hits the fan it will test you.

All in all i think Empire Total War is a great game and can certainly offer you many hours of enjoyment. I recommend this to anyone who likes strategy games and wants a colonial era setting in which to strategize.

This was my first Total War game, and it really made me fall in love with the series as a whole.  What is most impressive is the campaign, with nine playable empires and the whole world map on offer, which makes planning ahead all the more important.  The long campaign spans from 1700 to 1799, giving the player the chance to establish a strong economic base (one of the most enjoyable aspects is dominating the map by the end of a campaign).  The battle gameplay is also good, with a wide range of histrorically accurate units to choose from, with lends a very strategic element to each battle, as the player has to no how to counter the troops of the opposing side; a skilled player can gain victory over a numerically superior army.  The online gameplay is solid, with only occasional lag issues.  There are only a few minor downsides. There are occassional glitches and freezes (approximately one every fifty battles), Cavalry is very underpowered, which limits their effectiveness.  They are useful against unprotected artillery and countering other mounted units, but one small infantry group can rout a far larger cavalry force.  Finally, the general, while very important, has a limited range of gameplay options; the same level of morale is offered regardless of where the general is in relation to the rest of the fighting force, as long as if the general is alive or on the battlefield.  Overall however, Empire Total War is an amazing tactical and historical experience, which I would gladly recommend to anyone.  I would give it a score of 8/10
