Going through the Total War games in order of release, I came upon a strange offspring of the series called Empire. Now mind you, in this review I will be describing both the game as it was released and patched over time, and I will cover a mod for this game that I am personally playing right now called DarthMod.

So, where to start wih this one? You are probably aware by now that the developers of the Total War series, Creative Assembly, have had somewhat of a disaster with their release of Rome 2 and have been patching it constantly ever since. From what I've read(not having played that game) most of the game breaking bugs and failures have been eliminated, but the game itself is still hardly a challenge because of the bad AI programming.

That is pretty much the case with this game, even after a substantial amount of time passed between release and me writing this. The game is still fun as hell, and there will on occasion be a challenging battle or siege where the AI might be competent.  Also, the game tends to lag a lot in drawn out battles, even with a powerful processor. As I understand, this was the first game based on the Warscape engine and it seems that the devs at the time did not master it.These are some of the biggest gripes I have with this game, and there is a host of smaller ones. In any case, the game is flawed.

But underneath all the problems and bugs and flaws there is an incredibly engrossing and rich game which takes you to imperial era of the 18th century, giving you access to 3 strategic theaters to wage war, use subterfuge, develop your resources and loads of other activities. You will build powerful armies of infantry, cavalry and artillery with which to conquer, mighty fleets of warships to control the seas and protect your trade routes or raid your enemies. The naval battles are also a hell of a lot of fun once you get used to the wind mechanics and how to fire your cannons. I strongly recommend reading a guide on naval battles if you are unfamiliar with how sailing ships work. 

All of this adds up to a very good, if inconsistent, experience. But you know what's better? Having a grand experience all the way through. If you are willing, check out DarthMod and possibly some of the submods for it. It makes the game what it was supposed to be from the start, improving the AI substantially and actually making almost every battle a real challenge. It doesn't fix some of the core game problems with the engine and due to improved graphics it can lag a bit on slower computers, but if you can run it, get it ASAP. Be warned though, it is tough. Campaign AI is much more aggressive and willing to maneuver to get what it wants, and the battle AI for naval battles will seem like Satan at first because of the maneuvers it pulls.

tl/dr: Great game, even better with mods.

I had a job to do. My country, Great Britain, had just been through a century of unparalleled turbulence: an unwelcome joining of Scotland and England; religious strife; civil wars; an executed king; military dictatorship; a populist monarch restored; and the overthrow of a second king. Less than 15 years ago, the hated Catholic James II was forced into exile in the Glorious Revolution and a Protestant monarchy restored. A short, vicious war in Ireland put paid to any chance of a Catholic Stuart restoration. Nonetheless, the exiled James Stuart has sympathisers, the Jacobites, throughout Britain. Despite - or perhaps because of - this turbulent history, Britain is an engine driving the scientific and cultural advancement of northern Europe; turmoil foils creativity.

My job was fueled by my ambition and patriotism. I was to turn my country, previously fighting internally, to face outwards across the sea. Take possession of colonies in the America's and India. Destroy the French. Create the East India Company. Destroy the French. Take the archiapelago of Meditterannean islands and turn them into naval bases. Destroy the French. Use these naval bases to invade mainland Europe. Destroy the French. Claim global domination. Burn down Paris.

I successfully did this and brought glory to myself and country in a short space of time in the 18th century.

June 11th, 1744, Venice.

Venice belongs to the Spanish Empire at long last. The rivalry between the Venetians and the Spanish over a contested Italy had spawned conflicts for decades now, and everybody is happy to see that this bloodshed is now but history. There is a problem to be dealt with though, because these lands are wanted by the bloodthirsty Austrian Empire, to the northeast. I have sent diplomats to give their sovereign the finest of our horses as a state gift, presenting myself to them as a friend. The Austrian Emperor welcomed the gift, though it was useless, for one week later Austrian soldiers sacked our minor undefended towns all over Rhineland, Lombardy, and Venetia itself. The Austrians had not only declared war: they had commited crimes they could not be forgiven of.

November 25th, 1744, Zagreb

I ordered a massive ammount of my valiant soldiers, under the command of general Juan Ortíz, to march towards Zagreb, in the region of Croatia, to free the city of Austrian rule. We saw a devastated land along the way, and the city itself had little shine, for we saw that the Austrians cared little for the Croatian people, and cared too much for the Croatian goods. The garrison at Zagreb was mediocre at best, and was quickly defeated by my ranks, as my horsemen drew their swords and shouted in victory, while the Spanish flag rose from the City Hall and all the people cheered, for they were now free of their oppressors.

December 14th, 1744, Zagreb

The rebuilding of Zagreb and all of Croatia had but begun, but the Austrian Emperor was bursting so much with anger, that he could not wait a single second, and sent a huge force directly from Viena to reclaim Zagreb. It was a force composed by thousands of musketmen, mortars, cannons and hungarian hussars, all marching straight towards the city. I ordered Ortíz to defend the city with his very own life, if necessary, because he had the finest soldiers of Spain under his command and the most vulnerable citizens under his protection. As dusk approached, a heavy rain started falling over the city and the fields around it. Ortíz ordered the citizens to take up arms and get into the buildings to have a safe firing spot, while the Spanish line infantry would dig up trenches over the city streets, forming dead ends from where they could shoot the invaders that entered the city from the north. Some men stood hiding among the trees to the west of the city to ambush any Austrians trying to come around, and last but not least, men dug up trenches on the hills to the east, hoping to shoot any climbing Austrians. To the south, artillery was positioned to give cover fire to any of these positions, with Ortíz alongside hid general's bodyguard right beside the cannon. As the men were eagerly waiting, black and yellow flags appeared over the horizon and started to approach quickly.

The battle for Zagreb had begun.

The Austrians cowardly fire incendiary bombs from their howitzers to the civil buildings of the city. Ortíz orders the citizens to move to the streets so they will not collapse with the buildings. Austrians climbing the hill take volley after volley of gunshots and start to flee. In the forest, austrians are killed by bayonets from my concealed soldiers but inside the city itself, my men are sorrounded amidst the fire and the invading forces. Taking too much casualties, the armed citizens leave their guns and run with despair, fearing for their lives. Almost half the city is filled with black and yellows, and I Ortíz tries to use the men in the woods to sorround them from behind. The tactic works, and the Austrians in the city retreat to fields on the north. As my lines reorganize themselves to fire, more austrians come out of the northern woods and organize themselves as well. Being on the open field, my men are very succeptible to the howitzers, and start losing numbers very quickly to the balls of fire. Ortíz Himself runs towards the blazing streets and falling rain, circles through the infantry lines and dashes towards the howitzers, killing the artillerists and destroying the cannons. Just as he was about to return, a line of Austrian musketmen point their guns towards his bodyguard and shoots.

Ortíz falls off his horse.
His chest is filled with blood.
He is dead.

The tears of the men are confused with the rainfall for their lost general, and they fight even harder for the Austrians had killed their precious leader. They manage to push away their attackers to the north. On the hill to the east, the men come out of their trenches to fight the Austrians at the base of the hill. The two forces meet and start fighting alongside each other. There are no more bullets, the fight is only bayonets, punches, and kicks, and the Austrians quickly see that they are sorrounded, and start to run away. The few Spanish soldiers remaining run after them, but quickly fall to the ground in exhaustion. They look back at the city, their musket in hand, the water falling through their clothes and penetrating through their wounds like it was salt. The city was blazing among all that water, dead bodies and much, much blood filled the streets, a heavy smell of gunpowder, molten steel, and burned flesh stood over the air, but the soldiers permitted themselves a timid smile.

The buildings in Zagreb were destroyed
Her fields, laid trampled
Many of her sons, dead in the middle of the streets
But her spirit was intact
Her people, hopeful
Her liberty, fortified
Her safety, guaranteed.

I give a very conditional recommend for this game. It feels that every game in the Total War series would be great games even if they only live up to half of what they aspire to be. In Empire: Total War's case, half is about right. The game is incredibly ambitious, and while it does get some things right it also leaves many fundamentals broken (though arguably these are present in every Total War game). When things are good though, the game is a thing of beauty, and there are no games quite like it. 

The good: 

- The scope of the game is immense - covering all five continents in one of the most interesting and volatile period of human history 
- The battle simulation actually feels like a simulation - cannonballs bounce as they hit the ground, spilling dirt and crushing infantry. Soldiers stationed on top of fortifications fall to their deaths when the walls they stand on lose integrity and collapse. Weapons can jam, and you can hear the distinct clicks of misfired guns 
- Sound design and animations are fantastic. The game allows you to lower the camera down to shoulder level with the solders, and you can hear the whistle of cannonballs flying overhead, the marching steps of the infantry, and see the meticulously animated reloading sequence
- The game is very, very pretty. The characters, ships and buildings are extremely detailed, and you can put the game into slow motion to see beautifully rendered explosions of the ship's powder mags, the splinters coming off ships as cannonballs strike them, and line of infantry taking turns to shoot at each other in battle 

The bad: 

- The AI, in both campaign map and battle, is extremely dumb. On the campaign map the AI likes to move units around singly, instead of combining them so that they stand a better chance of survival in case of an ambush. The AI also marches armies directly into interception range of armies more than twice its size for them to get crushed, and attacked a besieged city twice with two half stacks instead of combining both to overwhelm the player 
- In battle, the AI flounders badly, sending units up against the the player's line singly instead of moving the entire line, allowing the player to concentrate firepower and wipe them out individually in otherwise well matched battles. In addition, the AI appears incapable of using buildings and fortifications at all - when defending a settlement, instead of installing units in buildings, the AI will simply march them towards the player to have them slaughtered 
- Other curious incidents include the AI leaving his units as sitting ducks for 45 minutes while I wipe out half his force with a squad of howitzer due to my artillery advantage, charging at infantry using light cavalry, who got wiped when said infantry formed up into box formation, and placing infantry within melee distance of artillery, shooting at my infantry unit while ignoring the canister shots decimating his unit 
- The pathfinding is horrible. This is especially apparent with units on fortification. Tasked with fighting an enemy on fortification, a unit would split itself in two, with half climbing the wall while the other half attempting to walk through the gates, even though the gates are not captured. Ordering a unit on fortification to attack the enemy with the fortification cannon is a hit and miss affair, since there are no 'man cannon' order, you have to rely on the game guessing your intention, otherwise the infantry would march out of the gates to confront the enemy on the ground 
- Ordering a unit to attack an enemy is a hit and miss affair. Sometimes, when ordered to fire on an enemy that is already within range, a unit will wheel around leisurely and ready itself to fire, instead of SHOOTING THOSE BASTARDS ALREADY. Similarly, ordering a unit of 120 men to engage a unit of 60 enemies in melee will sometimes result in 60 of the 120 men breaking formation to engage the enemy one-on-one while their compatriot stand in formation like idiots instead of ganging up on the enemy 
- Artillery can be ordered to attack ground outside their range - they will try, but their shots will fall short and miss - but not to attack units outside their range. If you do, the attack fails silently, and they would revert to firing at will at units within range. Artillery also do not prioritize units properly, sometimes firing at fleeing enemies over nearby enemies that are still shooting and thus present a bigger threat 
- Artillery units cannot target to avoid friendly fire. I'm not just talking about friendly fire when your infantry is standing in front of them, but they'll hit themselves (!) when they fire at an angle. 
- Diplomacy is a joke. While the AI makes an effort at realpolitiks and recognize when the situation is hopeless, they usually does so far too late. In addition, the AI often makes completely ridiculous, such as Austria offering India a piece of Europe in exchange for a trade treaty. 
- The game is buggy. Enemy units will walk through gates which have been captured by the player, even though those games are suppose to be locked visually. A single horse would get stuck around a rock when entering the battlefield as reinforcement, making the entire unit untargetable, and thus forcing me to bring artillery to shoot at them point blank to end a battle where every other unit has already fled

The release of Empire was an utter travesty on the Total War series, and while many of the original game-breaking problems were fixed, there remain remenants of a rushed production and bad decision making, worst of which is a weak AI that does not even begin to border on logical. You will be lambasted by offers to trade your major provinces for tiny island colonies almost every turn. In battle the AI will ignore your regiments of infantry and rush through them in an attempt to attack your artillery. You will have to take almost every province of a nation before they'll decide to give you peace, so you can deal with the other four nations that declared war on your last turn. 

There are many bugs still in this game that at times greatly removes any sense of pleasure in playing it. Cavalry clipping into buildings and being stuck, some armies completely ignoring your intercepting armies and rushing around them to do nothing more than raid your farm, and artillery aims for the extreme left of a formation at all times. Simply opening the government tab sometimes greets you with a giant, orange square as a graphical glitch one would think CA would have taken the time to fix.

It is a shame because the scope of this game is great, and no one else had done a project like Empire, but that is solely what makes it playable. Had CA any competition, Empire would have failed. I would not suggest getting this game at full price, not even $20 to be frank, and warn you against purchasing this rushed shell of a game of what could have been.

They do not make Total War games like they used to unfortunately, what happened to this franchise is similar to what happened to the Heroes of Might and Magic franchise. They lost their depth when the developers put more influence on pretty pixels instead of gameplay depth and replayability. The game was enjoyable but nothing like the old ones. Buy this one on sale and it might be worth your time. I judge a game mostly by a few factors, #1 is replayability, #2 is depth, #3 is enjoyment factor, #4 Graphics. So yes, graphics are important in a game but it is not the #1 thing that makes a good game. I played many good games back in the stone age of gaming that had crappy graphics but the game was still fun and you could play it again and again and it would still hold on to it's appeal.

I've played a ton on a diffrent steam account but because i went inactive on that account it delted itself :(. Anyways, Empire Total War :D what can i say it's awesome. It feels real, not by the game itself but by what the game does, you actually feel like your in the late 1700s ruling a government. The Ships, Troops, City managment, map layout and everything is downright perfect. My only complaint is diplomacy, i kinda always wanted it to have an animated leader like in Civilization V, otherwise no complaints its also perfect. 

What does this game stand out in? 

-Combat is realistic. This game has put in so much detail in the littlest things, its just perfect. I feel like im on the battelfeild during the 1700s. 

-Weather. A game like this has weather? yes, and it goes according to season. It doesn't have weather like rain, hurricans, etc. but for every season the enviorment changes. During the summer there is no snow, during the fall snow starts to come down in the north, and in winter all the normal places that get snow during the winter have it. Spring starts to show melting everywhere and then it repeats. This took some time to do and it really deserves credit cause it makes it realistic :) 

-Nations. This game has all the most important nations, major, minor, you name it of the entire 1700s in their realistic spots on the map and with their territories already put out. That had to take a LONG time to do like seriously, it's great to see all these natons. 

What is some stuff you don't like about the game? 

Nations- With the Darthmod Empire mod you get to do allot more and i believe the game should have allowed these options from the start. Nations like the newly born United States of America should have been in the normal version of the game for you to play as during normal gameplay. I do have to complain about that.

Otherwise the game still is great on its own. I HIGHLY recommend that you buy the entire game for $17 or better yet just pay $5 for the game when it's on sale cause it's a very good stragedy game.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]
Empire Total War is a marvelous game even today! This game has one of the largest maps in all of the Total War Series, Tons of factions to play as, Pristine Ranged and meele combat and a lot more.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
[*]Great Graphics for its time!
[*]Amazing campaign mode!
[*]Huge world map!
[*]Amazing Ranged and meele Combat!
[*]Tons of factions to play as!
[*]Tons of mods to get!
[*]Great trading system!
[*]And more!
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
[*]Sieges sometimes can get a little buggy however, playable.
[*]Doesn't have a steam workshop.
[*]Naval combat is a little frusturating to new players.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
In conclusion, Empire total war is a great gane with just a few little bugs however, I reccomend this game to any total war player that like more ranged base combat like Napeloen Total War! *Notice* If you are a huge fan for more meele based combat and dont like ranged gun combat this game might not be for you.

[h1] 9/10 [/h1]

Spend longer than you would ever want to confess, micromanaging your empire, battling your enemies and conquering the globe! No other game makes you feel so powerfull and yet so frangile... a real blast!

Total War is one of the most popular and best strategy game series around. A series that has tackled many time periods and settings such as the Roman Empire, Medevial, and Greece. It is not suprising that they tried to bring the series to the ever popular 1700s European setting. While games such as Age of Empire 3 thrived in this era, Total War falls apart. 

Pros: well there really aren't any. Any thing positive I can say for this game, other games in the series do better. 

Cons: well for one, the game is HORRIBLY optimised. I can max out Total War: Shogun 2, a newer game, but even on the lowest settings this game lags... on the campaign map. That's right, this game has issues smoothly running the WORLD MAP! Admitingly, Total War's campaign maps have always been more detailed than other series, trying to make the map look somewhat like an actual overview of the real world area, but still there isn't that much going on there. This problem is even worse in combat, where even the smallest battles can slow you down. God help you if there are more than about 10 units on screen at a time. The AI is AWFUL. Not only do your opponates have no sense of self-preservation, but your own units struggle to follow even your most basic commands. Trying to get units to hide behind cover confuses them more than just about anything. Also, the whole point of Total War games is formation based combat. While this works wonderfully in the pre-gun eras, here it is painful. All you have to do is line your troops up and wait for the enemy to come to you. Thanks to the poor AI they will walk straight up to you and not even bother to flank or surround and only load their guns when they are in range of your units. This means that often times your side can get 2 volleys into them before they fire back. This basically ruins any real sense of pride in your victory because it's borderline forced apon you. You have to try if you want to lose a battle. However, things are differnet in the world map. Here, your enemies watch you, and do a good job of taking undefended bases. This is the only time the game feels like it truly is a Total War game. Unfortunatly, it is drug down by making the diplomacy system laugable at best. Does a country hate you? Don't worry, all you need to do if gift them 10000 gold or so and they'll love you! Diplomacy has always been the weakest part of Total War games, but here it doesn't even really count as diplomacy. It really feels like you're in preschool and some kid hates you so you give him a gummybear and now you're friends. It's pathetic in every sense of the word. On TOP of all this, the game is broken, with units glitching through walls, units randomly not shooting (even when they have ammo and can hit their targets), and sometimes just ignoring your commands. 

TL:DL- Total War is an amazing seires, don't let this awful game trick you into thinking otherwise. Do yourself a favor and pick up Shogun 2 or Rome 1. I've tried many mods and even worked on it myself and in the end it's still a broken mess. It's not quite the Sonic '06 of strategy, but it isn't too far off from that.

I want to give this game a thumbs up, but after multiple revisits on and on off steam. After patching fixed most bugs, and mods filled the gaps left by campaign features. It still just falls short. The only thing this game has beyond the other total wars is ambition. With -The Americas, Europe, India, and four ocean trade arenas the campaign map is a sprawling magnificent thing. It isn't quite the global total war game I'd always wanted but it's the closest they have ever come in scope. 

However, the battles don't play as well as the Fall of the Samurai would manage for Shogun 2, the campaign doesn't have the flow of later titles, or the tight focus of the earlier ones. All and all the game is the awkward middle child of the series, and doesn't benefit from it. Even if you install it and never encounter a bug, which seems unlikely even after the wave of patches - you will still likely find the game to fall short of its ambition. Unless you are just absolutely in love with the era I'd recommend other Total War games - or even the Europa series.

Firstly, I have been a long time fan of the Total War series and have played since Rome II and every subsequent title since. I can say that this expansion is easily within my top three favorite TW games. This game has a few typical flaws found in earlier TW games, but overall is a solid experience. I have a few personal preferences that some might find annoying, I shall still list these in the Pro's column as it's my review and I'll do what I want. 
[u] Pro [/u] 
1) Diverse faction choives: TONS of factions to choose from, each with its own unique advantages/disadvantages. For example, the mryiad includes; the Ottoman Empire, Great Britain, The Iroquis Confederacy, and The Maratha Confederacy (to name a few). Unlike many TW games, the units are diverse and not merely rewraps of the same one unit. 

2) Awesome Economy!: At first I struggled to find a decent balance between my army maint. and income level when I first started out. However unlike most TW games, where the economic balance can seem daunting to beginners, I found this title to be pleasently forgiving. For veteran players, be prepared to make a TON of money, especially through trading. I can not express how paramount trading in this TW title. One note that many will find annoying, to upgrade your farms, mines, etc. you must click on each indv resource that is located around the map. For example, in Shogun 2 your farms are located winthin your city, along with any extra resources, in Empire only your military/admin. building is and you are forced to keep track of literally dozens of different resources. I like this personally, simply because it is cool to see your empire become more prosperous. 

3) Tons of land: Like tons, three different theatres; India, Europe and America. This means a lot of gameplay and conquering, oh the fun you'll have. 

[u] Cons [/u]
1: Stupid AI: The AI, like in many earlier releases, is not the most adpet at military combat. While sometimes I have been throughly suprised, I have never truly been threatened as I have in similiar titles playing on the hardest difficuly. Sadly, some of your major powers, like the Maratha Confederacy over time lose the ability to fight advanced troops like the Europeans. 

2: Lag/Crash: I have yet to play a game through without experiencing three crashes. Some games have taken me 50+ hours and to be consistently crashing gets old fast. I will say it is nothing to pre-patched Rome II. 

Consensus: If you are even a remote TW fan, then buy this game. You will have loads of fun and many hours to frolic across the world.

Firstly, I should say, I really like Empire:Total War. For the longest time, I considered Rome 1 the best Total War game as it was simple to grasp & you could focus entirely on the battles, manage cities or both. 

Empire:Total War was a purchase for a new strategy, I needed a new challenge. The introductory campaign was short & got the basics of tactics & control across well, but Empire:Total War is all about it's Grand Campaign, which is simply to conquer a set number of states or cities by a certain year. It's about 200 turns away from the start, plenty of time, but not so much you can be overly complacent.

The great elements of the Total War games are present; watching individual men fighting it out on the battle field, huge campaign areas (Actually, Europe, India & America are all major theatres), the very Civilization Game trait of encyclopedic entries on buildings & units & bitter enemies who are actually bent on destroying you. Empire adds naval battles, scientific research, Gentlemen who can duel with each other & the three areas to do battle in.

Unlike most of Empire's detractors, I enjoy the naval battles, because it forces you to think as a naval commander would have, which is very different to how a commander of land based armies thinks, & so requires a flexible, adaptable mind. For me, being forced to switch from commanding land-based forces, to the mind set of naval command & then back again is a chellenge for the RTS gamer in itself, never mind the battles themselves. The era of muskets & cannons is a nice change of pace from the previous ancient eras of the Medieval & Rome games.

I've completed it twice & racked up well over 200 hours at the time of writing & that is simply because I was always planning my next move, be that war & conquest, or consolidation & development, & I wanted to know if I had out-thought my enemy or mustered a large enough force to take the various objectives I'd set myself.

The only flaw in Empire specifically that really grates is the occasional, sometimes regular, crash to desktop that is well known about & you soon get in the habit of saving often, just in case. In fact I once lost several hours of effort after a crash.

The other flaw is a typical Total War failing; the AI. It does lack serious tactical nous. It never lines up it's forces in (what I think) to make the best use of the units it possesses & is happy to throw units at you with no subtlety at all. Sadly, the Total War AI has always seemed to be a generation behind the games.

That said, I really like Empire:Total War. Days & days of continuous strategic thinking can be invested & I found myself considering my next move in my mind on the way to work on several occasions. 

Recommended.

This game takes place in the colonial era. So guns play a rather large role in this, and because of the era the guns are mostly single shot muzzle loaders. There are also melee infantry, hoursemen (both armed with fire arms and melee weapons) , and artillery of varying caliber. 

Landscape is very important in this game because of the surplus of ranged units. Hight as in most games will help your ranged units and slow the advance of melee infantry. Artillery is also helped by being put on hills and the like.

In all honesty melee is not as important in this game as in others. But melee troops are still very useful. Because most units are ranged a melee unit can very quickly destroy their moral or the unit in general. But this goes the same both ways because of the ranged unit being well ranged. So melee are best for ambushes or holding walls.

One of the cons i mentioned above is that moral seems really fragile. Units can brake in a mater of SECONDS. This would be ok if it was mere cannon fodder but even the most elite of units can be broken after one or two volleys of fire then at other times they charge though no problem. The moral system seems unstable and inconstant.  -1 point 

As mentioned above all the factions are relatively balance because they share alot of units with small changes. The only faction that is at both a disadvantage and an advantage is the Indian nations. Because they are over all more stealthy they are good for ambushes, they also have better melee units from the start of the game, but their range is a lot lower then the European nations.

The online is very laggy if more then two players are involved. This is rather common in total war games. So unless playing 1 on 1 online or playing though LAN i would recommend not putting your hopes into online -.5 points
A small complaint i also have is the lack of online campaign. Many other total war games both before and after have this feature.

As mentioned above the unit to unit comparison is very rock paper scissors. But many strategy games are like this and with proper strategy and high ground advantage it can be changed.
so because you can counter it I think it evens out.
so over all i think it is a 8.5/10

"Empire Total War" as each of the  "Total War" game series is recommendable producing embedded in colonial times. If you like any game in the series, this title will certainly give you a lot of joy.

Creative Assemblies most ambitious project to date. The concept is simple, total World War set in the 18th century. It's absolutely fucking awesome. March your armies and now NAVIES across the various continents/oceans and expand your empire.

Gameplay is solid as you can expect from CA (up until Rome 2). A solid turn-based empire builder coupled with RTS battles. Special mention to naval battles, this was the first time CA decided to really focus on the ocean as a battlefield; as such there's some lack of depth to the actual strategy. But, if watching a few 122 cannon 1st rate ship-of-lines decimate a full fleet of sloops doesn't make you feel all warm and tingly inside, than I don't know if anything will.

To date, my favorite Total War game. I pray for Empire 2.

kindly looks over the battlefield and smiles, the flanks are secure, the cannons are wailing away, your ally is holding their side, and your abushes are working. At this point you believe it is all in the bag and that the enemy general should simply hand in their formal resignation to their monarchg immediatly and then be killed for treas9on and cowardess. 

You sit back and think 'soda' you go to your fridge and get a pepsi still smiling until you see your screen.

 Your ambushes have been killed, your allys line is shattered, and your cannons have had a firm horse charge up the ass. Being the quick tactictian you first look for the cause. Obviously it was your absence and your allys incompetence, but you look deeper, how did your incompetant ally get broken that quickly when they were safe before hand? 

after a few seconds of searching the battle field you see what has caused this, one unit of Indian war elephants flanked him and then went beserk on his anus. You sigh and quickly send a few men to kill this threat.

Next would be how your flanks became exposed enough for a quick cavalry blitz onto your cannons, your mouth drops open as you see the tiny hole in your line infantry, a hit and run. After you close this hole you turn your attention to how your ambushes got thwarted. 

You knew that the ambushes were temporary but you did not know the enemy would single them out and kill them vicously. Your eyes dart over the area that they were in, seems to your quick glance that the enemy had used light artys with some scout cavalry to do this, you send 1 units of scout cavalry to look for this.

In the meantime your units have murdered the elephants, HUZZA. your incompetant ally reforms his now rather small line, you order him to march foward. He says that might not be a great idea with the mens moral low, you insist that he goes in for the glory of your mother country. He sighs and moves his small rabble of troops forward. 

You scouts have found the enemy artys and to your great pleasure they seem unguarded. You keep your scouts in cover and sneak them closer. you decide that YOLO does apply to cavalry charges and send them straight for the poor bastards. SUCESS, much rejoicing was done in the scout cavalry unit, they only lost half of their men! a sacrafice well worth it.

you get a skype call from the enemy, you are now smiling for you believe you can gloat for you victory. you answer and begin with, "so now we both have no art"... your enemy is angry and exclaims that his mother country is better than yours, in disgust you kick him out of the call and focus on killing his troops with no rhyme or reason.

Suddenly the silence is broken by your mens screams of terror and pain, you look at your main line and your enemy just dropped gas on your whole clump of troops. The enemy mortars hiden so well at the back of them map are now pounding your troops with gas. Angered by this act of cruelty you send all cavalry units to deal with this threat. 

You hear the whinying of your cavalry dying, more bloody Indian war elephants have appeared in mass and are having a mass bouty call on your cavalry. Between the gas and the elephants your men have been slaughtered. about 5 squads remain, you reform these precious troops together in some woods where your devilish enemy cannot see them.

3 skirmisher squads (two of which are out of ammo), one tenth of a heavy cavalry unit, and a random bunch of canon opperators who had fled after the horse charge who decided to stop fleeing. Pondering for awhile you come up with a plan to destroy the enemy. 

sending your units through the woods you watch sympathetically as your ally is murdered by the enslaught of gas and elephants. He retreats after killing half of the elephants. He regroups his one unit with your group of lonely vaganbonds exclaimg that you told him to go forward and that you got him killed.. honwstly you dont really care, you congragulate him on killing half the elephants and tell him to buck up for the mother country. He bucks up, you then look at his one unit of sharpshooters which had been using melee during the whole battle and had not fired a single shot. Although this is stupid and you feel like you hsould chide your ally for his continual incompetance you realize this could be useful, you tell him to follow you.

You reach the elephant killing ground and send your two dud skirm troops up on melee mode, as per usual the elephants appear and charge, you tell your ally to use his sharps to fire. elephants begin to die in droves. in the meantime your cavalry units are probbing those damned mortars so hard. The enemys general begins to run across the map trying to make a wild goose chase. A signle satisfying round of cannon fire is heard as your mishmashed canonners fire the last shoot. THE PERFECT HIT, your twit of an advisor announces that the enemy general is nowinfact dead, a fact that you saw an enjoyed very much so. With this victory the enemy elephants evacuate the premises and the enemy has been slain.

Just another day in the life of a master strategist
10/10 would have my time wasted by dumb friends not being competant enough to hold their line vs one elephant again

Do I recommend this game? Yes.

This game is my favorite of the series. Seeing your calvary charge in and the enemy general become the world's first man to the moon is a very gratifying experience. The siege game play is mediocre and buggy but the full out land battles are the best of any series. The naval battles are also well done, I mostly make big fleets and autoresolve them, because I am not that good at them. My best campaign I have done was where I conquered the entire Islamic world, converted everyone to Protestantism and saved the Campaign as "George W. Bush" The thing is, with this huge of a map, you can do anything to that scale and volume. With the other Total Wars, religion doesn't matter, with this game it really does, and can be the difference between a happy people, and a rebellion. Another great feature in this game is revolutions. It adds so much depth and fun to the game. (When I become the Republic of France I think I had a lot less bloody revolution.)  I recommend this game completely.

This has got to be the weakest Total War title I've ever bought. 

I like the era, it's just that there isn't much strategy involved, it's pretty easy to just keep maneuvering your units into better firing positions. The fact it's the gun powder era isn't the problem, I've played Shogun 2 Fall of the Samurai & had a lot of fun, this however just doesn't play out well at all. It might just be that the setting doesn't interest me as much as a Japanese one, and the fact that there are little to none melee units to allow for more strategies.

The naval combat however is a blast. I definatly had a lot of fun playing naval battles. The ones on Empire are really a lot of fun, naval strategies is usually my weak point too.

But overall, in my opinion, the game is a bore. I'll keep trying to play it to try to find some enjoyment out of it, but I doubt I will, and will most likely return to another Total War game. - I'm gonna put the review as not recommended, but if you really like the era, & wouldn't enjoy the more older fighting style Total Wars, then I'd recommend Empire to you.

Sidenote: I know I've only played four hours, but I'm finding it seriously boring.

The period in which it is set I find very interesting and the wide range of units you can use in combat (late game) makes the battles more interesting. However, the battles feel very slow and the AI could be better.

The diplomacy system is probably my least favourite part of the game as the AI are not very flexible and it is very difficult to get a deal out of them, nothing peturbing them unless you stand outside their last region with an army Napoleon himself would have been proud of. 

My favourite part of the game is the campaign map itself, spanning Europe and North Africa, the Middle East, India and the Americas (or at least most of it). I would have liked the game to incorporate more of the map as regions to be controlled rather than have the rest of the known world as trade theatres. 

It is very enjoyable to play the game with most of the available nations, however, access to minor nations does not come with the vanilla game so I would get an all factions mod to enhance your experience. The Warpath Campaign is also a fun DLC worth the buy. 

For someone who is looking to get into strategy games, this is a good starting point. If you are looking for something with better battles I prefer the older Total War games of Rome and Medieval 2. If you are looking for a game which solely focuses on campaign strategy I would recommend a Paradox game, i.e Europa Universalis. Even if you do get one of the other games, this is still a great addition to have.

Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

I'm revisiting this game after taking a break for a couple years and now I remember why I stopped.  This game should be pretty awesome.  

Pros:  It's one of the few strategy / RTS games that tackle this time period and specifically focus on the American revolution.  Despite what others say, the units make sense since there was lots of a trade and conquering - you should have the ability to have the same technology through and through.  Also, if it wasn't balanced, the British would just win every game.  But...

CONS: So many.  This game is broken.  First off, the improvements are largely annoying and require 10 minutes of reading to figure out what they do.  The AI will randomly declare war on you which is just not realistic, a common mistake in strategy games.  Advisors/scientists/agents etc are a good idea but in this case they don't clearly do much of anything, window dressing.  Including India etc but then completely ignoring Africa (probably out of political correctness) - seriously though, the colonies wouldn't exist the way they did without that trade route, even as horrific as it was.  But colonists can magically sail to India - right!

You could look past all of this and just do battle and have a great time. That's if the battle system worked.  The AI on both sides is laughable.  Most of the time they sit around.  Even your units that you order, they just sit there.  Sometimes if they are engaged, they will stop and just get slaughtered.  Sometimes an enemy will run through their lines (in retreat) and they just sit there.  Like " oh, that's weird, there goes the enemy, oh well".  Often the enemy will just sit out in no where or in side castle and not do anything.  You could be winning and your army will lose confidence and run away.  You could masterfully out maneuver a powerful enemy and you should win but then you don't because your guys that are winning get scared???    

This should be a 2.99 game.  Or they could fix it but it's probably too late.  I recall the early Total War games being a lot more solid.

Empire, the first time we all got to the see the dream killing warscape engine.  For those of you looking for a great total war video on its many problems I recommend Dr. Reynold Sanity on youtube.  If you can stand Australian cynical and somewhat offensive humor he makes a lot of great points.  Nails it on the head.

For the price I would pick the game up but just watch your calavary chase after a routed unit and yea.....  Watch as the entire unit chases one man while the others run in the opossite direction and then just sit around.  Even after uncountable patches this game is still rather messy.  The AI while no longer creating armies of 7 cannons and a single skirmisher (not all the time) is a bit better, they are still pretty bad even by total war standards.  On the plus side they will form large fleets and armies.  Id ignore the campain all together.  It culminates in fighting a British army who only buys native horse musketmen who are the best guys you want to gaurd a fort and man the wall.  

Random agent spawning is frustrating as well.  Still if you like the time period get it or napoleon.  Stay away from Rome 2.  While many praise shogun 2 for its polish it is still hurt by the warscape engines lack of collision detection and only allowing 1vs1 melee.  Enjoy watching your men circle a single unit and get cut down one at a time.  

For the last great melee total war you want medievil 2.  Although Shogun is pretty solid.  They just need to really overhaul or just go back to the old engine with better looking models.

Still have to recommend.

NO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR CO-OP / MULTIPLAYER CAMPAIGN!!!!!

I bought two copies of this game for the sole purpose of playing co-op campaign with my girlfriend. After we downloaded the whole thing, we learned that Creative Assembly has taken the co-op mode and locked it as some sort of "beta test". The only way to get access to this "beta test" is to Email Sega and beg for one.

So I did. Sega e-mailed me back a week later and told me "tough luck, we're not giving you an unlock code for the co-op mode". So basically this game HAS a functional co-op mode, it's just locked up in some steam repository somewhere.

Honestly, I feel pretty ripped off right now. Hopefully this will help someone else avoid the same pitfall.

First of this is a long review but this is nothing but the truth about this game. I saw empire and i am kinda new to the total war franchise. i saw total war empire and i thought it would be a pretty decent game. I look up reviews on the game and sadly i saw a lot of hate. Now that was a long time ago and it has been a couple years since the game came out so i thought i would give it a go hoping all the bugs would be patched. I was wrong.......
The game is a mess still after all these years! I thought they would fix the AI and all the bugs but nope! The AI are awful just a disaster. The AI run straight and run away from your troops and dont even attack.  I spent an one hour playin ghtis game and I had to quit because the battle were so boring. I think the civil war is awesome and really cool but not like this when all the troops wont even attack and im standing there with one unit and still win the war because the army doesnt attack me. 
Next the game is so bad it hurts to play the game. The map is a wreck, you get so much men to start out with so you can take over the cities right next to you and demolish them like no problem if they even let you blow down the doors since the cannons dont like moving after you shoot something and decide to shoot a hill instead of moving and attack the gates. The gameplay is so basic on the campaign map and doesnt give you those heart pounding moments like you have on medieval 2 or shogun 2. You start out with like 5 alliances and those alliances wont even help you. Instead they will just sit back while im getting my ass kicked by the french. I signed a treaty with you to help me not sit around and watch my city fall to some other faction you are also fighting! Next when you get higher in level it takes five hours just for all the factions to take there turns. Ive watched youtube more then i was playing the game waiting for my turn to come. 
The concept is great rewriting history and not let america gain its independance or ally with america as the british and go crazy and fight the british or something. I was impressed with how much they gave a lot of detail on the battle grounds with the little stuff like rocks all over the place, broken down walls for your men to take cover behind while there firing bullets, forests to hide and set up ambushed and flanks on the enemy. The total war series does a fantastic job with units and how many units there are and how you can get some epic fights that take a long time like how it was back then. Sadly this game is missing so much that im actually sad that this is my first total war game i didnt like. I am still a big total war fan and will get all the games but empire was so bad and were missing so many key factors to make this game a good game and instead made this bad and not fun to play. Get shogun 2 or medieval 2 and lets hope that they will make a fun civil war game. Hope they do great concept just bad game. Ill be waiting sega! Make medevil 3 first ;)

This game is impossibly broken still, after all these years... The AI makes little sense most of the time, but by far the worst are the siege battles. Most  battles they sit outside my walls refusing to attack, only occasionally sending one or two units forward to die. This means your game session has what basically comes down to 20-minute pauses every single time someone sieges your cities, while you sit there fast-forwarding...

Equally annoying is the RNG auto-resolving battles. It doesn't matter at all how large your force is or by what margin you could win if you fought the battle yourself; you can easily end up losing 1000 troops to a 300-strong enemy force if the RNG gods demand it!

To top it off there are actually performance issues on my 2-month-old and very powerful new PC. This COULD have been a good game, but is badly let down by its stupid AI. This has completely turned me off ever buying another Total War game...

I had played Rome TW (brilliant) and Medieval 2 TW (also brilliant) for a good few years before trying Empire.  I was unsure whether the radical transition in technology would still offer gameplay I found interesting which is why I put it off for some while.  The RTS battles are indeed completely different and took a while to get used to but the learning curve itself was very enjoyable and it doesn't take long to get used to the different fighting style.

The large campaign map, while daunting at first, is the perfect next step in a TW game and there is great satisfaction to be had in nuturing a faction from humble begginings to a mighty empire.

The sea battles are very fluid and surprisingly realistic for The Creative Assembly's first attempt (I have not tried Napoleon TW, not sure how the two compare on this front).

My only issue with Empire TW is that there is a step away from the intricate historical detail shown in previous titles.  Rome TW and Medieval 2 TW were both very educational in a passive, subliminal kind of way.  It was almost impossible not to learn about the time period and this is something I loved.  Empire TW does not have this to quite the same extent (still above and beyond most other strategy titles) which is not likely to be an issue to most as I imagine most aren't even interested in this factor (maybe I need to get out more?).

Anyway, this game is an impeccable title in a brilliant francise.  I picked this up together with Shogun 2 TW in an offer around £7 and if this is available for a price under £15 it is well worth it.  Even if you are not a fan of startegy games, picking this up when on offer is an absolute must.  

Oh, and try Rome TW and Medieval TW as well!  Good day!

Empire for the sale price was in my opinion a damn good buy, It defiantly adds plus points for value, I’m not sure I would have been happy if I paid full price for this when it first came out though. There are a few bugs and glitches that do make for a laugh but honestly after this long I would have expected them patched out.

Some bugs I have encountered so far include my troops refusing to stand down or hold a line, and this really annoying one where when you try to move groups of troops at the same time some will just walk off into the void, the target line for their positioning is nowhere near where you clicked and often in a completely opposite direction, meaning you have to micromanage your troops when you shouldn’t have to, it kinds of breaks the fun of commanding an army when you have to look at each person and tell them…hey you go there, you over there, you follow him etc.  

This game is heavy on forward planning and strategy, it is important to move your troops into strong positions and either advance on the enemy or wait for them to come to you. There is also the world map from which makes different style of play, this is fun as you can engage in diplomacy and lay siege to forts rather than have to play each battle if you don’t want to (though you can engage each one if you choose). 

The ship combat is fun and has lots of different weapons and tactics to employ in order to gain the advantage, although the path route problem sometimes rears its ugly head again so you end up micromanaging each ship, and even then you have to keep an eye on it to make sure it is doing what you want. 

The setting is in the colony era for America and I have to say always one of the more interesting historical periods, there is a lot of lore about all different unit types, the battles themselves and the ships of which I have a good interest.

If you are into strategy, or history or both then this will probably interest you, I would pick it up on sale though as paying more than £10 for this would be a mistake in my opinion. 

I’ll definably be taking more of a look into this and may update this once I have tried the grand campaign out.

Empire: Total War is a fantastic RTS that spans the years 1700 - 1799. Through its endless conflicts with other nations, economies, and even rebel factions, Empire: Total War brings the player to the turbulent times when empires grew and failed. In this case, however, it is up to the player which faction they will pick, and through their actions, whether that faction will succeed or fail. Anyone who is an avid RTS player should strongly consider Empire: Total War as their next buy.

[h1]Score: 9/10[/h1]

Empire Total War:
What a game. What a serie. 

For those who missed this long and legendary train, you will have to know that the romance with this serie started in the year 2000 with Shogun Total War. A complete wargame where you could conquer Japan with an army of samurai or japenese warrior monks. And what a show it was at the time.

Empire Total War is the dignified successor from 2009. Forget Japan, now, it is time for the American continent, Europe, North Africa, Asia... Forget the Noble, proud and fierce samurais. You will have to make do with line infantry armed with muskets. 

As usual, it is turn based strategy where you decide where to move your units, choose the building to build, recruit troops. Mixed with real time strategy and tactics. Do not forget. Battles are won before the battle. This is real strategy. Once the enemy is at your doors, you fight with the army you already have, not the army you want.

Naval battles are not forgotten. You wont be able to act blaze and cool with these beauties. You will enjoy watching the crew running around while the ships are under enemy fire. And forget esthetics. Naval battles are extremely interesting. Will you use brutish firepower to win the day? Or will you use speed and agility? You will have to mind the battle morale of your men, as battle can destroy their will to fight faster than he can destroy their bodies. 

Will you use cannon balls to destroy their hulls and canons? Or will you use other munitions to destroy sails and crew? Will you risk a boarding action to add swords and light arms to the canons? Or will you rather see their ships sunk forfeiting the prizes for captured vessels?

I will be up to you to decide.

Here are a few features you have to know about:
- Scientific research: Choose the technologies you want to research first. Do you want baionett on your rifles to see you infantry survive more often in meele? Or do you want farming equipment to boosts revenue and population growth? Better artillery maybe? 
- Diplomacy: Make trade arrangements with some countries. Make vassals, negociate technology exchanges. 
- See your troops gain experience gunning from a battle to another. Your soldiers will be prouder (less prone to morale break) and deadlier (faster reloaded, stronger defense abilities).
- Hire generals and see your actions on the battlefield affect their skills.
- Hire from a a large choice of different units. Do you want to fight in the open with line infantry or do you want to skirmish with light infantry from a far. Do you want elite units or can you make do with cheaper to maintain militias? Cavalry and artillery are not forgotten. From mortars to cannons, from melee infantry to Dragoons. Do you want exotic units? Capture far away lands and hire special units of mercenaries and introduce their deadly skills to your enemies nightmares.
- Every structure and unit have page with statistics and historical data. You will learn a lot playing this game. The experience will definetely make your richer.

There are so many features to list... Anyway: This game is a must have for every strategy lover. You will see the hard work of the developpers and their attention to details. And following our "medieval ideology" they deserve our full support and it would be a shame to miss to explore their work. Kudos to the makers of this great game. 

ALERT: Not all Total War Serie are worth your money. Empire Total War is not an exception. But as every game is unique. We advise every consumer to gather intelligence before spending a penny. Your money is not only the access to the game. It is a message, an economic vote. If you buy something, you send the message that this product is worth buying. Be reasonnable. And nobody is rich enough to be able to afford bad products. A lot of good products are dying because of lack of ressources. Be advised.

I have mixed feelings about this game and its sequel, Napoleon.

On the one hand, they explore a time period (1700-1815) that's sadly neglected in games. It's a rich and fascinating epoch that includes the rise and fall of huge empires, the first global conflicts like the Seven Years War, the intellectual and cultural revolution of the Enlightenment, the shift from an age of highly-regulated "limited warfare" to massive armies based on conscription, the birth of the United States, the French Revolution, and so on. ETW spans the entire 18th century, and had the potential to be a grand-scale masterpiece.

In some ways, it delivers on that promise, especially with the help of mods (Darthmod is an absolute must). It has a huge campaign map that spans three continents, naval battles, land battles with thousands of infantrymen slugging it out to the accompaniment of artillery fire and cavalry charges, streamlined diplomacy, and a complex tech tree. Wars in ETW have a distinctly 18th-century flavor to them: colonial conflicts turn into battles for global mastery, while coalitions of great powers form intricate webs of alliances. The modded AI puts up a good fight, and will take over your colonies and wreck your trade if you're not careful.

But the world in Empire and Napoleon just doesn't feel as vibrant and alive as it did in Rome 1 and Medieval 2, which preceded ETW. In Medieval 2, your faction leader and his/her heirs were playable characters, as were merchants, diplomats, assassins, priests, and so on. There were crusades, marriages, heretics, and the Pope to worry about, and managing your settlements had some real depth to it. Each faction felt unique thanks to the voice-acting and a rich variety of specialty units. There were world-changing events like the Mongol invasion and bubonic plague.

Most of that is gone in Empire. Your faction leaders are almost invisible, relegated to a "Government" screen, and only give some abstract bonuses to things like unit upkeep. Diplomats, merchants, and settlement-building have been pretty much "streamlined" out of the game entirely. There are no game-changing events like the Roman Civil War or the Mongol Invasion to liven things up in the midgame. 

Factions feel identical. It doesn't matter if you're playing as Prussia, France, the Ottoman Empire, or Great Britain; all factions have the same units (line infantry and a few flavors of cavalry and artillery), without any real strengths or weaknesses. The only difference is your starting position.

Maybe the biggest letdown is the impact technologies have on your faction. I think it would have been brilliant move to have industrial and Enlightenment advances give you economic boosts at the expense of public order (workers' uprisings / strikes, upper-class coups and revolutions). After all, this is what happened in history. But instead, the "clamor for reform" penalties are so slight as to hardly make a difference. Researching Fire by Rank makes a bigger impact on the game than Utilitarianism or The Rights of Man, or industrial technology that would have destroyed older crafts or uprooted peasants.

ETW also does nothing to model the historical problems faced by huge empires of the time. Constant wars and over-expansion are encouraged; there's no penalties on public order as long as you're winning. In reality, though, even a successful 18th-century war could leave a nation spent and destabilized: the American Revolution was caused by the costs of Britain's victory in the Seven Years' War, and in turn the French Revolution was caused in part by the costs of aid to the United States. It would've been great to see a risk/reward factor in place - expand at the risk of uprisings at home and abroad. This could have led to a more elastic mid/late game, and would have added an extra dimension to strategy. In Medieval and Rome, you really feel like you're traversing an entire era of human history; in Empire, a hundred years pass, but the world hardly seems to change at all.

Finally, ETW and Napoleon both lack some of the extra polish and flavor that earlier games had. Unmodded, the soundtrack is dull and repetitive. The lack of period music is just baffling to me, and the voice acting is stale and leaves much to be desired. Factions, units, and settlements feel copy-pasted; it's all the same, just with slightly different coats of paint. And even though the battles feel authentic, both games have a toy soldier vibe to them; they lack the grit and brutality of the other entries in the series.

After several hundred hours, both Empire and Napoleon feel like a letdown. They're not bad at all, and they're worth playing just for a chance to explore a neglected historical period. But every time I play them, I can't shake the regret that they could have been so much more.

Despite a few minor chinks in its armour, Empire: Total War is an improvement over Medieval II in every conceivable way. Its campaign is larger, more tactical and engaging, while the improved AI ensures that real-time battles and siege warfare are more challenging and thrilling than in any previous Total War installment. Even by the standards of the series, Empire: Total War is epic. It takes the combined real-time and turn-based strategy, and pushes it out into the eighteenth century in style. It's bigger, and it has a hell of a lot more bang.

After reading many reviews and checking scores for this game, I decided to purchase it. It sounded like a game I would be very interested in, reminding me of older games I grew up with (Steel Panthers, Robert E. Lee, Lords of the Realm, etc.). However, it has been a big disappointment. I find the battles hard to control and the non-battle game play to be confusing and not very user friendly. Unfortunatly, this game has ruined the series for me and I will not be trying ther others.

Ugh, such mixed feelings on this game. The problem with pretty much all the total war games is that they do some things really well, and other things really poorly.

Empire is not really a bad game, and I kind of have to recommend it given that I certainly got well more than an hour of entertainment for each dollar I spent. I would probably recommend Medieval II over it if you are looking to get into the total war game, as it's probably the best of them in terms of design.

The worst aspect of Empire is the building management. Everything is strewn all over the place, and you have to spend a bunch of time finding each building site in order to upgrade anything. This kinda sucks in an empire building game, which this pretty indisputably is. All the other total war games get this right with varying degrees of success, but here Empire just fails horribly.

The best part of Empire is that it is probably the best balanced of the TW games. There is no overpowering faction you can just dominate with. This is sort of a mixed bag, because it is achieved by all the units being nearly identical, but it does make the game an actual challenge on higher difficulties.

All in all, there are lots of good things about this game, and if you play Paradox games then you will probably enjoy it. If you are new to the series, then I'd really recommend a different title as Empire is the most frustrating of the bunch to play.

The only Total War game I didn't like.

The game is definitely worth checking out. I really like various historicaly based detailes poping up during gameplay, which are also nation specific. Great touch.
Battle rules are a little different than other total war games, mostly due to firearms usage. 
Empire has different way to use regions. Beside the capital city there are towns which develop over time and can be used to increase happiness in region, income, convert to different religion, or build research facility. Those towns can be raided and damaged.

Cons:
Very limited usefullnes of agents. there are 3 types of agents and each has 1 or 2 actions which you might find usefull. It could have been more developed.
Diplomacy options are very limited from my point of view, and I have not noticed any specific value in terms of victory conditions (allies, portectorate).
Battle placements. Chosing a place of the battle on campaign map has little value as the area is poorly reflected on battle map. I think it is a breat loss.
Additional battle fortifications are rarely ever available and sometimes have weird consequences eg. artilery after fortifying cannot be moved and even change of angle is very limited. It certainly does not look like it should.
I have also missed Total war encyclopedia which would be very useful.

Overall I think the time period the game is set in is quite interesting and game is fun. Some things can be changed and improved by mods, which are missing on steam but do not doubt those are available.

First of all, this is my very first experience with the Total War franchise. So, as a noob and as not having any convictions about the game going in or any kind of nostalgia toward the previous titles, my opinion on Empire is one removed from any "fanboy-isms" or any kind of on-going irritations with the series. Second of all I didn't have any deep pre-conceived ideas about what I was going to get when I started playing the game and was only interested in the concept and the overall experience I would have over few weeks I guessed I would spend playing it.

So from the time I began to play Empire until now 100 hours later while I'm writing this review I can say that it impressed me thoroughly the entire time I was playing it. The game had a depth that I hadn't seen or expected from the campaign map and I began to find myself pouring over my taxes and the constuction of buildings in the provinces that I was beginning to dominate. The time spent not being in battle felt even more important than the battles themselves and the relationships you need to have with the computer controlled nations ultimately dicatate the length of time that it takes to control all of the territory of the world you need to acheive victory. I will say that this part of the game must've taken a lot of thought and input from many developers with extensive knowledge of the history of the 18th century as well as having more than the most basic understanding of how governments and the global economy at the time should be handled in a strategy game. The campaign map is full of so many choices that you as the ruler of the nation can hardly dismiss because if you do there are always consequences. It was very easy for me to waste 45 minutes at a time on one turn making sure that I did absolutely every single thing on the campaign map that I had meant to do for that one turn so that I would still have enough income on the next turn to be able to assault Calcutta and destroy the Mughal Empire once and for all after 50 hours of time fighting them back across the continent of India. 

The game is very deep and a campaign will take you far more than one or two sessions to complete no matter how long you choose to sit in front of your computer screen. The more preparation and time that you spend thinking about any one area of the game will reflect an overall sort of identity of the nation that you ultimately will build. You might have the worlds greatest army but your people hate you and revolt every time you click the End Turn button. It would have been much less of a headache on my part if I had just turned the automanage funcion on when I started playing and never delved into anything but the battle and expansion aspects of the game. 

And that is my biggest problem with the game unfortunately. After all the time I spent playing I wish I WOULD have turned automanage on. The game doesn't have a rewarding enough outcome and too many flaws with the battle system for me to have felt accomplished by the end of a campaign -- and the stupid movement points on the campaign map were fucking horseshit . . . . Often times I would cheat save right before making any kind of movements on the world map because I didn't know exactly how far I could move an army, or because the game would show me a green arrow leading all the way to a region capital I wanted to take control of and my army would move to just outside of the city. There are so many annoyances that it's easy to lose interest in the game itself I started to dread all the time that I was wasting to get everything right. It stopped being fun at a certain point and became work which is not how I wanted to feel playing a game with as awesome of a concept as this. I will say I'm not the world's biggest gamer and I will admit that I don't think I'm hardcore enought to play a game like this. I played this game as long as I did because I was committed and disciplined and had an idea in my head of what I wanted to acheive and how awesome it would feel when I did. But the fun factor definitely left me far short of my goal and I will say that it was not worth it. I'm not sorry I bought Empire for $9.99, and I can still say that I am impressed by the game after all that time I poured into it but am now without any desire to keep playing it.

I've seen the reviews of other games of the series and I want there to be a better Total War game to be developed than the one I played anyway. This is the type of game that needs more polish than it has and I would like to see what Creative Assembly could come up with if they listen to their online fan base and to also give one of these titles a much longer development time. That's what they really need is to have the little details and small flaws fixed so that the irritation factor isn't so bad. I realize just how many things the game is trying to run and juggle at the same time, and it would be absolutely incredible if they all worked, but I'd like to think that a game this big is tested before it is released for all the little annoying shit that you know is bound to happen with something with this much depth. That being said if you look at the big picture and try not to focus on so many things that piss you off, you'll find that war is Hell and it's fucking beautiful . . . . 8/10 (for the big picture)  6/10(for the experience of playing Empire)

Okay I'm going to just dive right in here and give my opinion than support with my evidence, I absolutely LOVE this game! Playing this allows me to experience one of my favorite times in history where so much could have gone so differently with tiny decisions that no one would have thought differently about. As Prussia you have a fairly large standing army, but very few territories to back it up, and even those two aren't connected offering a real challenge to meet the victory conditions. England starts with an average number of territories but should you do well enough in the Americas you get rewarded with guess who? The 13 colonies! So they start as already superior in funds and Troops, and should they push they overwhelm everyone. Other nations such as France and Spain have oppurtunities to destroy other nations decently often, such as Spain/France teaming up on the United Provinces, if you could hold off the rebellions you have a nice moneymaking region.
And then there is diplomacy, allowing you to either make or break a web of allies or enemies with the press of a button.
All in all, for Diplomacy and for my favourite timeline 10/10! And this is my personal opinion so those of you who don't like this game, don't go out loud saying "This game sucks! 0/10!!!!", actually leave reasons and criticism for everyone to actually benefit from in the community.

As a fan of the Total War franchise, I find Empire: Total War my personal favourite.  The naval battles really set it apart from the earlier titles.  And the tech tree is massive!  It requires you to either really focus on certain aspects or have multiple colleges for research.  The three theatres of operation (Europe, America, and India) and multiple trade zones add to the challenge of maintaining your empire.  You have many fronts to defend but so do your adversaries.  Overall it's a very solid game.

Highlights of latest campaign playing as the Netherlands:

-Crushed the French by taking Paris by turn 20.  Their overseas colonies all go rebel except one; welcome to the world stage the nation of Quebec.

-Conquered Madrid.  Gave it to one of my new best friends:  Portugal.  Spain only exists on Sardinia now.

-Conquered all of Scandinavia.  Gave it all to my other best friend: Hannover.  They are a true world power now and have been taking it to Russia ever since giving them Finland.

-After stabbing former ally England in the back found that the Irish and Scottish were happy to have my rule but England itself rebelled four times before they consented to the yoke.  They now love the Republic too.

-As a result of the conquest of England the United States rose in America.  Started a war with me over the Carolinas.  I captured the USS Consitution and it's now the flagship of my frigate fleet.  Thanks for the unique unit, America!  And the war doesn't go so good for them...

-The Maratha Confederacy foolishly declared war on me.  Used a V.O.C. army to conquer all of their holdings in India.  Kept a couple territories, gave the rest to the very friendly Mughal Empire.  Hinduism is almost non-existent as a religion, replaced by Protestantism and Islam.

An excellent addition to the total war series. The naval battles are a welcome and engaging inclusion, the research based tech tree also adds to your custimization ability, and the many traditional total war features are refined. The inclusion of three distinct theatres and an expansive new world impact gameplay as well. However, many will find the gun-based combat to be less enjoyable than the lance, sword, and bow based combat of past and more recent total wars. Also, the political systems and general development is not particularly deep. It may be more closely tied to the time period, but grooming family members who stay with you for much of the game is not an option. Overall, there are hundreds of hours of dynamic play here.
